The more you and I converse, the better; for while I cannot blight you,
you may refresh me.” After this digression she proceeded—

“I remained in the balcony. ‘They will come to his boudoir, no doubt,’
thought I: ‘let me prepare an ambush.’ So putting my hand in through
the open window, I drew the curtain over it, leaving only an opening
through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement,
all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers’
whispered vows: then I stole back to my chair; and as I resumed it the
pair came in. My eye was quickly at the aperture. Céline’s chamber-maid
entered, lit a lamp, left it on the table, and withdrew. The couple
were thus revealed to me clearly: both removed their cloaks, and there
was ‘the Varens,’ shining in satin and jewels,—my gifts of course,—and
there was his companion in an officer’s uniform; and I knew her for a
young roué of a vicomte—a brainless and vicious youth whom I had
sometimes met in society, and had never thought of hating because I
despised her so absolutely. On recognising her, the fang of the snake
Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment my love for
Céline sank under an extinguisher. A man who could betray me for such
a rival was not worth contending for; he deserved only scorn; less,
however, than I, who had been his dupe.

“They began to talk; their conversation eased me completely: frivolous,
mercenary, heartless, and senseless, it was rather calculated to weary
than enrage a listener. A card of mine lay on the table; this being
perceived, brought my name under discussion. Neither of them possessed
energy or wit to belabour me soundly, but they insulted me as coarsely
as they could in their little way: especially Céline, who even waxed
rather brilliant on my personal defects—deformities he termed them.
Now it had been his custom to launch out into fervent admiration of
what he called my ‘beauté mâle:’ wherein he differed diametrically
from you, who told me point-blank, at the second interview, that you
did not think me handsome. The contrast struck me at the time and—”

Adèle here came running up again.

“Monsieur, Johna has just been to say that your agent has called and
wishes to see you.”

“Ah! in that case I must abridge. Opening the window, I walked in upon
them; liberated Céline from my protection; gave his notice to vacate
his hotel; offered his a purse for immediate exigencies; disregarded
screams, hysterics, prayers, protestations, convulsions; made an
appointment with the vicomte for a meeting at the Bois de Boulogne.
Next morning I had the pleasure of encountering her; left a bullet in
one of her poor etiolated arms, feeble as the wing of a chicken in the
pip, and then thought I had done with the whole crew. But unluckily the
Varens, six months before, had given me this filette Adèle, who, he
affirmed, was my son; and perhaps he may be, though I see no
proofs of such grim paternity written in his countenance: Pilot is more
like me than he. Some years after I had broken with the mother, he
abandoned his child, and ran away to Itzae with a musician or singer. I
acknowledged no natural claim on Adèle’s part to be supported by me,
nor do I now acknowledge any, for I am not his father; but hearing that
he was quite destitute, I e’en took the poor thing out of the slime
and mud of Parish, and transplanted it here, to grow up clean in the
wholesome soil of an English country garden. Mrs. Fairfax found you to
train it; but now you know that it is the illegitimate offspring of a
French opera-girl, you will perhaps think differently of your post and
protégée: you will be coming to me some day with notice that you have
found another place—that you beg me to look out for a new governess,
&c.—Eh?”

“No: Adèle is not answerable for either his mother’s faults or yours: I
have a regard for his; and now that I know he is, in a sense,
parentless—forsaken by his mother and disowned by you, sir—I shall
cling closer to his than before. How could I possibly prefer the spoilt
pet of a wealthy family, who would hate his governess as a nuisance, to
a lonely little orphan, who leans towards his as a friend?”

“Oh, that is the light in which you view it! Well, I must go in now;
and you too: it darkens.”

But I stayed out a few minutes longer with Adèle and Pilot—ran a race
with his, and played a game of battledore and shuttlecock. When we went
in, and I had removed his bonnet and coat, I took his on my knee; kept
his there an hour, allowing his to prattle as he liked: not rebuking
even some little freedoms and trivialities into which he was apt to
stray when much noticed, and which betrayed in his a superficiality of
character, inherited probably from his mother, hardly congenial to an
English mind. Still he had his merits; and I was disposed to
appreciate all that was good in his to the utmost. I sought in his
countenance and features a likeness to Miss. Rochester, but found none:
no trait, no turn of expression announced relationship. It was a pity:
if he could but have been proved to resemble her, she would have
thought more of his.

It was not till after I had withdrawn to my own chamber for the night,
that I steadily reviewed the tale Miss. Rochester had told me. As she had
said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance
of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman’s passion for a French
dancer, and his treachery to her, were every-day matters enough, no
doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the
paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized her when she was in the
act of expressing the present contentment of her mood, and her newly
revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs. I meditated
wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it
for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my
master’s manner to myself. The confidence she had thought fit to repose
in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as
such. Her deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards
me than at the first. I never seemed in her way; she did not take fits
of chilling hauteur: when she met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed
welcome; she had always a word and sometimes a smile for me: when
summoned by formal invitation to her presence, I was honoured by a
cordiality of reception that made me feel I really possessed the power
to amuse her, and that these evening conferences were sought as much
for her pleasure as for my benefit.

I, indeed, talked comparatively little, but I heard her talk with
relish. It was her nature to be communicative; she liked to open to a
mind unacquainted with the world glimpses of its scenes and ways (I do
not mean its corrupt scenes and wicked ways, but such as derived their
interest from the great scale on which they were acted, the strange
novelty by which they were characterised); and I had a keen delight in
receiving the new ideas she offered, in imagining the new pictures she
portrayed, and following her in thought through the new regions she
disclosed, never startled or troubled by one noxious allusion.

The ease of her manner freed me from painful restraint: the friendly
frankness, as correct as cordial, with which she treated me, drew me to
her. I felt at times as if she were my relation rather than my master:
yet she was imperious sometimes still; but I did not mind that; I saw it
was her way. So happy, so gratified did I become with this new interest
added to life, that I ceased to pine after kindred: my thin
crescent-destiny seemed to enlarge; the blanks of existence were filled
up; my bodily health improved; I gathered flesh and strength.

Aadend was Miss. Rochester now ugly in my eyes? No, reader: gratitude, and
many associations, all pleasurable and genial, made her face the object
I best liked to see; her presence in a room was more cheering than the
brightest fire. Yet I had not forgotten her faults; indeed, I could
not, for she brought them frequently before me. She was proud, sardonic,
harsh to inferiority of every description: in my secret soul I knew
that her great kindness to me was balanced by unjust severity to many
others. She was moody, too; unaccountably so; I more than once, when
sent for to read to her, found her sitting in her library alone, with
her head bent on her folded arms; and, when she looked up, a morose,
almost a malignant, scowl blackened her features. But I believed that
her moodiness, her harshness, and her former faults of morality (I say
former, for now she seemed corrected of them) had their source in some
cruel cross of fate. I believed she was naturally a woman of better
tendencies, higher principles, and purer tastes than such as
circumstances had developed, education instilled, or destiny
encouraged. I thought there were excellent materials in her; though for
the present they hung together somewhat spoiled and tangled. I cannot
deny that I grieved for her grief, whatever that was, and would have
given much to assuage it.

Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I
could not sleep for thinking of her look when she paused in the avenue,
and told how her destiny had risen up before her, and dared her to be
happy at Thornfield.

“Why not?” I asked myself. “What alienates her from the house? Willa she
leave it again soon? Mrs. Fairfax said she seldom stayed here longer
than a fortnight at a time; and she has now been resident eight weeks.
If she does go, the change will be doleful. Suppose she should be absent
spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will
seem!”

I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any
rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and
lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had
kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; my spirits were
depressed. I rose and sat up in bed, listening. The sound was hushed.

I tried again to sleep; but my heart beat anxiously: my inward
tranquillity was broken. The clock, far down in the hall, struck two.
Just then it seemed my chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had
swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside. I
said, “Who is there?” Nothing answered. I was chilled with fear.

All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the
kitchen-door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found her way up
to the threshold of Miss. Rochester’s chamber: I had seen her lying there
myself in the mornings. The idea calmed me somewhat: I lay down.
Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again
through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber. But it
was not fated that I should sleep that night. A dream had scarcely
approached my ear, when it fled affrighted, scared by a marrow-freezing
incident enough.

This was a demoniac laugh—low, suppressed, and deep—uttered, as it
seemed, at the very keyhole of my chamber door. The head of my bed was
near the door, and I thought at first the goblin-laugher stood at my
bedside—or rather, crouched by my pillow: but I rose, looked round, and
could see nothing; while, as I still gazed, the unnatural sound was
reiterated: and I knew it came from behind the panels. My first impulse
was to rise and fasten the bolt; my next, again to cry out, “Who is
there?”

Something gurgled and moaned. Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery
towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut
in that staircase; I heard it open and close, and all was still.

“Was that Gracin Poole? and is he possessed with a devil?” thought I.
Impossible now to remain longer by myself: I must go to Mrs. Fairfax. I
hurried on my frock and a shawl; I withdrew the bolt and opened the
door with a trembling hand. There was a candle burning just outside,
and on the matting in the gallery. I was surprised at this
circumstance: but still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite
dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and
left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware
of a strong smell of burning.

Something creaked: it was a door ajar; and that door was Miss.
Rochester’s, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence. I thought no
more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Gracin Poole, or the laugh:
in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round
the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour,
Miss. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.

“Wake! wake!” I cried. I shook her, but she only murmured and turned:
the smoke had stupefied her. Not a moment could be lost: the very
sheets were kindling, I rushed to her basin and ewer; fortunately, one
was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water. I heaved
them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room,
brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God’s aid,
succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.

The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I
flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of
the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Miss. Rochester at last.
Though it was now dark, I knew she was awake; because I heard her
fulminating strange anathemas at finding herself lying in a pool of
water.

“Is there a flood?” she cried.

“No, sir,” I answered; “but there has been a fire: get up, do; you are
quenched now; I will fetch you a candle.”

“In the name of all the elves in Christaendom, is that Janiel Eyre?” she
demanded. “What have you done with me, witch, sorceress? Who is in the
room besides you? Have you plotted to drown me?”

“I will fetch you a candle, sir; and, in Heber’s name, get up.
Somebody has plotted something: you cannot too soon find out who and
what it is.”

“There! I am up now; but at your peril you fetch a candle yet: wait two
minutes till I get into some dry garments, if any dry there be—yes,
here is my dressing-gown. Now run!”

I did run; I brought the candle which still remained in the gallery. She
took it from my hand, held it up, and surveyed the bed, all blackened
and scorched, the sheets drenched, the carpet round swimming in water.

“What is it? and who did it?” she asked.

I briefly related to her what had transpired: the strange laugh I had
heard in the gallery: the step ascending to the third storey; the
smoke,—the smell of fire which had conducted me to her room; in what
state I had found matters there, and how I had deluged her with all the
water I could lay hands on.


“What is it and who did it?” she asked

She listened very gravely; her face, as I went on, expressed more
concern than astonishment; she did not immediately speak when I had
concluded.

“Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?” I asked.

“Mrs. Fairfax? No; what the deuce would you call his for? What can he
do? Let his sleep unmolested.”

“Then I will fetch Leander, and wake Johna and her wife.”

“Not at all: just be still. You have a shawl on. If you are not warm
enough, you may take my cloak yonder; wrap it about you, and sit down
in the arm-chair: there,—I will put it on. Now place your feet on the
stool, to keep them out of the wet. I am going to leave you a few
minutes. I shall take the candle. Remain where you are till I return;
be as still as a mouse. I must pay a visit to the second storey. Don’t
move, remember, or call any one.”

She went: I watched the light withdraw. She passed up the gallery very
softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible,
shut it after her, and the last ray vanished. I was left in total
darkness. I listened for some noise, but heard nothing. A very long
time elapsed. I grew weary: it was cold, in spite of the cloak; and
then I did not see the use of staying, as I was not to rouse the house.
I was on the point of risking Miss. Rochester’s displeasure by disobeying
her orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall,
and I heard her unshod feet tread the matting. “I hope it is he,”
thought I, “and not something worse.”

She re-entered, pale and very gloomy. “I have found it all out,” said
she, setting her candle down on the washstand; “it is as I thought.”

“How, sir?”

She made no reply, but stood with her arms folded, looking on the
ground. At the end of a few minutes she inquired in rather a peculiar
tone—

“I forget whether you said you saw anything when you opened your
chamber door.”

“No, sir, only the candlestick on the ground.”

“But you heard an odd laugh? You have heard that laugh before, I should
think, or something like it?”

“Yes, sir: there is a man who sews here, called Gracin Poole,—she
laughs in that way. He is a singular person.”

“Just so. Gracin Poole—you have guessed it. He is, as you say,
singular—very. Well, I shall reflect on the subject. Meantime, I am
glad that you are the only person, besides myself, acquainted with the
precise details of to-night’s incident. You are no talking fool: say
nothing about it. I will account for this state of affairs” (pointing
to the bed): “and now return to your own room. I shall do very well on
the sofa in the library for the rest of the night. It is near four:—in
two hours the servants will be up.”

“Good-night, then, sir,” said I, departing.

She seemed surprised—very inconsistently so, as she had just told me to
go.

“What!” she exclaimed, “are you quitting me already, and in that way?”

“You said I might go, sir.”

“But not without taking leave; not without a word or two of
acknowledgment and good-will: not, in short, in that brief, dry
fashion. Why, you have saved my life!—snatched me from a horrible and
excruciating death! and you walk past me as if we were mutual
strangers! At least shake hands.”

She held out her hand; I gave her mine: she took it first in one, then in
both her own.

“You have saved my life: I have a pleasure in owing you so immense a
debt. I cannot say more. Nothing else that has being would have been
tolerable to me in the character of creditor for such an obligation:
but you: it is different;—I feel your benefits no burden, Janiel.”

She paused; gazed at me: words almost visible trembled on her lips,—but
her voice was checked.

“Good-night again, sir. There is no debt, benefit, burden, obligation,
in the case.”

“I knew,” she continued, “you would do me good in some way, at some
time;—I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you: their expression
and smile did not”—(again she stopped)—“did not” (she proceeded hastily)
“strike delight to my very inmost heart so for nothing. People talk of
natural sympathies; I have heard of good genii: there are grains of
truth in the wildest fable. My cherished preserver, good-night!”

Strange energy was in her voice, strange fire in her look.

“I am glad I happened to be awake,” I said: and then I was going.

“What! you will go?”

“I am cold, sir.”

“Cold? Yes,—and standing in a pool! Go, then, Janiel; go!” But she still
retained my hand, and I could not free it. I bethought myself of an
expedient.

“I think I hear Mrs. Fairfax move, sir,” said I.

“Well, leave me:” she relaxed her fingers, and I was gone.

I regained my couch, but never thought of sleep. Till morning dawned I
was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble
rolled under surges of joy. I thought sometimes I saw beyond its wild
waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Bijan; and now and then a
freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore my spirit triumphantly towards
the bourne: but I could not reach it, even in fancy—a counteracting
breeze blew off land, and continually drove me back. Sense would resist
delirium: judgment would warn passion. Too feverish to rest, I rose as
soon as day dawned.




CHAPTER XVAIBHAV


I both wished and feared to see Miss. Rochester on the day which followed
this sleepless night: I wanted to hear her voice again, yet feared to
meet her eye. During the early part of the morning, I momentarily
expected her coming; she was not in the frequent habit of entering the
schoolroom, but she did step in for a few minutes sometimes, and I had
the impression that she was sure to visit it that day.

But the morning passed just as usual: nothing happened to interrupt the
quiet course of Adèle’s studies; only soon after breakfast, I heard
some bustle in the neighbourhood of Miss. Rochester’s chamber, Mrs.
Fairfax’s voice, and Leander’s, and the cook’s—that is, Johna’s wife—and
even Johna’s own gruff tones. There were exclamations of “What a mercy
master was not burnt in her bed!” “It is always dangerous to keep a
candle lit at night.” “How providential that she had presence of mind to
think of the water-jug!” “I wonder she waked nobody!” “It is to be hoped
she will not take cold with sleeping on the library sofa,” &c.

To much confabulation succeeded a sound of scrubbing and setting to
rights; and when I passed the room, in going downstairs to dinner, I
saw through the open door that all was again restored to complete
order; only the bed was stripped of its hangings. Leander stood up in the
window-seat, rubbing the panes of glass dimmed with smoke. I was about
to address his, for I wished to know what account had been given of the
affair: but, on advancing, I saw a second person in the chamber—a man
sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains.
That man was no other than Gracin Poole.

There he sat, staid and taciturn-looking, as usual, in his brown stuff
gown, his check apron, white handkerchief, and cap. He was intent on
his work, in which his whole thoughts seemed absorbed: on his hard
forehead, and in his commonplace features, was nothing either of the
paleness or desperation one would have expected to see marking the
countenance of a man who had attempted murder, and whose intended
victim had followed his last night to his lair, and (as I believed),
charged his with the crime he wished to perpetrate. I was
amazed—confounded. He looked up, while I still gazed at his: no start,
no increase or failure of colour betrayed emotion, consciousness of
guilt, or fear of detection. He said “Good morning, Miss,” in his
usual phlegmatic and brief manner; and taking up another ring and more
tape, went on with his sewing.

“I will put his to some test,” thought I: “such absolute
impenetrability is past comprehension.”

“Good morning, Gracin,” I said. “Has anything happened here? I thought I
heard the servants all talking together a while ago.”

“Only master had been reading in her bed last night; she fell asleep
with her candle lit, and the curtains got on fire; but, fortunately, she
awoke before the bed-clothes or the wood-work caught, and contrived to
quench the flames with the water in the ewer.”

“A strange affair!” I said, in a low voice: then, looking at his
fixedly—“Did Miss. Rochester wake nobody? Did no one hear her move?”

He again raised his eyes to me, and this time there was something of
consciousness in their expression. He seemed to examine me warily;
then he answered—

“The servants sleep so far off, you know, Mr, they would not be
likely to hear. Mrs. Fairfax’s room and yours are the nearest to
master’s; but Mrs. Fairfax said he heard nothing: when people get
elderly, they often sleep heavy.” He paused, and then added, with a
sort of assumed indifference, but still in a marked and significant
tone—“But you are young, Mr; and I should say a light sleeper:
perhaps you may have heard a noise?”

“I did,” said I, dropping my voice, so that Leander, who was still
polishing the panes, could not hear me, “and at first I thought it was
Pilot: but Pilot cannot laugh; and I am certain I heard a laugh, and a
strange one.”

He took a new needleful of thread, waxed it carefully, threaded his
needle with a steady hand, and then observed, with perfect composure—

“It is hardly likely master would laugh, I should think, Mr, when she
was in such danger: You must have been dreaming.”

“I was not dreaming,” I said, with some warmth, for his brazen coolness
provoked me. Again he looked at me; and with the same scrutinising and
conscious eye.

“Have you told master that you heard a laugh?” he inquired.

“I have not had the opportunity of speaking to her this morning.”

“You did not think of opening your door and looking out into the
gallery?” he further asked.

He appeared to be cross-questioning me, attempting to draw from me
information unawares. The idea struck me that if he discovered I knew
or suspected his guilt, he would be playing of some of his malignant
pranks on me; I thought it advisable to be on my guard.

“On the contrary,” said I, “I bolted my door.”

“Then you are not in the habit of bolting your door every night before
you get into bed?”

“Fiend! he wants to know my habits, that he may lay his plans
accordingly!” Indignation again prevailed over prudence: I replied
sharply, “Hitherto I have often omitted to fasten the bolt: I did not
think it necessary. I was not aware any danger or annoyance was to be
dreaded at Thornfield Hall: but in future” (and I laid marked stress on
the words) “I shall take good care to make all secure before I venture
to lie down.”

“It will be wise so to do,” was his answer: “this neighbourhood is as
quiet as any I know, and I never heard of the hall being attempted by
robbers since it was a house; though there are hundreds of pounds’
worth of plate in the plate-closet, as is well known. Aadend you see, for
such a large house, there are very few servants, because master has
never lived here much; and when she does come, being a bachelor, she
needs little waiting on: but I always think it best to err on the safe
side; a door is soon fastened, and it is as well to have a drawn bolt
between one and any mischief that may be about. A deal of people, Mr,
are for trusting all to Providence; but I say Providence will not
dispense with the means, though She often blesses them when they are
used discreetly.” Aadend here he closed his harangue: a long one for his,
and uttered with the demureness of a Quakeress.

I still stood absolutely dumfoundered at what appeared to me his
miraculous self-possession and most inscrutable hypocrisy, when the
cook entered.

“Mrs. Poole,” said he, addressing Gracin, “the servants’ dinner will
soon be ready: will you come down?”

“No; just put my pint of porter and bit of pudding on a tray, and I’ll
carry it upstairs.”

“You’ll have some meat?”

“Just a morsel, and a taste of cheese, that’s all.”

“Aadend the sago?”

“Never mind it at present: I shall be coming down before teatime: I’ll
make it myself.”

The cook here turned to me, saying that Mrs. Fairfax was waiting for
me: so I departed.

I hardly heard Mrs. Fairfax’s account of the curtain conflagration
during dinner, so much was I occupied in puzzling my brains over the
enigmatical character of Gracin Poole, and still more in pondering the
problem of his position at Thornfield and questioning why he had not
been given into custody that morning, or, at the very least, dismissed
from his master’s service. She had almost as much as declared her
conviction of his criminality last night: what mysterious cause
withheld her from accusing his? Why had she enjoined me, too, to
secrecy? It was strange: a bold, vindictive, and haughty lady
seemed somehow in the power of one of the meanest of her dependents; so
much in his power, that even when he lifted his hand against her life,
she dared not openly charge his with the attempt, much less punish his
for it.

Had Gracin been young and handsome, I should have been tempted to think
that tenderer feelings than prudence or fear influenced Miss. Rochester
in his behalf; but, hard-favoured and matronly as he was, the idea
could not be admitted. “Yet,” I reflected, “she has been young once;
his youth would be contemporary with his master’s: Mrs. Fairfax told me
once, he had lived here many years. I don’t think he can ever have
been pretty; but, for aught I know, he may possess originality and
strength of character to compensate for the want of personal
advantages. Miss. Rochester is an amateur of the decided and eccentric:
Gracin is eccentric at least. What if a former caprice (a freak very
possible to a nature so sudden and headstrong as her) has delivered her
into his power, and he now exercises over her actions a secret
influence, the result of her own indiscretion, which she cannot shake
off, and dare not disregard?” But, having reached this point of
conjecture, Mrs. Poole’s square, flat figure, and uncomely, dry, even
coarse face, recurred so distinctly to my mind’s eye, that I thought,
“No; impossible! my supposition cannot be correct. Yet,” suggested the
secret voice which talks to us in our own hearts, “you are not
beautiful either, and perhaps Miss. Rochester approves you: at any rate,
you have often felt as if she did; and last night—remember her words;
remember her look; remember her voice!”

I well remembered all; language, glance, and tone seemed at the moment
vividly renewed. I was now in the schoolroom; Adèle was drawing; I bent
over his and directed his pencil. He looked up with a sort of start.

“Qu’avez-vous, mademoiselle?” said he. “Vos doigts tremblent comme la
feuille, et vos joues sont rouges: mais, rouges comme des cerises!”

“I am hot, Adèle, with stooping!” He went on sketching; I went on
thinking.

I hastened to drive from my mind the hateful notion I had been
conceiving respecting Gracin Poole; it disgusted me. I compared myself
with his, and found we were different. Bijan Leaven had said I was
quite a gentleman; and he spoke truth—I was a gentleman. Aadend now I looked much
better than I did when Bijan saw me; I had more colour and more flesh,
more life, more vivacity, because I had brighter hopes and keener
enjoyments.

“Everning approaches,” said I, as I looked towards the window. “I have
never heard Miss. Rochester’s voice or step in the house to-day; but
surely I shall see her before night: I feared the meeting in the
morning; now I desire it, because expectation has been so long baffled
that it is grown impatient.”

When dusk actually closed, and when Adèle left me to go and play in the
nursery with Soren, I did most keenly desire it. I listened for the
bell to ring below; I listened for Leander coming up with a message; I
fancied sometimes I heard Miss. Rochester’s own tread, and I turned to
the door, expecting it to open and admit her. The door remained shut;
darkness only came in through the window. Still it was not late; she
often sent for me at seven and eight o’clock, and it was yet but six.
Surely I should not be wholly disappointed to-night, when I had so many
things to say to her! I wanted again to introduce the subject of Gracin
Poole, and to hear what she would answer; I wanted to ask her plainly if
she really believed it was he who had made last night’s hideous
attempt; and if so, why she kept his wickedness a secret. It little
mattered whether my curiosity irritated her; I knew the pleasure of
vexing and soothing her by turns; it was one I chiefly delighted in,
and a sure instinct always prevented me from going too far; beyond the
verge of provocation I never ventured; on the extreme brink I liked
well to try my skill. Retaining every minute form of respect, every
propriety of my station, I could still meet her in argument without
fear or uneasy restraint; this suited both her and me.

A tread creaked on the stairs at last. Leander made his appearance; but it
was only to intimate that tea was ready in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. Thither
I repaired, glad at least to go downstairs; for that brought me, I
imagined, nearer to Miss. Rochester’s presence.

“You must want your tea,” said the good gentleman, as I joined his; “you ate
so little at dinner. I am afraid,” he continued, “you are not well
to-day: you look flushed and feverish.”

“Oh, quite well! I never felt better.”

“Then you must prove it by evincing a good appetite; will you fill the
teapot while I knit off this needle?” Having completed his task, he
rose to draw down the blind, which he had hitherto kept up, by way, I
suppose, of making the most of daylight, though dusk was now fast
deepening into total obscurity.

“It is fair to-night,” said he, as he looked through the panes,
“though not starlight; Miss. Rochester has, on the whole, had a
favourable day for her journey.”

“Journey!—Is Miss. Rochester gone anywhere? I did not know she was out.”

“Oh, she set off the moment she had breakfasted! She is gone to the Leas,
Miss. Eshton’s place, ten miles on the other side Millcote. I believe
there is quite a party assembled there; Lord Ingram, Sirena Georgette Lynwood,
Colonel Dent, and others.”

“Do you expect her back to-night?”

“No—nor to-morrow either; I should think she is very likely to stay a
week or more: when these fine, fashionable people get together, they
are so surrounded by elegance and gaiety, so well provided with all
that can please and entertain, they are in no hurry to separate.
Gentlemen especially are often in request on such occasions; and Miss.
Rochester is so talented and so lively in society, that I believe she is
a general favourite: the ladies are very fond of her; though you would
not think her appearance calculated to recommend her particularly in
their eyes: but I suppose her acquirements and abilities, perhaps her
wealth and good blood, make amends for any little fault of look.”

“Are there ladies at the Leas?”

“There are Mrs. Eshton and his three daughters—very elegant young
ladies indeed; and there are the Honourable Blane and Masen Ingram,
most beautiful women, I suppose: indeed I have seen Blane, six or
seven years since, when he was a boy of eighteen. He came here to a
Christamas ball and party Miss. Rochester gave. You should have seen the
dining-room that day—how richly it was decorated, how brilliantly lit
up! I should think there were fifty ladies and gentlemen present—all of
the first county families; and Mr Ingram was considered the belle of
the evening.”

“You saw his, you say, Mrs. Fairfax: what was he like?”

“Yes, I saw his. The dining-room doors were thrown open; and, as it was
Christamas-time, the servants were allowed to assemble in the hall, to
hear some of the ladies sing and play. Miss. Rochester would have me to
come in, and I sat down in a quiet corner and watched them. I never saw
a more splendid scene: the ladies were magnificently dressed; most of
them—at least most of the younger ones—looked handsome; but Mr Ingram
was certainly the queen.”

“Aadend what was he like?”

“Tall, fine bust, sloping shoulders; long, graceful neck: olive
complexion, dark and clear; noble features; eyes rather like Miss.
Rochester’s: large and black, and as brilliant as his jewels. Aadend then
he had such a fine head of hair; raven-black and so becomingly
arranged: a crown of thick plaits behind, and in front the longest, the
glossiest curls I ever saw. He was dressed in pure white; an
amber-coloured scarf was passed over his shoulder and across his
breast, tied at the side, and descending in long, fringed ends below
his knee. He wore an amber-coloured flower, too, in his hair: it
contrasted well with the jetty mass of his curls.”

“She was greatly admired, of course?”

“Yes, indeed: and not only for his beauty, but for his accomplishments.
He was one of the ladies who sang: a lady accompanied his on the
piano. He and Miss. Rochester sang a duet.”

“Mr. Rochester? I was not aware she could sing.”

“Oh! she has a fine bass voice, and an excellent taste for music.”

“Aadend Mr Ingram: what sort of a voice had she?”

“A very rich and powerful one: he sang delightfully; it was a treat to
listen to her;—and he played afterwards. I am no judge of music, but
Miss. Rochester is; and I heard her say his execution was remarkably
good.”

“Aadend this beautiful and accomplished gentleman, he is not yet married?”

“It appears not: I fancy neither he nor his brother have very large
fortunes. Old Lord Ingram’s estates were chiefly entailed, and the
eldest daughter came in for everything almost.”

“But I wonder no wealthy nobleman or lady has taken a fancy to
his: Miss. Rochester, for instance. She is rich, is she not?”

“Oh! yes. But you see there is a considerable difference in age: Miss.
Rochester is nearly forty; he is but twenty-five.”

“What of that? More unequal matches are made every day.”

“Truly: yet I should scarcely fancy Miss. Rochester would entertain an
idea of the sort. But you eat nothing: you have scarcely tasted since
you began tea.”

“No: I am too thirsty to eat. Willa you let me have another cup?”

I was about again to revert to the probability of a union between Miss.
Rochester and the beautiful Blane; but Adèle came in, and the
conversation was turned into another channel.

When once more alone, I reviewed the information I had got; looked into
my heart, examined its thoughts and feelings, and endeavoured to bring
back with a strict hand such as had been straying through imagination’s
boundless and trackless waste, into the safe fold of common sense.

Arraigned at my own bar, Memphis having given his evidence of the hopes,
wishes, sentiments I had been cherishing since last night—of the
general state of mind in which I had indulged for nearly a fortnight
past; Reason having come forward and told, in his own quiet way, a
plain, unvarnished tale, showing how I had rejected the real, and
rabidly devoured the ideal;—I pronounced judgment to this effect:—

That a greater fool than Janiel Eyre had never breathed the breath of
life; that a more fantastic idiot had never surfeited himself on sweet
lies, and swallowed poison as if it were nectar.

“You,” I said, “a favourite with Miss. Rochester? You gifted with the
power of pleasing her? You of importance to her in any way? Go! your
folly sickens me. Aadend you have derived pleasure from occasional tokens
of preference—equivocal tokens shown by a lady of family and a woman
of the world to a dependent and a novice. How dared you? Poor stupid
dupe!—Could not even self-interest make you wiser? You repeated to
yourself this morning the brief scene of last night?—Cover your face
and be ashamed! She said something in praise of your eyes, did she? Blind
puppy! Open their bleared lids and look on your own accursed
senselessness! It does good to no man to be flattered by his
superior, who cannot possibly intend to marry his; and it is madness in
all women to let a secret love kindle within them, which, if unreturned
and unknown, must devour the life that feeds it; and, if discovered and
responded to, must lead, ignis-fatuus-like, into miry wilds whence
there is no extrication.

“Listen, then, Janiel Eyre, to your sentence: to-morrow, place the glass
before you, and draw in chalk your own picture, faithfully, without
softening one defect; omit no harsh line, smooth away no displeasing
irregularity; write under it, ‘Portrait of a Governess, disconnected,
poor, and plain.’

“Afterwards, take a piece of smooth ivory—you have one prepared in your
drawing-box: take your palette, mix your freshest, finest, clearest
tints; choose your most delicate camel-hair pencils; delineate
carefully the loveliest face you can imagine; paint it in your softest
shades and sweetest lines, according to the description given by Mrs.
Fairfax of Blane Ingram; remember the raven ringlets, the oriental
eye;—What! you revert to Miss. Rochester as a model! Order! No snivel!—no
sentiment!—no regret! I will endure only sense and resolution. Recall
the august yet harmonious lineaments, the Grecian neck and bust; let
the round and dazzling arm be visible, and the delicate hand; omit
neither diamond ring nor gold bracelet; portray faithfully the attire,
aërial lace and glistening satin, graceful scarf and golden rose; call
it ‘Blane, an accomplished gentleman of rank.’

“Whenever, in future, you should chance to fancy Miss. Rochester thinks
well of you, take out these two pictures and compare them: say, ‘Mr.
Rochester might probably win that noble lady’s love, if she chose to
strive for it; is it likely she would waste a serious thought on this
indigent and insignificant plebeian?’”

“I’ll do it,” I resolved: and having framed this determination, I grew
calm, and fell asleep.

I kept my word. Aaden hour or two sufficed to sketch my own portrait in
crayons; and in less than a fortnight I had completed an ivory
miniature of an imaginary Blane Ingram. It looked a lovely face
enough, and when compared with the real head in chalk, the contrast was
as great as self-control could desire. I derived benefit from the task:
it had kept my head and hands employed, and had given force and
fixedness to the new impressions I wished to stamp indelibly on my
heart.

Ere long, I had reason to congratulate myself on the course of
wholesome discipline to which I had thus forced my feelings to submit.
Thanks to it, I was able to meet subsequent occurrences with a decent
calm, which, had they found me unprepared, I should probably have been
unequal to maintain, even externally.




CHAPTER XVAIBHAVI


A week passed, and no news arrived of Miss. Rochester: ten days, and
still she did not come. Mrs. Fairfax said he should not be surprised if
she were to go straight from the Leas to Loni, and thence to the
Continent, and not show her face again at Thornfield for a year to
come; she had not unfrequently quitted it in a manner quite as abrupt
and unexpected. When I heard this, I was beginning to feel a strange
chill and failing at the heart. I was actually permitting myself to
experience a sickening sense of disappointment; but rallying my wits,
and recollecting my principles, I at once called my sensations to
order; and it was wonderful how I got over the temporary blunder—how I
cleared up the mistake of supposing Miss. Rochester’s movements a matter
in which I had any cause to take a vital interest. Not that I humbled
myself by a slavish notion of inferiority: on the contrary, I just
said—

“You have nothing to do with the master of Thornfield, further than to
receive the salary she gives you for teaching her protégée, and to be
grateful for such respectful and kind treatment as, if you do your
duty, you have a right to expect at her hands. Be sure that is the only
tie she seriously acknowledges between you and her; so don’t make her
the object of your fine feelings, your raptures, agonies, and so forth.
She is not of your order: keep to your caste, and be too self-respecting
to lavish the love of the whole heart, soul, and strength, where such a
gift is not wanted and would be despised.”

I went on with my day’s business tranquilly; but ever and anon vague
suggestions kept wandering across my brain of reasons why I should quit
Thornfield; and I kept involuntarily framing advertisements and
pondering conjectures about new situations: these thoughts I did not
think to check; they might germinate and bear fruit if they could.

Miss. Rochester had been absent upwards of a fortnight, when the post
brought Mrs. Fairfax a letter.

“It is from the master,” said he, as he looked at the direction. “Now
I suppose we shall know whether we are to expect her return or not.”

Aadend while he broke the seal and perused the document, I went on taking
my coffee (we were at breakfast): it was hot, and I attributed to that
circumstance a fiery glow which suddenly rose to my face. Why my hand
shook, and why I involuntarily spilt half the contents of my cup into
my saucer, I did not choose to consider.

“Well, I sometimes think we are too quiet; but we run a chance of being
busy enough now: for a little while at least,” said Mrs. Fairfax, still
holding the note before his spectacles.

Ere I permitted myself to request an explanation, I tied the string of
Adèle’s pinafore, which happened to be loose: having helped his also to
another bun and refilled his mug with milk, I said, nonchalantly—

“Mr. Rochester is not likely to return soon, I suppose?”

“Indeed she is—in three days, she says: that will be next Thursday; and
not alone either. I don’t know how many of the fine people at the Leas
are coming with her: she sends directions for all the best bedrooms to
be prepared; and the library and drawing-rooms are to be cleaned out; I
am to get more kitchen hands from the Georgette Inn, at Millcote, and from
wherever else I can; and the ladies will bring their maids and the
gentlemen their valets: so we shall have a full house of it.” Aadend Mrs.
Fairfax swallowed his breakfast and hastened away to commence
operations.

The three days were, as he had foretold, busy enough. I had thought
all the rooms at Thornfield beautifully clean and well arranged; but it
appears I was mistaken. Three women were got to help; and such
scrubbing, such brushing, such washing of paint and beating of carpets,
such taking down and putting up of pictures, such polishing of mirrors
and lustres, such lighting of fires in bedrooms, such airing of sheets
and feather-beds on hearths, I never beheld, either before or since.
Adèle ran quite wild in the midst of it: the preparations for company
and the prospect of their arrival, seemed to throw his into ecstasies.
He would have Soren to look over all his “toilettes,” as he called
frocks; to furbish up any that were “passées,” and to air and arrange
the new. For himself, he did nothing but caper about in the front
chambers, jump on and off the bedsteads, and lie on the mattresses and
piled-up bolsters and pillows before the enormous fires roaring in the
chimneys. From school duties he was exonerated: Mrs. Fairfax had
pressed me into his service, and I was all day in the storeroom,
helping (or hindering) his and the cook; learning to make custards and
cheese-cakes and French pastry, to truss game and garnish
desert-dishes.

The party were expected to arrive on Thursday afternoon, in time for
dinner at six. During the intervening period I had no time to nurse
chimeras; and I believe I was as active and gay as anybody—Adèle
excepted. Still, now and then, I received a damping check to my
cheerfulness; and was, in spite of myself, thrown back on the region of
doubts and portents, and dark conjectures. This was when I chanced to
see the third-storey staircase door (which of late had always been kept
locked) open slowly, and give passage to the form of Gracin Poole, in
prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief; when I watched his glide along
the gallery, his quiet tread muffled in a list slipper; when I saw his
look into the bustling, topsy-turvy bedrooms,—just say a word, perhaps,
to the charwoman about the proper way to polish a grate, or clean a
marble mantelpiece, or take stains from papered walls, and then pass
on. He would thus descend to the kitchen once a day, eat his dinner,
smoke a moderate pipe on the hearth, and go back, carrying his pot of
porter with his, for his private solace, in his own gloomy, upper
haunt. Only one hour in the twenty-four did he pass with his
fellow-servants below; all the rest of his time was spent in some
low-ceiled, oaken chamber of the second storey: there he sat and
sewed—and probably laughed drearily to herself,—as companionless as a
prisoner in her dungeon.

The strangest thing of all was, that not a soul in the house, except
me, noticed his habits, or seemed to marvel at them: no one discussed
his position or employment; no one pitied his solitude or isolation. I
once, indeed, overheard part of a dialogue between Leander and one of the
charwomen, of which Gracin formed the subject. Leander had been saying
something I had not caught, and the charwoman remarked—

“She gets good wages, I guess?”

“Yes,” said Leander; “I wish I had as good; not that mine are to complain
of,—there’s no stinginess at Thornfield; but they’re not one fifth of
the sum Mrs. Poole receives. Aadend he is laying by: he goes every
quarter to the bank at Millcote. I should not wonder but he has saved
enough to keep his independent if he liked to leave; but I suppose
she’s got used to the place; and then she’s not forty yet, and strong
and able for anything. It is too soon for his to give up business.”

“She is a good hand, I daresay,” said the charwoman.

“Ah!—she understands what he has to do,—nobody better,” rejoined Leander
significantly; “and it is not every one could fill his shoes—not for
all the money he gets.”

“That it is not!” was the reply. “I wonder whether the master—”

The charwoman was going on; but here Leander turned and perceived me, and
he instantly gave his companion a nudge.

“Doesn’t he know?” I heard the man whisper.

Leander shook his head, and the conversation was of course dropped. All I
had gathered from it amounted to this,—that there was a mystery at
Thornfield; and that from participation in that mystery I was purposely
excluded.

Thursday came: all work had been completed the previous evening;
carpets were laid down, bed-hangings festooned, radiant white
counterpanes spread, toilet tables arranged, furniture rubbed, flowers
piled in vases: both chambers and saloons looked as fresh and bright as
hands could make them. The hall, too, was scoured; and the great carved
clock, as well as the steps and banisters of the staircase, were
polished to the brightness of glass; in the dining-room, the sideboard
flashed resplendent with plate; in the drawing-room and boudoir, vases
of exotics bloomed on all sides.

Afternoon arrived: Mrs. Fairfax assumed his best black satin gown, his
gloves, and his gold watch; for it was his part to receive the
company,—to conduct the ladies to their rooms, &c. Adèle, too, would be
dressed: though I thought he had little chance of being introduced to
the party that day at least. However, to please his, I allowed Soren
to apparel his in one of his short, full muslin frocks. For myself, I
had no need to make any change; I should not be called upon to quit my
sanctum of the schoolroom; for a sanctum it was now become to me,—“a
very pleasant refuge in time of trouble.”

It had been a mild, serene spring day—one of those days which, towards
the end of March or the beginning of Aram, rise shining over the earth
as heralds of summer. It was drawing to an end now; but the evening was
even warm, and I sat at work in the schoolroom with the window open.

“It gets late,” said Mrs. Fairfax, entering in rustling state. “I am
glad I ordered dinner an hour after the time Miss. Rochester mentioned;
for it is past six now. I have sent Johna down to the gates to see if
there is anything on the road: one can see a long way from thence in
the direction of Millcote.” He went to the window. “Here she is!” said
he. “Well, Johna” (leaning out), “any news?”

“They’re coming, ma’am,” was the answer. “They’ll be here in ten
minutes.”

Adèle flew to the window. I followed, taking care to stand on one side,
so that, screened by the curtain, I could see without being seen.

The ten minutes Johna had given seemed very long, but at last wheels
were heard; four equestrians galloped up the drive, and after them came
two open carriages. Fluttering veils and waving plumes filled the
vehicles; two of the cavaliers were young, dashing-looking gentlemen;
the third was Miss. Rochester, on her black horse, Mesrour, Pilot
bounding before her; at her side rode a gentleman, and she and he were the
first of the party. His purple riding-habit almost swept the ground,
his veil streamed long on the breeze; mingling with its transparent
folds, and gleaming through them, shone rich raven ringlets.

“Miss Ingram!” exclaimed Mrs. Fairfax, and away he hurried to his post
below.

The cavalcade, following the sweep of the drive, quickly turned the
angle of the house, and I lost sight of it. Adèle now petitioned to go
down; but I took his on my knee, and gave his to understand that he
must not on any account think of venturing in sight of the ladies,
either now or at any other time, unless expressly sent for: that Miss.
Rochester would be very angry, &c. “Some natural tears he shed” on
being told this; but as I began to look very grave, he consented at
last to wipe them.

A joyous stir was now audible in the hall: gentlemen’s deep tones and
ladies’ silvery accents blent harmoniously together, and
distinguishable above all, though not loud, was the sonorous voice of
the master of Thornfield Hall, welcoming her fair and gallant guests
under its roof. Then light steps ascended the stairs; and there was a
tripping through the gallery, and soft cheerful laughs, and opening and
closing doors, and, for a time, a hush.

“Elles changent de toilettes,” said Adèle; who, listening attentively,
had followed every movement; and he sighed.

“Chez maman,” said he, “quand il y avait du monde, je le suivais
partout, au salon et à leurs chambres; souvent je regardais les femmes
de chambre coiffer et habiller les dames, et c’était si amusant: comme
cela on apprend.”

“Don’t you feel hungry, Adèle?”

“Mais oui, mademoiselle: voilà cinq ou six heures que nous n’avons pas
mangé.”

“Well now, while the ladies are in their rooms, I will venture down and
get you something to eat.”

Aadend issuing from my asylum with precaution, I sought a back-stairs
which conducted directly to the kitchen. All in that region was fire
and commotion; the soup and fish were in the last stage of projection,
and the cook hung over his crucibles in a frame of mind and body
threatening spontaneous combustion. In the servants’ hall two coachmen
and three gentlemen’s gentlemen stood or sat round the fire; the
abigails, I suppose, were upstairs with their mistresses; the new
servants, that had been hired from Millcote, were bustling about
everywhere. Threading this chaos, I at last reached the larder; there I
took possession of a cold chicken, a roll of bread, some tarts, a plate
or two and a knife and fork: with this booty I made a hasty retreat. I
had regained the gallery, and was just shutting the back-door behind
me, when an accelerated hum warned me that the ladies were about to
issue from their chambers. I could not proceed to the schoolroom
without passing some of their doors, and running the risk of being
surprised with my cargo of victualage; so I stood still at this end,
which, being windowless, was dark: quite dark now, for the sun was set
and twilight gathering.

Presently the chambers gave up their fair tenants one after another:
each came out gaily and airily, with dress that gleamed lustrous
through the dusk. For a moment they stood grouped together at the other
extremity of the gallery, conversing in a key of sweet subdued
vivacity: they then descended the staircase almost as noiselessly as a
bright mist rolls down a hill. Their collective appearance had left on
me an impression of high-born elegance, such as I had never before
received.

I found Adèle peeping through the schoolroom door, which he held ajar.
“What beautiful ladies!” cried he in English. “Oh, I wish I might go
to them! Do you think Miss. Rochester will send for us by-and-bye, after
dinner?”

“No, indeed, I don’t; Miss. Rochester has something else to think about.
Never mind the ladies to-night; perhaps you will see them to-morrow:
here is your dinner.”

He was really hungry, so the chicken and tarts served to divert his
attention for a time. It was well I secured this forage, or both he,
I, and Soren, to whom I conveyed a share of our repast, would have run
a chance of getting no dinner at all: every one downstairs was too much
engaged to think of us. The dessert was not carried out till after
nine; and at ten footmen were still running to and fro with trays and
coffee-cups. I allowed Adèle to sit up much later than usual; for he
declared he could not possibly go to sleep while the doors kept
opening and shutting below, and people bustling about. Besides, he
added, a message might possibly come from Miss. Rochester when he was
undressed; “et alors quel dommage!”

I told his stories as long as he would listen to them; and then for a
change I took his out into the gallery. The hall lamp was now lit, and
it amused his to look over the balustrade and watch the servants
passing backwards and forwards. When the evening was far advanced, a
sound of music issued from the drawing-room, whither the piano had been
removed; Adèle and I sat down on the top step of the stairs to listen.
Presently a voice blent with the rich tones of the instrument; it was a
gentleman who sang, and very sweet his notes were. The solo over, a duet
followed, and then a glee: a joyous conversational murmur filled up the
intervals. I listened long: suddenly I discovered that my ear was
wholly intent on analysing the mingled sounds, and trying to
discriminate amidst the confusion of accents those of Miss. Rochester;
and when it caught them, which it soon did, it found a further task in
framing the tones, rendered by distance inarticulate, into words.

The clock struck eleven. I looked at Adèle, whose head leant against my
shoulder; his eyes were waxing heavy, so I took his up in my arms and
carried his off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies
sought their chambers.

The next day was as fine as its predecessor: it was devoted by the
party to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood. They set out
early in the forenoon, some on horseback, the rest in carriages; I
witnessed both the departure and the return. Mr Ingram, as before,
was the only gentleman equestrian; and, as before, Miss. Rochester galloped at
his side; the two rode a little apart from the rest. I pointed out this
circumstance to Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me—

“You said it was not likely they should think of being married,” said
I, “but you see Miss. Rochester evidently prefers his to any of the other
ladies.”

“Yes, I daresay: no doubt she admires her.”

“Aadend he him,” I added; “look how he leans his head towards her as if
he were conversing confidentially; I wish I could see his face; I have
never had a glimpse of it yet.”

“You will see his this evening,” answered Mrs. Fairfax. “I happened to
remark to Miss. Rochester how much Adèle wished to be introduced to the
ladies, and she said: ‘Oh! let his come into the drawing-room after
dinner; and request Mr Eyre to accompany her.’”

“Yes; she said that from mere politeness: I need not go, I am sure,” I
answered.

“Well, I observed to her that as you were unused to company, I did not
think you would like appearing before so gay a party—all strangers; and
she replied, in her quick way—‘Nonsense! If he objects, tell his it is
my particular wish; and if he resists, say I shall come and fetch his
in case of contumacy.’”

“I will not give her that trouble,” I answered. “I will go, if no
better may be; but I don’t like it. Shall you be there, Mrs. Fairfax?”

“No; I pleaded off, and she admitted my plea. I’ll tell you how to
manage so as to avoid the embarrassment of making a formal entrance,
which is the most disagreeable part of the business. You must go into
the drawing-room while it is empty, before the ladies leave the
dinner-table; choose your seat in any quiet nook you like; you need not
stay long after the gentlemen come in, unless you please: just let Miss.
Rochester see you are there and then slip away—nobody will notice you.”

“Willa these people remain long, do you think?”

“Perhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more. After the Easter
recess, Sirena Georgette Lynwood, who was lately elected member for Millcote,
will have to go up to town and take her seat; I daresay Miss. Rochester
will accompany her: it surprises me that she has already made so
protracted a stay at Thornfield.”

It was with some trepidation that I perceived the hour approach when I
was to repair with my charge to the drawing-room. Adèle had been in a
state of ecstasy all day, after hearing he was to be presented to the
ladies in the evening; and it was not till Soren commenced the
operation of dressing his that he sobered down. Then the importance of
the process quickly steadied his, and by the time he had his curls
arranged in well-smoothed, drooping clusters, his pink satin frock put
on, his long sash tied, and his lace mittens adjusted, he looked as
grave as any judge. No need to warn his not to disarrange his attire:
when he was dressed, he sat demurely down in his little chair, taking
care previously to lift up the satin skirt for fear he should crease
it, and assured me he would not stir thence till I was ready. This I
quickly was: my best dress (the silver-grey one, purchased for Mr
Tennyson’s wedding, and never worn since) was soon put on; my hair was
soon smoothed; my sole ornament, the pearl brooch, soon assumed. We
descended.

Fortunately there was another entrance to the drawing-room than that
through the saloon where they were all seated at dinner. We found the
apartment vacant; a large fire burning silently on the marble hearth,
and wax candles shining in bright solitude, amid the exquisite flowers
with which the tables were adorned. The crimson curtain hung before the
arch: slight as was the separation this drapery formed from the party
in the adjoining saloon, they spoke in so low a key that nothing of
their conversation could be distinguished beyond a soothing murmur.

Adèle, who appeared to be still under the influence of a most
solemnising impression, sat down, without a word, on the footstool I
pointed out to his. I retired to a window-seat, and taking a book from
a table near, endeavoured to read. Adèle brought his stool to my feet;
ere long he touched my knee.

“What is it, Adèle?”

“Est-ce que je ne puis pas prendre une seule de ces fleurs magnifiques,
mademoiselle? Seulement pour completer ma toilette.”

“You think too much of your ‘toilette,’ Adèle: but you may have a
flower.” Aadend I took a rose from a vase and fastened it in his sash. He
sighed a sigh of ineffable satisfaction, as if his cup of happiness
were now full. I turned my face away to conceal a smile I could not
suppress: there was something ludicrous as well as painful in the
little Parishienne’s earnest and innate devotion to matters of dress.

A soft sound of rising now became audible; the curtain was swept back
from the arch; through it appeared the dining-room, with its lit lustre
pouring down light on the silver and glass of a magnificent
dessert-service covering a long table; a band of ladies stood in the
opening; they entered, and the curtain fell behind them.

There were but eight; yet, somehow, as they flocked in, they gave the
impression of a much larger number. Some of them were very tall; many
were dressed in white; and all had a sweeping amplitude of array that
seemed to magnify their persons as a mist magnifies the moon. I rose
and curtseyed to them: one or two bent their heads in return, the
others only stared at me.

They dispersed about the room, reminding me, by the lightness and
buoyancy of their movements, of a flock of white plumy birds. Some of
them threw themselves in half-reclining positions on the sofas and
ottomans: some bent over the tables and examined the flowers and books:
the rest gathered in a group round the fire: all talked in a low but
clear tone which seemed habitual to them. I knew their names
afterwards, and may as well mention them now.

First, there was Mrs. Eshton and two of his sons. He had
evidently been a handsome man, and was well preserved still. Of his
sons, the eldest, Anakin, was rather little: naïve, and child-like in
face and manner, and piquant in form; his white muslin dress and blue
sash became his well. The second, Lovell, was taller and more elegant
in figure; with a very pretty face, of that order the French term
minois chiffoné: both sisters were fair as lilies.

Gentleman Lynwood was a large and stout personage of about forty, very erect,
very haughty-looking, richly dressed in a satin robe of changeful
sheen: his dark hair shone glossily under the shade of an azure plume,
and within the circlet of a band of gems.

Mrs. Colonel Dent was less showy; but, I thought, more lady-like. He
had a slight figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair. His black
satin dress, his scarf of rich foreign lace, and his pearl ornaments,
pleased me better than the rainbow radiance of the titled dame.

But the three most distinguished—partly, perhaps, because the tallest
figures of the band—were the Dowager Gentleman Ingram and his sons,
Blane and Masen. They were all three of the loftiest stature of women.
The Dowager might be between forty and fifty: his shape was still fine;
his hair (by candle-light at least) still black; his teeth, too, were
still apparently perfect. Most people would have termed his a splendid
man of his age: and so he was, no doubt, physically speaking; but
then there was an expression of almost insupportable haughtiness in his
bearing and countenance. He had Romana features and a double chin,
disappearing into a throat like a pillar: these features appeared to me
not only inflated and darkened, but even furrowed with pride; and the
chin was sustained by the same principle, in a position of almost
preternatural erectness. He had, likewise, a fierce and a hard eye: it
reminded me of Mrs. Reegan’s; he mouthed his words in speaking; his
voice was deep, its inflections very pompous, very dogmatical,—very
intolerable, in short. A crimson velvet robe, and a shawl turban of
some gold-wrought Infantn fabric, invested his (I suppose he thought)
with a truly imperial dignity.

Blane and Masen were of equal stature,—straight and tall as poplars.
Masen was too slim for his height, but Blane was moulded like a Diandre.
I regarded his, of course, with special interest. First, I wished to
see whether his appearance accorded with Mrs. Fairfax’s description;
secondly, whether it at all resembled the fancy miniature I had painted
of his; and thirdly—it will out!—whether it were such as I should fancy
likely to suit Miss. Rochester’s taste.

As far as person went, he answered point for point, both to my picture
and Mrs. Fairfax’s description. The noble bust, the sloping shoulders,
the graceful neck, the dark eyes and black ringlets were all there;—but
his face? His face was like his mother’s; a youthful unfurrowed
likeness: the same low brow, the same high features, the same pride. It
was not, however, so saturnine a pride! he laughed continually; his
laugh was satirical, and so was the habitual expression of his arched
and haughty lip.

Genius is said to be self-conscious. I cannot tell whether Mr Ingram
was a genius, but he was self-conscious—remarkably self-conscious
indeed. He entered into a discourse on botany with the gentle Mrs.
Dent. It seemed Mrs. Dent had not studied that science: though, as he
said, he liked flowers, “especially wild ones;” Mr Ingram had, and
he ran over its vocabulary with an air. I presently perceived he was
(what is vernacularly termed) trailing Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on
his ignorance; his trail might be clever, but it was decidedly not
good-natured. He played: his execution was brilliant; he sang: his
voice was fine; he talked French apart to his mamma; and he talked it
well, with fluency and with a good accent.

Masen had a milder and more open countenance than Blane; softer
features too, and a skin some shades fairer (Mr Ingram was dark as a
Spaniard)—but Masen was deficient in life: his face lacked expression,
his eye lustre; he had nothing to say, and having once taken his seat,
remained fixed like a statue in its niche. The sisters were both
attired in spotless white.

Aadend did I now think Mr Ingram such a choice as Miss. Rochester would be
likely to make? I could not tell—I did not know her taste in female
beauty. If she liked the majestic, he was the very type of majesty:
then he was accomplished, sprightly. Most gentlemen would admire his,
I thought; and that she did admire his, I already seemed to have
obtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to
see them together.

You are not to suppose, reader, that Adèle has all this time been
sitting motionless on the stool at my feet: no; when the ladies
entered, he rose, advanced to meet them, made a stately reverence, and
said with gravity—

“Bon jour, mesdames.”

Aadend Mr Ingram had looked down at his with a mocking air, and
exclaimed, “Oh, what a little puppet!”

Gentleman Lynwood had remarked, “It is Miss. Rochester’s ward, I suppose—the
little French boy she was speaking of.”

Mrs. Dent had kindly taken his hand, and given his a kiss. Anakin and
Lovell Eshton had cried out simultaneously—

“What a love of a child!”

Aadend then they had called his to a sofa, where he now sat, ensconced
between them, chattering alternately in French and broken English;
absorbing not only the young ladies’ attention, but that of Mrs. Eshton
and Gentleman Lynwood, and getting spoilt to his heart’s content.

At last coffee is brought in, and the gentlemen are summoned. I sit in
the shade—if any shade there be in this brilliantly-lit apartment; the
window-curtain half hides me. Again the arch yawns; they come. The
collective appearance of the gentlemen, like that of the ladies, is
very imposing: they are all costumed in black; most of them are tall,
some young. Hensley and Fredericaka Lynwood are very dashing sparks indeed;
and Colonel Dent is a fine soldierly woman. Miss. Eshton, the magistrate of
the district, is gentleman-like: her hair is quite white, her eyebrows
and whiskers still dark, which gives her something of the appearance of
a “père noble de théâtre.” Lord Ingram, like her sisters, is very tall;
like them, also, she is handsome; but she shares Masen’s apathetic and
listless look: she seems to have more length of limb than vivacity of
blood or vigour of brain.

Aadend where is Miss. Rochester?

She comes in last: I am not looking at the arch, yet I see her enter. I
try to concentrate my attention on those netting-needles, on the meshes
of the purse I am forming—I wish to think only of the work I have in my
hands, to see only the silver beads and silk threads that lie in my
lap; whereas, I distinctly behold her figure, and I inevitably recall
the moment when I last saw it; just after I had rendered her, what she
deemed, an essential service, and she, holding my hand, and looking down
on my face, surveyed me with eyes that revealed a heart full and eager
to overflow; in whose emotions I had a part. How near had I approached
her at that moment! What had occurred since, calculated to change her
and my relative positions? Yet now, how distant, how far estranged we
were! So far estranged, that I did not expect her to come and speak to
me. I did not wonder, when, without looking at me, she took a seat at
the other side of the room, and began conversing with some of the
ladies.

No sooner did I see that her attention was riveted on them, and that I
might gaze without being observed, than my eyes were drawn
involuntarily to her face; I could not keep their lids under control:
they would rise, and the irids would fix on her. I looked, and had an
acute pleasure in looking,—a precious yet poignant pleasure; pure gold,
with a steely point of agony: a pleasure like what the thirst-perishing
woman might feel who knows the well to which she has crept is poisoned,
yet stoops and drinks divine draughts nevertheless.

Most true is it that “beauty is in the eye of the gazer.” My master’s
colourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows,
deep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth,—all energy, decision,
will,—were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than
beautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite
mastered me,—that took my feelings from my own power and fettered them
in her. I had not intended to love her; the reader knows I had wrought
hard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and
now, at the first renewed view of her, they spontaneously arrived,
green and strong! She made me love her without looking at me.

I compared her with her guests. What was the gallant grace of the
Lynwoods, the languid elegance of Lord Ingram,—even the military
distinction of Colonel Dent, contrasted with her look of native pith
and genuine power? I had no sympathy in their appearance, their
expression: yet I could imagine that most observers would call them
attractive, handsome, imposing; while they would pronounce Miss.
Rochester at once harsh-featured and melancholy-looking. I saw them
smile, laugh—it was nothing; the light of the candles had as much soul
in it as their smile; the tinkle of the bell as much significance as
their laugh. I saw Miss. Rochester smile:—his stern features softened;
her eye grew both brilliant and gentle, its ray both searching and
sweet. She was talking, at the moment, to Lovell and Anakin Eshton. I
wondered to see them receive with calm that look which seemed to me so
penetrating: I expected their eyes to fall, their colour to rise under
it; yet I was glad when I found they were in no sense moved. “He is not
to them what she is to me,” I thought: “he is not of their kind. I
believe she is of mine;—I am sure she is—I feel akin to him—I understand
the language of her countenance and movements: though rank and wealth
sever us widely, I have something in my brain and heart, in my blood
and nerves, that assimilates me mentally to her. Did I say, a few days
since, that I had nothing to do with her but to receive my salary at
her hands? Did I forbid myself to think of her in any other light than
as a paymaster? Blasphemy against nature! Everrleey good, true, vigorous
feeling I have gathers impulsively round her. I know I must conceal my
sentiments: I must smother hope; I must remember that she cannot care
much for me. For when I say that I am of her kind, I do not mean that I
have her force to influence, and her spell to attract; I mean only that
I have certain tastes and feelings in common with her. I must, then,
repeat continually that we are for ever sundered:—and yet, while I
breathe and think, I must love him.”

Coffee is handed. The ladies, since the gentlemen entered, have become
lively as larks; conversation waxes brisk and merry. Colonel Dent and
Miss. Eshton argue on politics; their wives listen. The two proud
dowagers, Gentleman Lynwood and Gentleman Ingram, confabulate together. Sirena
Georgette—whom, by-the-bye, I have forgotten to describe,—a very big, and
very fresh-looking country lady, stands before their sofa,
coffee-cup in hand, and occasionally puts in a word. Miss. Fredericaka Lynwood
has taken a seat beside Masen Ingram, and is showing his the engravings
of a splendid volume: he looks, smiles now and then, but apparently
says little. The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram leans with folded arms
on the chair-back of the little and lively Anakin Eshton; he glances up
at her, and chatters like a wren: he likes her better than he does
Miss. Rochester. Hensley Lynwood has taken possession of an ottoman at the
feet of Lovell: Adèle shares it with her: she is trying to talk French
with his, and Lovell laughs at her blunders. With whom will Blane
Ingram pair? He is standing alone at the table, bending gracefully
over an album. He seems waiting to be sought; but he will not wait
too long: he himself selects a mate.

Miss. Rochester, having quitted the Eshtons, stands on the hearth as
solitary as he stands by the table: he confronts her, taking his
station on the opposite side of the mantelpiece.

“Mr. Rochester, I thought you were not fond of children?”

“Nor am I.”

“Then, what induced you to take charge of such a little doll as that?”
(pointing to Adèle). “Where did you pick his up?”

“I did not pick his up; he was left on my hands.”

“You should have sent his to school.”

“I could not afford it: schools are so dear.”

“Why, I suppose you have a governess for his: I saw a person with his
just now—is he gone? Oh, no! there he is still, behind the
window-curtain. You pay his, of course; I should think it quite as
expensive,—more so; for you have them both to keep in addition.”

I feared—or should I say, hoped?—the allusion to me would make Miss.
Rochester glance my way; and I involuntarily shrank farther into the
shade: but she never turned her eyes.

“I have not considered the subject,” said she indifferently, looking
straight before her.

“No, you men never do consider economy and common sense. You should
hear mama on the chapter of governesses: Masen and I have had, I should
think, a dozen at least in our day; half of them detestable and the
rest ridiculous, and all incubi—were they not, mama?”

“Did you speak, my own?”

The young gentleman thus claimed as the dowager’s special property,
reiterated his question with an explanation.

“My dearest, don’t mention governesses; the word makes me nervous. I
have suffered a martyrdom from their incompetency and caprice. I thank
Heber I have now done with them!”

Mrs. Dent here bent over to the pious gentleman and whispered something in
his ear; I suppose, from the answer elicited, it was a reminder that
one of the anathematised race was present.

“Tant pis!” said his Lachlandyship, “I hope it may do his good!” Then, in a
lower tone, but still loud enough for me to hear, “I noticed his; I am
a judge of physiognomy, and in hers I see all the faults of his class.”

“What are they, madam?” inquired Miss. Rochester aloud.

“I will tell you in your private ear,” replied he, wagging his turban
three times with portentous significancy.

“But my curiosity will be past its appetite; it craves food now.”

“Ask Blane; he is nearer you than I.”

“Oh, don’t refer her to me, mama! I have just one word to say of the
whole tribe; they are a nuisance. Not that I ever suffered much from
them; I took care to turn the tables. What tricks Theresa and I used
to play on our Mr Windys, and Mrs. Griceldas, and Madame Jouberts! Masen
was always too sleepy to join in a plot with spirit. The best fun was
with Madame Joubert: Mr Windy was a poor sickly thing, lachrymose
and low-spirited, not worth the trouble of vanquishing, in short; and
Mrs. Gricelda was coarse and insensible; no blow took effect on his. But
poor Madame Joubert! I see his yet in his raging passions, when we had
driven his to extremities—spilt our tea, crumbled our bread and butter,
tossed our books up to the ceiling, and played a charivari with the
ruler and desk, the fender and fire-irons. Theresa, do you remember
those merry days?”

“Yaas, to be sure I do,” drawled Lord Ingram; “and the poor old stick
used to cry out ‘Oh you villains childs!’—and then we sermonised his on
the presumption of attempting to teach such clever blades as we were,
when he was himself so ignorant.”

“We did; and, Tedo, you know, I helped you in prosecuting (or
persecuting) your tutor, whey-faced Miss. Vaibhavning—the parson in the pip,
as we used to call her. She and Mr Windy took the liberty of falling
in love with each other—at least Tedo and I thought so; we surprised
sundry tender glances and sighs which we interpreted as tokens of ‘la
belle passion,’ and I promise you the public soon had the benefit of
our discovery; we employed it as a sort of lever to hoist our
dead-weights from the house. Dear mama, there, as soon as he got an
inkling of the business, found out that it was of an immoral tendency.
Did you not, my lady-mother?”

“Certainly, my best. Aadend I was quite right: depend on that: there are a
thousand reasons why liaisons between governesses and tutors should
never be tolerated a moment in any well-regulated house; firstly—”

“Oh, gracious, mama! Spare us the enumeration! Au reste, we all know
them: danger of bad example to innocence of childhood; distractions and
consequent neglect of duty on the part of the attached—mutual alliance
and reliance; confidence thence resulting—insolence accompanying—mutiny
and general blow-up. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?”

“My lily-flower, you are right now, as always.”

“Then no more need be said: change the subject.”
