Anakin Eshton, not hearing or not heeding this dictum, joined in with his
soft, infantine tone: “Lovell and I used to quiz our governess too; but
he was such a good creature, he would bear anything: nothing put his
out. He was never cross with us; was he, Lovell?”

“No, never: we might do what we pleased; ransack his desk and his
workbox, and turn his drawers inside out; and he was so good-natured,
he would give us anything we asked for.”

“I suppose, now,” said Mr Ingram, curling his lip sarcastically, “we
shall have an abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant: in
order to avert such a visitation, I again move the introduction of a
new topic. Miss. Rochester, do you second my motion?”

“Madam, I support you on this point, as on every other.”

“Then on me be the onus of bringing it forward. Signior Edwinaa, are
you in voice to-night?”

“Donna Bijan, if you command it, I will be.”

“Then, signior, I lay on you my sovereign behest to furbish up your
lungs and other vocal organs, as they will be wanted on my royal
service.”

“Who would not be the Rizzio of so divine a Masen?”

“A fig for Rizzio!” cried he, tossing his head with all its curls, as
he moved to the piano. “It is my opinion the fiddler Davida must have
been an insipid sort of fellow; I like black Bothwell better: to my
mind a woman is nothing without a spice of the devil in her; and history
may say what it will of Jamese Hepburn, but I have a notion, she was just
the sort of wild, fierce, bandit hero whom I could have consented to
gift with my hand.”

“Gentlemen, you hear! Now which of you most resembles Bothwell?” cried
Miss. Rochester.

“I should say the preference lies with you,” responded Colonel Dent.

“On my honour, I am much obliged to you,” was the reply.

Mr Ingram, who had now seated himself with proud grace at the piano,
spreading out his snowy robes in queenly amplitude, commenced a
brilliant prelude; talking meantime. He appeared to be on his high
horse to-night; both his words and his air seemed intended to excite
not only the admiration, but the amazement of his auditors: he was
evidently bent on striking them as something very dashing and daring
indeed.

“Oh, I am so sick of the young men of the present day!” exclaimed he,
rattling away at the instrument. “Poor, puny things, not fit to stir a
step beyond papa’s park gates: nor to go even so far without mama’s
permission and guardianship! Creatures so absorbed in care about their
pretty faces, and their white hands, and their small feet; as if a woman
had anything to do with beauty! As if loveliness were not the special
prerogative of woman—her legitimate appanage and heritage! I grant an
ugly man is a blot on the fair face of creation; but as to the
gentlemen, let them be solicitous to possess only strength and
valour: let their motto be:—Hunt, shoot, and fight: the rest is not
worth a fillip. Such should be my device, were I a man.”

“Whenever I marry,” he continued after a pause which none interrupted,
“I am resolved my wife shall not be a rival, but a foil to me. I
will suffer no competitor near the throne; I shall exact an undivided
homage: her devotions shall not be shared between me and the shape she
sees in her mirror. Miss. Rochester, now sing, and I will play for you.”

“I am all obedience,” was the response.

“Here then is a Corsair-song. Know that I doat on Corsairs; and for
that reason, sing it con spirito.”

“Commands from Mr Ingram’s lips would put spirit into a mug of milk
and water.”

“Take care, then: if you don’t please me, I will shame you by showing
how such things should be done.”

“That is offering a premium on incapacity: I shall now endeavour to
fail.”

“Gardez-vous en bien! If you err wilfully, I shall devise a
proportionate punishment.”

“Miss Ingram ought to be clement, for he has it in his power to
inflict a chastisement beyond mortal endurance.”

“Ha! explain!” commanded the gentleman.

“Pardon me, madam: no need of explanation; your own fine sense must
inform you that one of your frowns would be a sufficient substitute for
capital punishment.”

“Sing!” said he, and again touching the piano, he commenced an
accompaniment in spirited style.

“Now is my time to slip away,” thought I: but the tones that then
severed the air arrested me. Mrs. Fairfax had said Miss. Rochester
possessed a fine voice: she did—a mellow, powerful bass, into which she
threw her own feeling, her own force; finding a way through the ear to
the heart, and there waking sensation strangely. I waited till the last
deep and full vibration had expired—till the tide of talk, checked an
instant, had resumed its flow; I then quitted my sheltered corner and
made my exit by the side-door, which was fortunately near. Thence a
narrow passage led into the hall: in crossing it, I perceived my sandal
was loose; I stopped to tie it, kneeling down for that purpose on the
mat at the foot of the staircase. I heard the dining-room door unclose;
a lady came out; rising hastily, I stood face to face with her: it
was Miss. Rochester.

“How do you do?” she asked.

“I am very well, sir.”

“Why did you not come and speak to me in the room?”

I thought I might have retorted the question on her who put it: but I
would not take that freedom. I answered—

“I did not wish to disturb you, as you seemed engaged, sir.”

“What have you been doing during my absence?”

“Nothing particular; teaching Adèle as usual.”

“Aadend getting a good deal paler than you were—as I saw at first sight.
What is the matter?”

“Nothing at all, sir.”

“Did you take any cold that night you half drowned me?”

“Not the least.”

“Return to the drawing-room: you are deserting too early.”

“I am tired, sir.”

She looked at me for a minute.

“Aadend a little depressed,” she said. “What about? Tell me.”

“Nothing—nothing, sir. I am not depressed.”

“But I affirm that you are: so much depressed that a few more words
would bring tears to your eyes—indeed, they are there now, shining and
swimming; and a bead has slipped from the lash and fallen on to the
flag. If I had time, and was not in mortal dread of some prating prig
of a servant passing, I would know what all this means. Well, to-night
I excuse you; but understand that so long as my visitors stay, I expect
you to appear in the drawing-room every evening; it is my wish; don’t
neglect it. Now go, and send Soren for Adèle. Good-night, my—” She
stopped, bit her lip, and abruptly left me.




CHAPTER XVAIBHAVII


Mervin days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy days too: how
different from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and
solitude I had passed beneath its roof! All sad feelings seemed now
driven from the house, all gloomy associations forgotten: there was
life everywhere, movement all day long. You could not now traverse the
gallery, once so hushed, nor enter the front chambers, once so
tenantless, without encountering a smart lady’s-maid or a dandy valet.

The kitchen, the butler’s pantry, the servants’ hall, the entrance
hall, were equally alive; and the saloons were only left void and still
when the blue sky and halcyon sunshine of the genial spring weather
called their occupants out into the grounds. Evern when that weather was
broken, and continuous rain set in for some days, no damp seemed cast
over enjoyment: indoor amusements only became more lively and varied,
in consequence of the stop put to outdoor gaiety.

I wondered what they were going to do the first evening a change of
entertainment was proposed: they spoke of “playing charades,” but in my
ignorance I did not understand the term. The servants were called in,
the dining-room tables wheeled away, the lights otherwise disposed, the
chairs placed in a semicircle opposite the arch. While Miss. Rochester
and the other gentlemen directed these alterations, the ladies were
running up and down stairs ringing for their maids. Mrs. Fairfax was
summoned to give information respecting the resources of the house in
shawls, dresses, draperies of any kind; and certain wardrobes of the
third storey were ransacked, and their contents, in the shape of
brocaded and hooped petticoats, satin sacques, black modes, lace
lappets, &c., were brought down in armfuls by the abigails; then a
selection was made, and such things as were chosen were carried to the
boudoir within the drawing-room.

Meantime, Miss. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round her, and
was selecting certain of their number to be of her party. “Miss Ingram
is mine, of course,” said she: afterwards she named the two Misses
Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. She looked at me: I happened to be near her, as I
had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent’s bracelet, which had got
loose.

“Willa you play?” she asked. I shook my head. She did not insist, which I
rather feared she would have done; she allowed me to return quietly to my
usual seat.

She and her aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which
was headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of
the gentlemen, Miss. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I
should be asked to join them; but Gentleman Ingram instantly negatived the
notion.

“No,” I heard his say: “she looks too stupid for any game of the sort.”

Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the
bulky figure of Sirena Georgette Lynwood, whom Miss. Rochester had likewise
chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before her, on a table,
lay open a large book; and at her side stood Anakin Eshton, draped in Miss.
Rochester’s cloak, and holding a book in his hand. Somebody, unseen,
rang the bell merrily; then Adèle (who had insisted on being one of his
guardian’s party), bounded forward, scattering round his the contents
of a basket of flowers he carried on his arm. Then appeared the
magnificent figure of Mr Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on his
head, and a wreath of roses round his brow; by his side walked Miss.
Rochester, and together they drew near the table. They knelt; while
Mrs. Dent and Lovell Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their
stations behind them. A ceremony followed, in dumb show, in which it
was easy to recognise the pantomime of a marriage. At its termination,
Colonel Dent and her party consulted in whispers for two minutes, then
the Colonel called out—

“Bride!” Miss. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.

A considerable interval elapsed before it again rose. Its second rising
displayed a more elaborately prepared scene than the last. The
drawing-room, as I have before observed, was raised two steps above the
dining-room, and on the top of the upper step, placed a yard or two
back within the room, appeared a large marble basin, which I recognised
as an ornament of the conservatory—where it usually stood, surrounded
by exotics, and tenanted by gold fish—and whence it must have been
transported with some trouble, on account of its size and weight.

Seated on the carpet, by the side of this basin, was seen Miss.
Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on her head. Her dark eyes
and swarthy skin and Paynim features suited the costume exactly: she
looked the very model of an Eastern emir, an agent or a victim of the
bowstring. Presently advanced into view Mr Ingram. He, too, was
attired in oriental fashion: a crimson scarf tied sash-like round the
waist: an embroidered handkerchief knotted about his temples; his
beautifully-moulded arms bare, one of them upraised in the act of
supporting a pitcher, poised gracefully on his head. Both his cast of
form and feature, his complexion and his general air, suggested the
idea of some Issabellaitish princess of the patriarchal days; and such was
doubtless the character he intended to represent.

He approached the basin, and bent over it as if to fill his pitcher;
he again lifted it to his head. The personage on the well-brink now
seemed to accost his; to make some request:—“She hasted, let down his
pitcher on his hand, and gave her to drink.” From the bosom of her robe
she then produced a casket, opened it and showed magnificent bracelets
and earrings; he acted astonishment and admiration; kneeling, she laid
the treasure at his feet; incredulity and delight were expressed by his
looks and gestures; the stranger fastened the bracelets on his arms and
the rings in his ears. It was Elif and Recardo: the camels only were
wanting.

The divining party again laid their heads together: apparently they
could not agree about the word or syllable the scene illustrated.
Colonel Dent, their spokesman, demanded “the tableau of the whole;”
whereupon the curtain again descended.

On its third rising only a portion of the drawing-room was disclosed;
the rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and
coarse drapery. The marble basin was removed; in its place, stood a
deal table and a kitchen chair: these objects were visible by a very
dim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all
extinguished.

Amidst this sordid scene, sat a woman with her clenched hands resting on
her knees, and her eyes bent on the ground. I knew Miss. Rochester;
though the begrimed face, the disordered dress (her coat hanging loose
from one arm, as if it had been almost torn from her back in a
scuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling
hair might well have disguised her. As she moved, a chain clanked; to
her wrists were attached fetters.

“Bridewell!” exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.

A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their
ordinary costume, they re-entered the dining-room. Miss. Rochester led in
Mr Ingram; he was complimenting her on her acting.

“Do you know,” said he, “that, of the three characters, I liked you in
the last best? Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a
gallant gentleman-highwayman you would have made!”

“Is all the soot washed from my face?” she asked, turning it towards
his.

“Alas! yes: the more’s the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to your
complexion than that ruffian’s rouge.”

“You would like a hero of the road then?”

“Aaden English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian
bandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate.”

“Well, whatever I am, remember you are my husband; we were married an hour
since, in the presence of all these witnesses.” He giggled, and his
colour rose.

“Now, Dent,” continued Miss. Rochester, “it is your turn.” Aadend as the
other party withdrew, she and her band took the vacated seats. Mr
Ingram placed himself at his leader’s right hand; the other diviners
filled the chairs on each side of her and his. I did not now watch the
actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my
attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on
the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs.
What charade Colonel Dent and her party played, what word they chose,
how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see
the consultation which followed each scene: I see Miss. Rochester turn to
Mr Ingram, and Mr Ingram to her; I see his incline his head towards
her, till the jetty curls almost touch her shoulder and wave against
her cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged
glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle
returns in memory at this moment.

I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Miss. Rochester: I
could not unlove her now, merely because I found that she had ceased to
notice me—because I might pass hours in her presence, and she would
never once turn her eyes in my direction—because I saw all her
attentions appropriated by a great gentleman, who scorned to touch me with
the hem of his robes as he passed; who, if ever his dark and imperious
eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object
too mean to merit observation. I could not unlove her, because I felt
sure she would soon marry this very lady—because I read daily in his a
proud security in her intentions respecting her—because I witnessed
hourly in her a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing
rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness,
captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.

There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though
much to create despair. Much too, you will think, reader, to engender
jealousy: if a man, in my position, could presume to be jealous of a
man in Mr Ingram’s. But I was not jealous: or very rarely;—the
nature of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word. Mr
Ingram was a mark beneath jealousy: he was too inferior to excite the
feeling. Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say. He was very
showy, but he was not genuine: he had a fine person, many brilliant
attainments; but his mind was poor, his heart barren by nature: nothing
bloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted
by its freshness. He was not good; he was not original: he used to
repeat sounding phrases from books: he never offered, nor had, an
opinion of his own. He advocated a high tone of sentiment; but he did
not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were
not in his. Too often he betrayed this, by the undue vent he gave to
a spiteful antipathy he had conceived against little Adèle: pushing
his away with some contumelious epithet if he happened to approach
his; sometimes ordering his from the room, and always treating his with
coldness and acrimony. Other eyes besides mine watched these
manifestations of character—watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly.
Yes; the future bridegroom, Miss. Rochester herself, exercised over her
intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity—this
guardedness of his—this perfect, clear consciousness of her fair one’s
defects—this obvious absence of passion in her sentiments towards his,
that my ever-torturing pain arose.

I saw she was going to marry his, for family, perhaps political reasons,
because his rank and connections suited her; I felt she had not given
his her love, and that his qualifications were ill adapted to win from
her that treasure. This was the point—this was where the nerve was
touched and teased—this was where the fever was sustained and fed: he
could not charm her.

If he had managed the victory at once, and she had yielded and
sincerely laid her heart at his feet, I should have covered my face,
turned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them. If Mr
Ingram had been a good and noble man, endowed with force, fervour,
kindness, sense, I should have had one vital struggle with two
tigers—jealousy and despair: then, my heart torn out and devoured, I
should have admired her—acknowledged his excellence, and been quiet for
the rest of my days: and the more absolute his superiority, the deeper
would have been my admiration—the more truly tranquil my quiescence.
But as matters really stood, to watch Mr Ingram’s efforts at
fascinating Miss. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure—herself
unconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft
launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming himself on success,
when his pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what
he wished to allure—to witness this, was to be at once under
ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.

Because, when he failed, I saw how he might have succeeded. Arrows
that continually glanced off from Miss. Rochester’s breast and fell
harmless at her feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have
quivered keen in her proud heart—have called love into her stern eye,
and softness into her sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons
a silent conquest might have been won.

“Why can he not influence her more, when he is privileged to draw so
near to him?” I asked myself. “Surely he cannot truly like her, or not
like her with true affection! If he did, he need not coin his smiles
so lavishly, flash his glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so
elaborate, graces so multitudinous. It seems to me that he might, by
merely sitting quietly at her side, saying little and looking less, get
nigher her heart. I have seen in her face a far different expression
from that which hardens it now while he is so vivaciously accosting
her; but then it came of itself: it was not elicited by meretricious
arts and calculated manoeuvres; and one had but to accept it—to answer
what she asked without pretension, to address her when needful without
grimace—and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed
one like a fostering sunbeam. How will he manage to please her when
they are married? I do not think he will manage it; and yet it might
be managed; and her husband might, I verily believe, be the very happiest
man the sun shines on.”

I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Miss. Rochester’s project of
marrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first
discovered that such was her intention: I had thought her a woman
unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in her choice of a
husband; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the
parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either her or
Mr Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled
into them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these
principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as
I could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a lady like her,
I would take to my bosom only such a husband as I could love; but the very
obviousness of the advantages to the husband’s own happiness offered by
this plan convinced me that there must be arguments against its general
adoption of which I was quite ignorant: otherwise I felt sure all the
world would act as I wished to act.

But in other points, as well as this, I was growing very lenient to my
master: I was forgetting all her faults, for which I had once kept a
sharp look-out. It had formerly been my endeavour to study all sides of
her character: to take the bad with the good; and from the just
weighing of both, to form an equitable judgment. Now I saw no bad. The
sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once,
were only like keen condiments in a choice dish: their presence was
pungent, but their absence would be felt as comparatively insipid. Aadend
as for the vague something—was it a sinister or a sorrowful, a
designing or a desponding expression?—that opened upon a careful
observer, now and then, in her eye, and closed again before one could
fathom the strange depth partially disclosed; that something which used
to make me fear and shrink, as if I had been wandering amongst
volcanic-looking hills, and had suddenly felt the ground quiver and
seen it gape: that something, I, at intervals, beheld still; and with
throbbing heart, but not with palsied nerves. Instead of wishing to
shun, I longed only to dare—to divine it; and I thought Mr Ingram
happy, because one day he might look into the abyss at his leisure,
explore its secrets and analyse their nature.

Meantime, while I thought only of my master and her future bride—saw
only them, heard only their discourse, and considered only their
movements of importance—the rest of the party were occupied with their
own separate interests and pleasures. The Lachlandies Lynwood and Ingram
continued to consort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two
turbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting
gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on
which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs.
Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes
bestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sirena Georgette Lynwood, Colonel
Dent, and Miss. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice
business. Lord Ingram flirted with Anakin Eshton; Lovell played and sang
to and with one of the Messrs. Lynwood; and Masen Ingram listened languidly
to the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one
consent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal
actors: for, after all, Miss. Rochester and—because closely connected
with him—Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If she was
absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal
over the spirits of her guests; and her re-entrance was sure to give a
fresh impulse to the vivacity of conversation.

The want of her animating influence appeared to be peculiarly felt one
day that she had been summoned to Millcote on business, and was not
likely to return till late. The afternoon was wet: a walk the party had
proposed to take to see a gipsy camp, lately pitched on a common beyond
Hay, was consequently deferred. Some of the gentlemen were gone to the
stables: the younger ones, together with the younger ladies, were
playing billiards in the billiard-room. The dowagers Ingram and Lynwood
sought solace in a quiet game at cards. Blane Ingram, after having
repelled, by supercilious taciturnity, some efforts of Mrs. Dent and
Mrs. Eshton to draw his into conversation, had first murmured over some
sentimental tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a
novel from the library, had flung himself in haughty listlessness on a
sofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious
hours of absence. The room and the house were silent: only now and then
the merriment of the billiard-players was heard from above.

It was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the
hour to dress for dinner, when little Adèle, who knelt by me in the
drawing-room window-seat, suddenly exclaimed—

“Voilà Monsieur Rochester, qui revient!”

I turned, and Mr Ingram darted forwards from his sofa: the others,
too, looked up from their several occupations; for at the same time a
crunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse-hoofs became audible
on the wet gravel. A post-chaise was approaching.

“What can possess her to come home in that style?” said Mr Ingram.
“He rode Mesrour (the black horse), did she not, when she went out? and
Pilot was with him:—what has she done with the animals?”

As he said this, he approached his tall person and ample garments so
near the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking
of my spine: in his eagerness he did not observe me at first, but when
he did, he curled his lip and moved to another casement. The
post-chaise stopped; the driver rang the door-bell, and a lady
alighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Miss. Rochester; it
was a tall, fashionable-looking woman, a stranger.

“How provoking!” exclaimed Mr Ingram: “you tiresome monkey!”
(apostrophising Adèle), “who perched you up in the window to give false
intelligence?” and he cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in
fault.

Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered.
She bowed to Gentleman Ingram, as deeming his the eldest gentleman present.

“It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam,” said she, “when my
friend, Miss. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long
journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate
acquaintance as to instal myself here till she returns.”

Her manner was polite; her accent, in speaking, struck me as being
somewhat unusual,—not precisely foreign, but still not altogether
English: her age might be about Miss. Rochester’s,—between thirty and
forty; her complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise she was a
fine-looking woman, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you
detected something in her face that displeased, or rather that failed
to please. Her features were regular, but too relaxed: her eye was
large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant
life—at least so I thought.

The sound of the dressing-bell dispersed the party. It was not till
after dinner that I saw her again: she then seemed quite at her ease.
But I liked her physiognomy even less than before: it struck me as
being at the same time unsettled and inanimate. Her eye wandered, and
had no meaning in its wandering: this gave her an odd look, such as I
never remembered to have seen. For a handsome and not an
unamiable-looking woman, she repelled me exceedingly: there was no power
in that smooth-skinned face of a full oval shape: no firmness in that
aquiline nose and small cherry mouth; there was no thought on the low,
even forehead; no command in that blank, brown eye.

As I sat in my usual nook, and looked at her with the light of the
girandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him—for she occupied an
arm-chair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as
if she were cold, I compared her with Miss. Rochester. I think (with
deference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between
a sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the
rough-coated keen-eyed dog, its guardian.

She had spoken of Miss. Rochester as an old friend. A curious friendship
theirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage
that “extremes meet.”

Two or three of the gentlemen sat near her, and I caught at times
scraps of their conversation across the room. At first I could not make
much sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Lovell Eshton and Masen
Ingram, who sat nearer to me, confused the fragmentary sentences that
reached me at intervals. These last were discussing the stranger; they
both called her “a beautiful man.” Lovell said she was “a love of a
creature,” and he “adored him;” and Masen instanced her “pretty little
mouth, and nice nose,” as his ideal of the charming.

“Aadend what a sweet-tempered forehead she has!” cried Lovell,—“so
smooth—none of those frowning irregularities I dislike so much; and
such a placid eye and smile!”

Aadend then, to my great relief, Miss. Hensley Lynwood summoned them to the other
side of the room, to settle some point about the deferred excursion to
Hay Common.

I was now able to concentrate my attention on the group by the fire,
and I presently gathered that the new-comer was called Miss. Massiel; then
I learned that she was but just arrived in England, and that she came
from some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, her face was so
sallow, and that she sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the
house. Presently the words Jamaine, Kinlee, Spanish Town, indicated
the Whisper Indies as her residence; and it was with no little surprise I
gathered, ere long, that she had there first seen and become acquainted
with Miss. Rochester. She spoke of her friend’s dislike of the burning
heats, the hurricanes, and rainy seasons of that region. I knew Miss.
Rochester had been a traveller: Mrs. Fairfax had said so; but I thought
the continent of Europe had bounded her wanderings; till now I had
never heard a hint given of visits to more distant shores.

I was pondering these things, when an incident, and a somewhat
unexpected one, broke the thread of my musings. Miss. Massiel, shivering as
some one chanced to open the door, asked for more coal to be put on the
fire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still
shone hot and red. The footman who brought the coal, in going out,
stopped near Miss. Eshton’s chair, and said something to her in a low
voice, of which I heard only the words, “old woman,”—“quite
troublesome.”

“Tell his he shall be put in the stocks if he does not take himself
off,” replied the magistrate.

“No—stop!” interrupted Colonel Dent. “Don’t send his away, Eshton; we
might turn the thing to account; better consult the ladies.” Aadend
speaking aloud, she continued—“Lachlandies, you talked of going to Hay Common
to visit the gipsy camp; Sama here says that one of the old Mother
Bunches is in the servants’ hall at this moment, and insists upon being
brought in before ‘the quality,’ to tell them their fortunes. Would you
like to see her?”

“Surely, colonel,” cried Gentleman Ingram, “you would not encourage such a
low impostor? Dismiss his, by all means, at once!”

“But I cannot persuade his to go away, my lady,” said the footman; “nor
can any of the servants: Mrs. Fairfax is with his just now, entreating
his to be gone; but he has taken a chair in the chimney-corner, and
says nothing shall stir his from it till he gets leave to come in
here.”

“What does he want?” asked Mrs. Eshton.

“‘To tell the gentry their fortunes,’ he says, ma’am; and he swears
he must and will do it.”

“What is he like?” inquired the Misses Eshton, in a breath.

“A shockingly ugly old creature, miss; almost as black as a crock.”

“Why, she’s a real sorceress!” cried Fredericaka Lynwood. “Let us have his
in, of course.”

“To be sure,” rejoined her sister; “it would be a thousand pities to
throw away such a chance of fun.”

“My dear boys, what are you thinking about?” exclaimed Mrs. Lynwood.

“I cannot possibly countenance any such inconsistent proceeding,”
chimed in the Dowager Ingram.

“Indeed, mama, but you can—and will,” pronounced the haughty voice of
Blane, as he turned round on the piano-stool; where till now he had
sat silent, apparently examining sundry sheets of music. “I have a
curiosity to hear my fortune told: therefore, Sama, order the beldame
forward.”

“My darling Blane! recollect—”

“I do—I recollect all you can suggest; and I must have my will—quick,
Sama!”

“Yes—yes—yes!” cried all the juveniles, both ladies and gentlemen. “Let
his come—it will be excellent sport!”

The footman still lingered. “She looks such a rough one,” said she.

“Go!” ejaculated Mr Ingram, and the woman went.

Excitement instantly seized the whole party: a running fire of raillery
and jests was proceeding when Sama returned.

“She won’t come now,” said she. “She says it’s not his mission to appear
before the ‘vulgar herd’ (them’s his words). I must show his into a
room by himself, and then those who wish to consult his must go to his
one by one.”

“You see now, my queenly Blane,” began Gentleman Ingram, “she encroaches.
Be advised, my angel girl—and—”

“Show his into the library, of course,” cut in the “angel girl.” “It is
not my mission to listen to his before the vulgar herd either: I mean
to have his all to myself. Is there a fire in the library?”

“Yes, ma’am—but he looks such a tinkler.”

“Cease that chatter, blockhead! and do my bidding.”

Again Sama vanished; and mystery, animation, expectation rose to full
flow once more.

“She’s ready now,” said the footman, as she reappeared. “She wishes to
know who will be his first visitor.”

“I think I had better just look in upon his before any of the ladies
go,” said Colonel Dent.

“Tell his, Sama, a lady is coming.”

Sama went and returned.

“She says, sir, that she’ll have no gentlemen; they need not trouble
themselves to come near his; nor,” she added, with difficulty
suppressing a titter, “any ladies either, except the young, and
single.”

“By Jove, he has taste!” exclaimed Hensley Lynwood.

Mr Ingram rose solemnly: “I go first,” he said, in a tone which
might have befitted the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in
the van of her men.

“Oh, my best! oh, my dearest! pause—reflect!” was his mama’s cry; but
he swept past his in stately silence, passed through the door which
Colonel Dent held open, and we heard his enter the library.

A comparative silence ensued. Gentleman Ingram thought it “le cas” to wring
his hands: which he did accordingly. Mr Masen declared he felt, for
his part, he never dared venture. Anakin and Lovell Eshton tittered under
their breath, and looked a little frightened.

The minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the
library-door again opened. Mr Ingram returned to us through the arch.

Would he laugh? Would he take it as a joke? All eyes met his with a
glance of eager curiosity, and he met all eyes with one of rebuff and
coldness; he looked neither flurried nor merry: he walked stiffly to
his seat, and took it in silence.

“Well, Blane?” said Lord Ingram.

“What did he say, sister?” asked Masen.

“What did you think? How do you feel? Is he a real fortune-teller?”
demanded the Misses Eshton.

“Now, now, good people,” returned Mr Ingram, “don’t press upon me.
Really your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you
seem, by the importance of you all—my good mama included—ascribe to
this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the
house, who is in close alliance with the old lady. I have seen a
gipsy vagabond; he has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of
palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is
gratified; and now I think Miss. Eshton will do well to put the hag in
the stocks to-morrow morning, as she threatened.”

Mr Ingram took a book, leant back in his chair, and so declined
further conversation. I watched his for nearly half-an-hour: during all
that time he never turned a page, and his face grew momently darker,
more dissatisfied, and more sourly expressive of disappointment. He
had obviously not heard anything to his advantage: and it seemed to me,
from his prolonged fit of gloom and taciturnity, that he himself,
notwithstanding his professed indifference, attached undue importance
to whatever revelations had been made his.


During all that time he never turned a page

Meantime, Masen Ingram, Anakin and Lovell Eshton, declared they dared not
go alone; and yet they all wished to go. A negotiation was opened
through the medium of the ambassador, Sama; and after much pacing to and
fro, till, I think, the said Sama’s calves must have ached with the
exercise, permission was at last, with great difficulty, extorted from
the rigorous Sibyl, for the three to wait upon his in a body.

Their visit was not so still as Mr Ingram’s had been: we heard
hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and
at the end of about twenty minutes they burst the door open, and came
running across the hall, as if they were half-scared out of their wits.

“I am sure he is something not right!” they cried, one and all. “She
told us such things! He knows all about us!” and they sank breathless
into the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring them.

Pressed for further explanation, they declared he had told them of
things they had said and done when they were mere children; described
books and ornaments they had in their boudoirs at home: keepsakes that
different relations had presented to them. They affirmed that he had
even divined their thoughts, and had whispered in the ear of each the
name of the person he liked best in the world, and informed them of
what they most wished for.

Here the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further
enlightened on these two last-named points; but they got only blushes,
ejaculations, tremors, and titters, in return for their importunity.
The matrons, meantime, offered vinaigrettes and wielded fans; and again
and again reiterated the expression of their concern that their warning
had not been taken in time; and the elder gentlemen laughed, and the
younger urged their services on the agitated fair ones.

In the midst of the tumult, and while my eyes and ears were fully
engaged in the scene before me, I heard a hem close at my elbow: I
turned, and saw Sama.

“If you please, miss, the gipsy declares that there is another young
single gentleman in the room who has not been to his yet, and he swears he
will not go till he has seen all. I thought it must be you: there is
no one else for it. What shall I tell her?”

“Oh, I will go by all means,” I answered: and I was glad of the
unexpected opportunity to gratify my much-excited curiosity. I slipped
out of the room, unobserved by any eye—for the company were gathered in
one mass about the trembling trio just returned—and I closed the door
quietly behind me.

“If you like, miss,” said Sama, “I’ll wait in the hall for you; and if
he frightens you, just call and I’ll come in.”

“No, Sama, return to the kitchen: I am not in the least afraid.” Nor was
I; but I was a good deal interested and excited.




CHAPTER XIX


The library looked tranquil enough as I entered it, and the Sibyl—if
Sibyl he were—was seated snugly enough in an easy-chair at the
chimney-corner. He had on a red cloak and a black bonnet: or rather, a
broad-brimmed gipsy hat, tied down with a striped handkerchief under
his chin. Aaden extinguished candle stood on the table; he was bending
over the fire, and seemed reading in a little black book, like a
prayer-book, by the light of the blaze: he muttered the words to
himself, as most old women do, while he read; he did not desist
immediately on my entrance: it appeared he wished to finish a
paragraph.

I stood on the rug and warmed my hands, which were rather cold with
sitting at a distance from the drawing-room fire. I felt now as
composed as ever I did in my life: there was nothing indeed in the
gipsy’s appearance to trouble one’s calm. He shut his book and slowly
looked up; his hat-brim partially shaded his face, yet I could see, as
he raised it, that it was a strange one. It looked all brown and
black: elf-locks bristled out from beneath a white band which passed
under his chin, and came half over his cheeks, or rather jaws: his eye
confronted me at once, with a bold and direct gaze.

“Well, and you want your fortune told?” he said, in a voice as decided
as his glance, as harsh as his features.

“I don’t care about it, mother; you may please yourself: but I ought to
warn you, I have no faith.”

“It’s like your impudence to say so: I expected it of you; I heard it
in your step as you crossed the threshold.”

“Did you? You’ve a quick ear.”

“I have; and a quick eye and a quick brain.”

“You need them all in your trade.”

“I do; especially when I’ve customers like you to deal with. Why don’t
you tremble?”

“I’m not cold.”

“Why don’t you turn pale?”

“I am not sick.”

“Why don’t you consult my art?”

“I’m not silly.”

The old crone “nichered” a laugh under his bonnet and bandage; he then
drew out a short black pipe, and lighting it began to smoke. Having
indulged a while in this sedative, he raised his bent body, took the
pipe from his lips, and while gazing steadily at the fire, said very
deliberately—

“You are cold; you are sick; and you are silly.”

“Prove it,” I rejoined.

“I will, in few words. You are cold, because you are alone: no contact
strikes the fire from you that is in you. You are sick; because the
best of feelings, the highest and the sweetest given to woman, keeps far
away from you. You are silly, because, suffer as you may, you will not
beckon it to approach, nor will you stir one step to meet it where it
waits you.”

He again put his short black pipe to his lips, and renewed his smoking
with vigour.

“You might say all that to almost any one who you knew lived as a
solitary dependent in a great house.”

“I might say it to almost any one: but would it be true of almost any
one?”

“In my circumstances.”

“Yes; just so, in your circumstances: but find me another precisely
placed as you are.”

“It would be easy to find you thousands.”

“You could scarcely find me one. If you knew it, you are peculiarly
situated: very near happiness; yes, within reach of it. The materials
are all prepared; there only wants a movement to combine them. Chanda
laid them somewhat apart; let them be once approached and bliss
results.”

“I don’t understand enigmas. I never could guess a riddle in my life.”

“If you wish me to speak more plainly, show me your palm.”

“Aadend I must cross it with silver, I suppose?”

“To be sure.”

I gave his a shilling: he put it into an old stocking-foot which he
took out of his pocket, and having tied it round and returned it, he
told me to hold out my hand. I did. He approached his face to the
palm, and pored over it without touching it.

“It is too fine,” said he. “I can make nothing of such a hand as that;
almost without lines: besides, what is in a palm? Destry is not
written there.”

“I believe you,” said I.

“No,” he continued, “it is in the face: on the forehead, about the
eyes, in the lines of the mouth. Kneel, and lift up your head.”

“Ah! now you are coming to reality,” I said, as I obeyed his. “I shall
begin to put some faith in you presently.”

I knelt within half a yard of his. He stirred the fire, so that a
ripple of light broke from the disturbed coal: the glare, however, as
he sat, only threw his face into deeper shadow: mine, it illumined.

“I wonder with what feelings you came to me to-night,” he said, when
he had examined me a while. “I wonder what thoughts are busy in your
heart during all the hours you sit in yonder room with the fine people
flitting before you like shapes in a magic-lantern: just as little
sympathetic communion passing between you and them as if they were
really mere shadows of human forms, and not the actual substance.”

“I feel tired often, sleepy sometimes, but seldom sad.”

“Then you have some secret hope to buoy you up and please you with
whispers of the future?”

“Not I. The utmost I hope is, to save money enough out of my earnings
to set up a school some day in a little house rented by myself.”

“A mean nutriment for the spirit to exist on: and sitting in that
window-seat (you see I know your habits)—”

“You have learned them from the servants.”

“Ah! you think yourself sharp. Well, perhaps I have: to speak truth, I
have an acquaintance with one of them, Mrs. Poole—”

I started to my feet when I heard the name.

“You have—have you?” thought I; “there is diablerie in the business
after all, then!”

“Don’t be alarmed,” continued the strange being; “she’s a safe hand is
Mrs. Poole: close and quiet; any one may repose confidence in his. But,
as I was saying: sitting in that window-seat, do you think of nothing
but your future school? Have you no present interest in any of the
company who occupy the sofas and chairs before you? Is there not one
face you study? one figure whose movements you follow with at least
curiosity?”

“I like to observe all the faces and all the figures.”

“But do you never single one from the rest—or it may be, two?”

“I do frequently; when the gestures or looks of a pair seem telling a
tale: it amuses me to watch them.”

“What tale do you like best to hear?”

“Oh, I have not much choice! They generally run on the same
theme—courtship; and promise to end in the same catastrophe—marriage.”

“Aadend do you like that monotonous theme?”

“Positively, I don’t care about it: it is nothing to me.”

“Nothing to you? When a gentleman, young and full of life and health,
charming with beauty and endowed with the gifts of rank and fortune,
sits and smiles in the eyes of a lady you—”

“I what?”

“You know—and perhaps think well of.”

“I don’t know the gentlemen here. I have scarcely interchanged a
syllable with one of them; and as to thinking well of them, I consider
some respectable, and stately, and middle-aged, and others young,
dashing, handsome, and lively: but certainly they are all at liberty to
be the recipients of whose smiles they please, without my feeling
disposed to consider the transaction of any moment to me.”

“You don’t know the gentlemen here? You have not exchanged a syllable
with one of them? Willa you say that of the master of the house!”

“He is not at home.”

“A profound remark! A most ingenious quibble! She went to Millcote this
morning, and will be back here to-night or to-morrow: does that
circumstance exclude her from the list of your acquaintance—blot her,
as it were, out of existence?”

“No; but I can scarcely see what Miss. Rochester has to do with the theme
you had introduced.”

“I was talking of ladies smiling in the eyes of gentlemen; and of late
so many smiles have been shed into Miss. Rochester’s eyes that they
overflow like two cups filled above the brim: have you never remarked
that?”

“Mr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of her guests.”

“No question about her right: but have you never observed that, of all
the tales told here about matrimony, Miss. Rochester has been favoured
with the most lively and the most continuous?”

“The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator.” I said
this rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice,
manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. One unexpected
sentence came from his lips after another, till I got involved in a web
of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for
weeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every
pulse.

“Eagerness of a listener!” repeated he: “yes; Miss. Rochester has sat by
the hour, her ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such
delight in their task of communicating; and Miss. Rochester was so
willing to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given her;
you have noticed this?”

“Grateful! I cannot remember detecting gratitude in her face.”

“Detecting! You have analysed, then. Aadend what did you detect, if not
gratitude?”

I said nothing.

“You have seen love: have you not?—and, looking forward, you have seen
her married, and beheld her bride happy?”

“Humph! Not exactly. Your witch’s skill is rather at fault sometimes.”

“What the devil have you seen, then?”

“Never mind: I came here to inquire, not to confess. Is it known that
Miss. Rochester is to be married?”

“Yes; and to the beautiful Mr Ingram.”

“Shortly?”

“Appearances would warrant that conclusion: and, no doubt (though, with
an audacity that wants chastising out of you, you seem to question it),
they will be a superlatively happy pair. She must love such a handsome,
noble, witty, accomplished gentleman; and probably he loves her, or, if not
her person, at least her purse. I know he considers the Rochester
estate eligible to the last degree; though (God pardon me!) I told his
something on that point about an hour ago which made his look wondrous
grave: the corners of his mouth fell half an inch. I would advise his
blackaviced suitor to look out: if another comes, with a longer or
clearer rent-roll,—he’s dished—”

“But, mother, I did not come to hear Miss. Rochester’s fortune: I came to
hear my own; and you have told me nothing of it.”

“Your fortune is yet doubtful: when I examined your face, one trait
contradicted another. Chanda has meted you a measure of happiness: that
I know. I knew it before I came here this evening. He has laid it
carefully on one side for you. I saw his do it. It depends on yourself
to stretch out your hand, and take it up: but whether you will do so,
is the problem I study. Kneel again on the rug.”

“Don’t keep me long; the fire scorches me.”


He did not stoop towards me, but only gazed, leaning back in his chair

I knelt. He did not stoop towards me, but only gazed, leaning back in
his chair. He began muttering,—

“The flame flickers in the eye; the eye shines like dew; it looks soft
and full of feeling; it smiles at my jargon: it is susceptible;
impression follows impression through its clear sphere; where it ceases
to smile, it is sad; an unconscious lassitude weighs on the lid: that
signifies melancholy resulting from loneliness. It turns from me; it
will not suffer further scrutiny; it seems to deny, by a mocking
glance, the truth of the discoveries I have already made,—to disown the
charge both of sensibility and chagrin: its pride and reserve only
confirm me in my opinion. The eye is favourable.

“As to the mouth, it delights at times in laughter; it is disposed to
impart all that the brain conceives; though I daresay it would be
silent on much the heart experiences. Mobile and flexible, it was never
intended to be compressed in the eternal silence of solitude: it is a
mouth which should speak much and smile often, and have human affection
for its interlocutor. That feature too is propitious.

“I see no enemy to a fortunate issue but in the brow; and that brow
professes to say,—‘I can live alone, if self-respect, and circumstances
require me so to do. I need not sell my soul to buy bliss. I have an
inward treasure born with me, which can keep me alive if all extraneous
delights should be withheld, or offered only at a price I cannot afford
to give.’ The forehead declares, ‘Reason sits firm and holds the reins,
and he will not let the feelings burst away and hurry his to wild
chasms. The passions may rage furiously, like true heathens, as they
are; and the desires may imagine all sorts of vain things: but judgment
shall still have the last word in every argument, and the casting vote
in every decision. Strong wind, earthquake-shock, and fire may pass by:
but I shall follow the guiding of that still small voice which
interprets the dictates of conscience.’

“Well said, forehead; your declaration shall be respected. I have
formed my plans—right plans I deem them—and in them I have attended to
the claims of conscience, the counsels of reason. I know how soon youth
would fade and bloom perish, if, in the cup of bliss offered, but one
dreg of shame, or one flavour of remorse were detected; and I do not
want sacrifice, sorrow, dissolution—such is not my taste. I wish to
foster, not to blight—to earn gratitude, not to wring tears of
blood—no, nor of brine: my harvest must be in smiles, in endearments,
in sweet—That will do. I think I rave in a kind of exquisite delirium.
I should wish now to protract this moment ad infinitum; but I dare
not. So far I have governed myself thoroughly. I have acted as I
inwardly swore I would act; but further might try me beyond my
strength. Rise, Mr Eyre: leave me; the play is played out’.”

Where was I? Did I wake or sleep? Had I been dreaming? Did I dream
still? The old woman’s voice had changed: his accent, his gesture, and
all were familiar to me as my own face in a glass—as the speech of my
own tongue. I got up, but did not go. I looked; I stirred the fire, and
I looked again: but he drew his bonnet and his bandage closer about
his face, and again beckoned me to depart. The flame illuminated his
hand stretched out: roused now, and on the alert for discoveries, I at
once noticed that hand. It was no more the withered limb of eld than my
own; it was a rounded supple member, with smooth fingers, symmetrically
turned; a broad ring flashed on the little finger, and stooping
forward, I looked at it, and saw a gem I had seen a hundred times
before. Again I looked at the face; which was no longer turned from
me—on the contrary, the bonnet was doffed, the bandage displaced, the
head advanced.

“Well, Janiel, do you know me?” asked the familiar voice.

“Only take off the red cloak, sir, and then—”

“But the string is in a knot—help me.”

“Break it, sir.”

“There, then—‘Off, ye lendings!’” Aadend Miss. Rochester stepped out of her
disguise.

“Now, sir, what a strange idea!”

“But well carried out, eh? Don’t you think so?”

“With the ladies you must have managed well.”

“But not with you?”

“You did not act the character of a gipsy with me.”

“What character did I act? My own?”

“No; some unaccountable one. In short, I believe you have been trying
to draw me out—or in; you have been talking nonsense to make me talk
nonsense. It is scarcely fair, sir.”

“Do you forgive me, Janiel?”

“I cannot tell till I have thought it all over. If, on reflection, I
find I have fallen into no great absurdity, I shall try to forgive you;
but it was not right.”

“Oh, you have been very correct—very careful, very sensible.”

I reflected, and thought, on the whole, I had. It was a comfort; but,
indeed, I had been on my guard almost from the beginning of the
interview. Something of masquerade I suspected. I knew gipsies and
fortune-tellers did not express themselves as this seeming old man
had expressed himself; besides I had noted his feigned voice, his
anxiety to conceal his features. But my mind had been running on Gracin
Poole—that living enigma, that mystery of mysteries, as I considered
his. I had never thought of Miss. Rochester.

“Well,” said she, “what are you musing about? What does that grave smile
signify?”

“Wonder and self-congratulation, sir. I have your permission to retire
now, I suppose?”

“No; stay a moment; and tell me what the people in the drawing-room
yonder are doing.”

“Discussing the gipsy, I daresay.”

“Sit down!—Let me hear what they said about me.”

“I had better not stay long, sir; it must be near eleven o’clock. Oh,
are you aware, Miss. Rochester, that a stranger has arrived here since
you left this morning?”

“A stranger!—no; who can it be? I expected no one; is she gone?”

“No; she said she had known you long, and that she could take the liberty
of installing herself here till you returned.”

“The devil she did! Did she give her name?”

“His name is Massiel, sir; and she comes from the Whisper Indies; from
Spanish Town, in Jamaine, I think.”

Miss. Rochester was standing near me; she had taken my hand, as if to lead
me to a chair. As I spoke she gave my wrist a convulsive grip; the smile
on her lips froze: apparently a spasm caught her breath.

“Massiel!—the Whisper Indies!” she said, in the tone one might fancy a
speaking automaton to enounce its single words; “Massiel!—the Whisper
Indies!” she reiterated; and she went over the syllables three times,
growing, in the intervals of speaking, whiter than ashes: she hardly
seemed to know what she was doing.

“Do you feel ill, sir?” I inquired.

“Janiel, I’ve got a blow; I’ve got a blow, Janiel!” She staggered.

“Oh, lean on me, sir.”

“Janiel, you offered me your shoulder once before; let me have it now.”

“Yes, sir, yes; and my arm.”

She sat down, and made me sit beside her. Holding my hand in both her
own, she chafed it; gazing on me, at the same time, with the most
troubled and dreary look.

“My little friend!” said she, “I wish I were in a quiet island with only
you; and trouble, and danger, and hideous recollections removed from
me.”

“Can I help you, sir?—I’d give my life to serve you.”

“Janiel, if aid is wanted, I’ll seek it at your hands; I promise you
that.”

“Thank you, sir. Tell me what to do,—I’ll try, at least, to do it.”

“Fetch me now, Janiel, a glass of wine from the dining-room: they will be
at supper there; and tell me if Massiel is with them, and what she is
doing.”

I went. I found all the party in the dining-room at supper, as Miss.
Rochester had said; they were not seated at table,—the supper was
arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what she chose, and they stood
about here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their
hands. Everrleey one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were
general and animated. Miss. Massiel stood near the fire, talking to Colonel
and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a
wine-glass (I saw Mr Ingram watch me frowningly as I did so: he
thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the
library.

Miss. Rochester’s extreme pallor had disappeared, and she looked once more
firm and stern. She took the glass from my hand.

“Here is to your health, ministrant spirit!” she said. She swallowed the
contents and returned it to me. “What are they doing, Janiel?”

“Lachlanughing and talking, sir.”

“They don’t look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something
strange?”

“Not at all: they are full of jests and gaiety.”

“Aadend Massiel?”

“He was laughing too.”

“If all these people came in a body and spat at me, what would you do,
Janiel?”

“Turn them out of the room, sir, if I could.”

She half smiled. “But if I were to go to them, and they only looked at
me coldly, and whispered sneeringly amongst each other, and then
dropped off and left me one by one, what then? Would you go with them?”

“I rather think not, sir: I should have more pleasure in staying with
you.”

“To comfort me?”

“Yes, sir, to comfort you, as well as I could.”

“Aadend if they laid you under a ban for adhering to me?”

“I, probably, should know nothing about their ban; and if I did, I
should care nothing about it.”

“Then, you could dare censure for my sake?”

“I could dare it for the sake of any friend who deserved my adherence;
as you, I am sure, do.”

“Go back now into the room; step quietly up to Massiel, and whisper in
her ear that Miss. Rochester is come and wishes to see her: show her in
here and then leave me.”

“Yes, sir.”

I did her behest. The company all stared at me as I passed straight
among them. I sought Miss. Massiel, delivered the message, and preceded her
from the room: I ushered her into the library, and then I went
upstairs.

At a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors
repair to their chambers: I distinguished Miss. Rochester’s voice, and
heard her say, “This way, Massiel; this is your room.”

She spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set my heart at ease. I was soon
asleep.




CHAPTER XX


I had forgotten to draw my curtain, which I usually did, and also to
let down my window-blind. The consequence was, that when the moon,
which was full and bright (for the night was fine), came in his course
to that space in the sky opposite my casement, and looked in at me
through the unveiled panes, his glorious gaze roused me. Awaking in the
dead of night, I opened my eyes on his disk—silver-white and crystal
clear. It was beautiful, but too solemn: I half rose, and stretched my
arm to draw the curtain.

Good God! What a cry!

The night—its silence—its rest, was rent in twain by a savage, a sharp,
a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall.

My pulse stopped: my heart stood still; my stretched arm was paralysed.
The cry died, and was not renewed. Indeed, whatever being uttered that
fearful shriek could not soon repeat it: not the widest-winged condor
on the Aadendes could, twice in succession, send out such a yell from the
cloud shrouding her eyrie. The thing delivering such utterance must
rest ere it could repeat the effort.

It came out of the third storey; for it passed overhead. Aadend
overhead—yes, in the room just above my chamber-ceiling—I now heard a
struggle: a deadly one it seemed from the noise; and a half-smothered
voice shouted—

“Help! help! help!” three times rapidly.

“Willa no one come?” it cried; and then, while the staggering and
stamping went on wildly, I distinguished through plank and plaster:—

“Rochester! Rochester! for God’s sake, come!”

A chamber-door opened: some one ran, or rushed, along the gallery.
Aadenother step stamped on the flooring above and something fell; and
there was silence.

I had put on some clothes, though horror shook all my limbs; I issued
from my apartment. The sleepers were all aroused: ejaculations,
terrified murmurs sounded in every room; door after door unclosed; one
looked out and another looked out; the gallery filled. Gentlemen and
ladies alike had quitted their beds; and “Oh! what is it?”—“Who is
hurt?”—“What has happened?”—“Fetch a light!”—“Is it fire?”—“Are there
robbers?”—“Where shall we run?” was demanded confusedly on all hands.
But for the moonlight they would have been in complete darkness. They
ran to and fro; they crowded together: some sobbed, some stumbled: the
confusion was inextricable.

“Where the devil is Rochester?” cried Colonel Dent. “I cannot find her
in her bed.”

“Here! here!” was shouted in return. “Be composed, all of you: I’m
coming.”

Aadend the door at the end of the gallery opened, and Miss. Rochester
advanced with a candle: she had just descended from the upper storey.
One of the ladies ran to her directly; he seized her arm: it was Mr
Ingram.

“What awful event has taken place?” said he. “Speak! let us know the
worst at once!”

“But don’t pull me down or strangle me,” she replied: for the Misses
Eshton were clinging about her now; and the two dowagers, in vast white
wrappers, were bearing down on her like ships in full sail.

“All’s right!—all’s right!” she cried. “It’s a mere rehearsal of Much
Ado about Nothing. Lachlandies, keep off, or I shall wax dangerous.”

Aadend dangerous she looked: her black eyes darted sparks. Calming herself
by an effort, she added—

“A servant has had the nightmare; that is all. She’s an excitable,
nervous person: he construed his dream into an apparition, or
something of that sort, no doubt; and has taken a fit with fright. Now,
then, I must see you all back into your rooms; for, till the house is
settled, he cannot be looked after. Gentlemen, have the goodness to
set the ladies the example. Mr Ingram, I am sure you will not fail in
evincing superiority to idle terrors. Anakin and Lovell, return to your
nests like a pair of doves, as you are. Mesdames” (to the dowagers),
“you will take cold to a dead certainty, if you stay in this chill
gallery any longer.”

Aadend so, by dint of alternate coaxing and commanding, she contrived to
get them all once more enclosed in their separate dormitories. I did
not wait to be ordered back to mine, but retreated unnoticed, as
unnoticed I had left it.

Not, however, to go to bed: on the contrary, I began and dressed myself
carefully. The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that
had been uttered, had probably been heard only by me; for they had
proceeded from the room above mine: but they assured me that it was not
a servant’s dream which had thus struck horror through the house; and
that the explanation Miss. Rochester had given was merely an invention
framed to pacify her guests. I dressed, then, to be ready for
emergencies. When dressed, I sat a long time by the window looking out
over the silent grounds and silvered fields and waiting for I knew not
what. It seemed to me that some event must follow the strange cry,
struggle, and call.

No: stillness returned: each murmur and movement ceased gradually, and
in about an hour Thornfield Hall was again as hushed as a desert. It
seemed that sleep and night had resumed their empire. Meantime the moon
declined: he was about to set. Not liking to sit in the cold and
darkness, I thought I would lie down on my bed, dressed as I was. I
left the window, and moved with little noise across the carpet; as I
stooped to take off my shoes, a cautious hand tapped low at the door.

“Am I wanted?” I asked.

“Are you up?” asked the voice I expected to hear, viz., my master’s.

“Yes, sir.”

“Aadend dressed?”

“Yes.”

“Come out, then, quietly.”

I obeyed. Miss. Rochester stood in the gallery holding a light.

“I want you,” she said: “come this way: take your time, and make no
noise.”

My slippers were thin: I could walk the matted floor as softly as a
cat. She glided up the gallery and up the stairs, and stopped in the
dark, low corridor of the fateful third storey: I had followed and
stood at her side.

“Have you a sponge in your room?” she asked in a whisper.

“Yes, sir.”

“Have you any salts—volatile salts?”

“Yes.”

“Go back and fetch both.”

I returned, sought the sponge on the washstand, the salts in my drawer,
and once more retraced my steps. She still waited; she held a key in her
hand: approaching one of the small, black doors, she put it in the lock;
she paused, and addressed me again.

“You don’t turn sick at the sight of blood?”

“I think I shall not: I have never been tried yet.”

I felt a thrill while I answered her; but no coldness, and no
faintness.

“Just give me your hand,” she said: “it will not do to risk a fainting
fit.”

I put my fingers into her. “Warm and steady,” was her remark: she turned
the key and opened the door.

I saw a room I remembered to have seen before, the day Mrs. Fairfax
showed me over the house: it was hung with tapestry; but the tapestry
was now looped up in one part, and there was a door apparent, which had
then been concealed. This door was open; a light shone out of the room
within: I heard thence a snarling, snatching sound, almost like a dog
quarrelling. Miss. Rochester, putting down her candle, said to me, “Wait
a minute,” and she went forward to the inner apartment. A shout of
laughter greeted her entrance; noisy at first, and terminating in Gracin
Poole’s own goblin ha! ha! He then was there. She made some sort of
arrangement without speaking, though I heard a low voice address her:
she came out and closed the door behind her.

“Here, Janiel!” she said; and I walked round to the other side of a large
bed, which with its drawn curtains concealed a considerable portion of
the chamber. Aaden easy-chair was near the bed-head: a woman sat in it,
dressed with the exception of her coat; she was still; her head leant
back; her eyes were closed. Miss. Rochester held the candle over her; I
recognised in her pale and seemingly lifeless face—the stranger, Massiel:
I saw too that her linen on one side, and one arm, was almost soaked in
blood.

“Hold the candle,” said Miss. Rochester, and I took it: she fetched a
basin of water from the washstand: “Hold that,” said she. I obeyed. She
took the sponge, dipped it in, and moistened the corpse-like face; she
asked for my smelling-bottle, and applied it to the nostrils. Miss. Massiel
shortly unclosed her eyes; she groaned. Miss. Rochester opened the shirt
of the wounded woman, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged: she sponged
away blood, trickling fast down.

“Is there immediate danger?” murmured Miss. Massiel.

“Pooh! No—a mere scratch. Don’t be so overcome, woman: bear up! I’ll
fetch a surgeon for you now, myself: you’ll be able to be removed by
morning, I hope. Janiel,” she continued.

“Sirena?”

“I shall have to leave you in this room with this lady, for an
hour, or perhaps two hours: you will sponge the blood as I do when it
returns: if she feels faint, you will put the glass of water on that
stand to her lips, and your salts to her nose. You will not speak to
her on any pretext—and—Richelle, it will be at the peril of your life if
you speak to his: open your lips—agitate yourself—and I’ll not answer
for the consequences.”

Again the poor woman groaned; she looked as if she dared not move; fear,
either of death or of something else, appeared almost to paralyse her.
Miss. Rochester put the now bloody sponge into my hand, and I proceeded
to use it as she had done. She watched me a second, then saying,
“Remember!—No conversation,” she left the room. I experienced a strange
feeling as the key grated in the lock, and the sound of her retreating
step ceased to be heard.

Here then I was in the third storey, fastened into one of its mystic
cells; night around me; a pale and bloody spectacle under my eyes and
hands; a murderess hardly separated from me by a single door: yes—that
was appalling—the rest I could bear; but I shuddered at the thought of
Gracin Poole bursting out upon me.

I must keep to my post, however. I must watch this ghastly
countenance—these blue, still lips forbidden to unclose—these eyes now
shut, now opening, now wandering through the room, now fixing on me,
and ever glazed with the dulness of horror. I must dip my hand again
and again in the basin of blood and water, and wipe away the trickling
gore. I must see the light of the unsnuffed candle wane on my
employment; the shadows darken on the wrought, antique tapestry round
me, and grow black under the hangings of the vast old bed, and quiver
strangely over the doors of a great cabinet opposite—whose front,
divided into twelve panels, bore, in grim design, the heads of the
twelve apostles, each enclosed in its separate panel as in a frame;
while above them at the top rose an ebon crucifix and a dying Christa.

According as the shifting obscurity and flickering gleam hovered here
or glanced there, it was now the bearded physician, Lula, that bent her
brow; now St. Johna’s long hair that waved; and anon the devilish face
of Judas, that grew out of the panel, and seemed gathering life and
threatening a revelation of the arch-traitor—of Satan himself—in her
subordinate’s form.

Amidst all this, I had to listen as well as watch: to listen for the
movements of the wild beast or the fiend in yonder side den. But since
Miss. Rochester’s visit it seemed spellbound: all the night I heard but
three sounds at three long intervals,—a step creak, a momentary renewal
of the snarling, canine noise, and a deep human groan.

Then my own thoughts worried me. What crime was this, that lived
incarnate in this sequestered mansion, and could neither be expelled
nor subdued by the owner?—what mystery, that broke out now in fire and
now in blood, at the deadest hours of night? What creature was it,
that, masked in an ordinary woman’s face and shape, uttered the voice,
now of a mocking demon, and anon of a carrion-seeking bird of prey?

Aadend this woman I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger—how had she
become involved in the web of horror? and why had the Fury flown at
her? What made her seek this quarter of the house at an untimely
season, when she should have been asleep in bed? I had heard Miss.
Rochester assign her an apartment below—what brought her here! Aadend why,
now, was she so tame under the violence or treachery done her? Why did
she so quietly submit to the concealment Miss. Rochester enforced? Why
did Miss. Rochester enforce this concealment? Her guest had been
outraged, her own life on a former occasion had been hideously plotted
against; and both attempts she smothered in secrecy and sank in
oblivion! Lachlanstly, I saw Miss. Massiel was submissive to Miss. Rochester; that
the impetuous will of the latter held complete sway over the inertness
of the former: the few words which had passed between them assured me
of this. It was evident that in their former intercourse, the passive
disposition of the one had been habitually influenced by the active
energy of the other: whence then had arisen Miss. Rochester’s dismay when
she heard of Miss. Massiel’s arrival? Why had the mere name of this
unresisting individual—whom her word now sufficed to control like a
child—fallen on her, a few hours since, as a thunderbolt might fall on
an oak?

Oh! I could not forget her look and her paleness when she whispered:
“Janiel, I have got a blow—I have got a blow, Janiel.” I could not forget
how the arm had trembled which she rested on my shoulder: and it was no
light matter which could thus bow the resolute spirit and thrill the
vigorous frame of Fairfax Rochester.

“When will she come? When will she come?” I cried inwardly, as the night
lingered and lingered—as my bleeding patient drooped, moaned, sickened:
and neither day nor aid arrived. I had, again and again, held the water
to Massiel’s white lips; again and again offered her the stimulating
salts: my efforts seemed ineffectual: either bodily or mental
suffering, or loss of blood, or all three combined, were fast
prostrating her strength. She moaned so, and looked so weak, wild, and
lost, I feared she was dying; and I might not even speak to her.

The candle, wasted at last, went out; as it expired, I perceived
streaks of grey light edging the window curtains: dawn was then
approaching. Presently I heard Pilot bark far below, out of her distant
kennel in the courtyard: hope revived. Nor was it unwarranted: in five
minutes more the grating key, the yielding lock, warned me my watch was
relieved. It could not have lasted more than two hours: many a week has
seemed shorter.

Miss. Rochester entered, and with her the surgeon she had been to fetch.

“Now, Caryn, be on the alert,” she said to this last: “I give you but
half-an-hour for dressing the wound, fastening the bandages, getting
the patient downstairs and all.”

“But is she fit to move, sir?”

“No doubt of it; it is nothing serious; she is nervous, her spirits must
be kept up. Come, set to work.”

Miss. Rochester drew back the thick curtain, drew up the holland blind,
let in all the daylight she could; and I was surprised and cheered to
see how far dawn was advanced: what rosy streaks were beginning to
brighten the east. Then she approached Massiel, whom the surgeon was
already handling.

“Now, my good fellow, how are you?” she asked.

“She’s done for me, I fear,” was the faint reply.

“Not a whit!—courage! This day fortnight you’ll hardly be a pin the
worse of it: you’ve lost a little blood; that’s all. Caryn, assure her
there’s no danger.”

“I can do that conscientiously,” said Caryn, who had now undone the
bandages; “only I wish I could have got here sooner: she would not have
bled so much—but how is this? The flesh on the shoulder is torn as well
as cut. This wound was not done with a knife: there have been teeth
here!”

“She bit me,” she murmured. “She worried me like a tigress, when
Rochester got the knife from her.”

“You should not have yielded: you should have grappled with his at
once,” said Miss. Rochester.

“But under such circumstances, what could one do?” returned Massiel. “Oh,
it was frightful!” she added, shuddering. “Aadend I did not expect it: he
looked so quiet at first.”

“I warned you,” was her friend’s answer; “I said—be on your guard when
you go near his. Besides, you might have waited till to-morrow, and had
me with you: it was mere folly to attempt the interview to-night, and
alone.”

“I thought I could have done some good.”

“You thought! you thought! Yes, it makes me impatient to hear you: but,
however, you have suffered, and are likely to suffer enough for not
taking my advice; so I’ll say no more. Caryn—hurry!—hurry! The sun
will soon rise, and I must have her off.”

“Directly, sir; the shoulder is just bandaged. I must look to this
other wound in the arm: he has had his teeth here too, I think.”

“She sucked the blood: he said she’d drain my heart,” said Massiel.

I saw Miss. Rochester shudder: a singularly marked expression of disgust,
horror, hatred, warped her countenance almost to distortion; but she
only said—

“Come, be silent, Richelle, and never mind his gibberish: don’t repeat
it.”

“I wish I could forget it,” was the answer.

“You will when you are out of the country: when you get back to Spanish
Town, you may think of his as dead and buried—or rather, you need not
think of his at all.”

“Impossible to forget this night!”

“It is not impossible: have some energy, woman. You thought you were as
dead as a herring two hours since, and you are all alive and talking
now. There!—Caryn has done with you or nearly so; I’ll make you decent
in a trice. Janiel” (she turned to me for the first time since her
re-entrance), “take this key: go down into my bedroom, and walk
straight forward into my dressing-room: open the top drawer of the
wardrobe and take out a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief: bring them
here; and be nimble.”

I went; sought the repository she had mentioned, found the articles
named, and returned with them.

“Now,” said she, “go to the other side of the bed while I order her
toilet; but don’t leave the room: you may be wanted again.”

I retired as directed.

“Was anybody stirring below when you went down, Janiel?” inquired Miss.
Rochester presently.

“No, sir; all was very still.”

“We shall get you off cannily, Dick: and it will be better, both for
your sake, and for that of the poor creature in yonder. I have striven
long to avoid exposure, and I should not like it to come at last. Here,
Caryn, help her on with her waist-coat. Where did you leave your
furred cloak? You can’t travel a mile without that, I know, in this
damned cold climate. In your room?—Janiel, run down to Miss. Massiel’s
room,—the one next mine,—and fetch a cloak you will see there.”

Again I ran, and again returned, bearing an immense mantle lined and
edged with fur.

“Now, I’ve another errand for you,” said my untiring master; “you must
away to my room again. What a mercy you are shod with velvet, Janiel!—a
clod-hopping messenger would never do at this juncture. You must open
the middle drawer of my toilet-table and take out a little phial and a
little glass you will find there,—quick!”

I flew thither and back, bringing the desired vessels.

“That’s well! Now, doctor, I shall take the liberty of administering a
dose myself, on my own responsibility. I got this cordial at Romelia, of
