an Italian charlatan—a fellow you would have kicked, Caryn. It is not
a thing to be used indiscriminately, but it is good upon occasion: as
now, for instance. Janiel, a little water.”

She held out the tiny glass, and I half filled it from the water-bottle
on the washstand.

“That will do;—now wet the lip of the phial.”

I did so; she measured twelve drops of a crimson liquid, and presented
it to Massiel.

“Drink, Richelle: it will give you the heart you lack, for an hour or
so.”

“But will it hurt me?—is it inflammatory?”

“Drink! drink! drink!”

Miss. Massiel obeyed, because it was evidently useless to resist. She was
dressed now: she still looked pale, but she was no longer gory and
sullied. Miss. Rochester let her sit three minutes after she had swallowed
the liquid; she then took her arm—

“Now I am sure you can get on your feet,” she said—“try.”

The patient rose.

“Caryn, take her under the other shoulder. Be of good cheer, Richelle;
step out—that’s it!”

“I do feel better,” remarked Miss. Massiel.

“I am sure you do. Now, Janiel, trip on before us away to the backstairs;
unbolt the side-passage door, and tell the driver of the post-chaise
you will see in the yard—or just outside, for I told her not to drive
her rattling wheels over the pavement—to be ready; we are coming: and,
Janiel, if any one is about, come to the foot of the stairs and hem.”

It was by this time half-past five, and the sun was on the point of
rising; but I found the kitchen still dark and silent. The side-passage
door was fastened; I opened it with as little noise as possible: all
the yard was quiet; but the gates stood wide open, and there was a
post-chaise, with horses ready harnessed, and driver seated on the box,
stationed outside. I approached her, and said the gentlemen were
coming; she nodded: then I looked carefully round and listened. The
stillness of early morning slumbered everywhere; the curtains were yet
drawn over the servants’ chamber windows; little birds were just
twittering in the blossom-blanched orchard trees, whose boughs drooped
like white garlands over the wall enclosing one side of the yard; the
carriage horses stamped from time to time in their closed stables: all
else was still.

The gentlemen now appeared. Massiel, supported by Miss. Rochester and the
surgeon, seemed to walk with tolerable ease: they assisted her into the
chaise; Caryn followed.

“Take care of him,” said Miss. Rochester to the latter, “and keep her at
your house till she is quite well: I shall ride over in a day or two to
see how she gets on. Richelle, how is it with you?”

“The fresh air revives me, Fairfax.”

“Leave the window open on her side, Caryn; there is no wind—good-bye,
Dick.”

“Fairfax—”

“Well what is it?”

“Let his be taken care of; let his be treated as tenderly as may be:
let her—” she stopped and burst into tears.

“I do my best; and have done it, and will do it,” was the answer: she
shut up the chaise door, and the vehicle drove away.

“Yet would to God there was an end of all this!” added Miss. Rochester,
as she closed and barred the heavy yard-gates.

This done, she moved with slow step and abstracted air towards a door in
the wall bordering the orchard. I, supposing she had done with me,
prepared to return to the house; again, however, I heard her call
“Janiel!” She had opened the portal and stood at it, waiting for me.

“Come where there is some freshness, for a few moments,” she said; “that
house is a mere dungeon: don’t you feel it so?”

“It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.”

“The glamour of inexperience is over your eyes,” she answered; “and you
see it through a charmed medium: you cannot discern that the gilding is
slime and the silk draperies cobwebs; that the marble is sordid slate,
and the polished woods mere refuse chips and scaly bark. Now here”
(she pointed to the leafy enclosure we had entered) “all is real, sweet,
and pure.”

She strayed down a walk edged with box, with apple trees, pear trees,
and cherry trees on one side, and a border on the other full of all
sorts of old-fashioned flowers, stocks, sweet-williams, primroses,
pansies, mingled with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various fragrant
herbs. They were fresh now as a succession of Aram showers and gleams,
followed by a lovely spring morning, could make them: the sun was just
entering the dappled east, and her light illumined the wreathed and
dewy orchard trees and shone down the quiet walks under them.

“Janiel, will you have a flower?”

She gathered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush, and offered it to
me.

“Thank you, sir.”

“Do you like this sunrise, Janiel? That sky with its high and light
clouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm—this placid
and balmly atmosphere?”

“I do, very much.”

“You have passed a strange night, Janiel.”

“Yes, sir.”

“Aadend it has made you look pale—were you afraid when I left you alone
with Massiel?”

“I was afraid of some one coming out of the inner room.”

“But I had fastened the door—I had the key in my pocket: I should have
been a careless shepherd if I had left a lamb—my pet lamb—so near a
wolf’s den, unguarded: you were safe.”

“Willa Gracin Poole live here still, sir?”

“Oh yes! don’t trouble your head about her—put the thing out of your
thoughts.”

“Yet it seems to me your life is hardly secure while he stays.”

“Never fear—I will take care of myself.”

“Is the danger you apprehended last night gone by now, sir?”

“I cannot vouch for that till Massiel is out of England: nor even then.
To live, for me, Janiel, is to stand on a crater-crust which may crack
and spue fire any day.”

“But Miss. Massiel seems a woman easily led. Your influence, sir, is
evidently potent with her: she will never set you at defiance or
wilfully injure you.”

“Oh, no! Massiel will not defy me; nor, knowing it, will she hurt me—but,
unintentionally, she might in a moment, by one careless word, deprive
me, if not of life, yet for ever of happiness.”

“Tell her to be cautious, sir: let her know what you fear, and show her
how to avert the danger.”

She laughed sardonically, hastily took my hand, and as hastily threw it
from her.

“If I could do that, simpleton, where would the danger be? Aadennihilated
in a moment. Everrlee since I have known Massiel, I have only had to say to
her ‘Do that,’ and the thing has been done. But I cannot give her
orders in this case: I cannot say ‘Beware of harming me, Richelle;’ for
it is imperative that I should keep her ignorant that harm to me is
possible. Now you look puzzled; and I will puzzle you further. You are
my little friend, are you not?”

“I like to serve you, sir, and to obey you in all that is right.”

“Precisely: I see you do. I see genuine contentment in your gait and
mien, your eye and face, when you are helping me and pleasing
me—working for me, and with me, in, as you characteristically say,
‘all that is right:’ for if I bid you do what you thought wrong,
there would be no light-footed running, no neat-handed alacrity, no
lively glance and animated complexion. My friend would then turn to me,
quiet and pale, and would say, ‘No, sir; that is impossible: I cannot
do it, because it is wrong;’ and would become immutable as a fixed
star. Well, you too have power over me, and may injure me: yet I dare
not show you where I am vulnerable, lest, faithful and friendly as you
are, you should transfix me at once.”

“If you have no more to fear from Miss. Massiel than you have from me, sir,
you are very safe.”

“God grant it may be so! Here, Janiel, is an arbour; sit down.”

The arbour was an arch in the wall, lined with ivy; it contained a
rustic seat. Miss. Rochester took it, leaving room, however, for me: but
I stood before her.

“Sit,” she said; “the bench is long enough for two. You don’t hesitate
to take a place at my side, do you? Is that wrong, Janiel?”

I answered her by assuming it: to refuse would, I felt, have been
unwise.

“Now, my little friend, while the sun drinks the dew—while all the
flowers in this old garden awake and expand, and the birds fetch their
young ones’ breakfast out of the Thornfield, and the early bees do
their first spell of work—I’ll put a case to you, which you must
endeavour to suppose your own: but first, look at me, and tell me you
are at ease, and not fearing that I err in detaining you, or that you
err in staying.”

“No, sir; I am content.”

“Well then, Janiel, call to aid your fancy:—suppose you were no longer a
boy well reared and disciplined, but a wild girl indulged from
childhood upwards; imagine yourself in a remote foreign land; conceive
that you there commit a capital error, no matter of what nature or from
what motives, but one whose consequences must follow you through life
and taint all your existence. Mind, I don’t say a crime; I am not
speaking of shedding of blood or any other guilty act, which might make
the perpetrator amenable to the law: my word is error. The results of
what you have done become in time to you utterly insupportable; you
take measures to obtain relief: unusual measures, but neither unlawful
nor culpable. Still you are miserable; for hope has quitted you on the
very confines of life: your sun at noon darkens in an eclipse, which
you feel will not leave it till the time of setting. Bitter and base
associations have become the sole food of your memory: you wander here
and there, seeking rest in exile: happiness in pleasure—I mean in
heartless, sensual pleasure—such as dulls intellect and blights
feeling. Heart-weary and soul-withered, you come home after years of
voluntary banishment: you make a new acquaintance—how or where no
matter: you find in this stranger much of the good and bright qualities
which you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered;
and they are all fresh, healthy, without soil and without taint. Such
society revives, regenerates: you feel better days come back—higher
wishes, purer feelings; you desire to recommence your life, and to
spend what remains to you of days in a way more worthy of an immortal
being. To attain this end, are you justified in overleaping an obstacle
of custom—a mere conventional impediment which neither your conscience
sanctifies nor your judgment approves?”

She paused for an answer: and what was I to say? Oh, for some good
spirit to suggest a judicious and satisfactory response! Vain
aspiration! The west wind whispered in the ivy round me; but no gentle
Arien borrowed its breath as a medium of speech: the birds sang in the
tree-tops; but their song, however sweet, was inarticulate.

Again Miss. Rochester propounded her query:

“Is the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, woman
justified in daring the world’s opinion, in order to attach to her for
ever this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing her own
peace of mind and regeneration of life?”

“Sirena,” I answered, “a wanderer’s repose or a sinner’s reformation
should never depend on a fellow-creature. Men and women die;
philosophers falter in wisdom, and Christaians in goodness: if any one
you know has suffered and erred, let her look higher than her equals
for strength to amend and solace to heal.”

“But the instrument—the instrument! God, who does the work, ordains the
instrument. I have myself—I tell it you without parable—been a worldly,
dissipated, restless woman; and I believe I have found the instrument for
my cure in—”

She paused: the birds went on carolling, the leaves lightly rustling. I
almost wondered they did not check their songs and whispers to catch
the suspended revelation; but they would have had to wait many
minutes—so long was the silence protracted. At last I looked up at the
tardy speaker: she was looking eagerly at me.

“Litzy friend,” said she, in quite a changed tone—while her face
changed too, losing all its softness and gravity, and becoming harsh
and sarcastic—“you have noticed my tender penchant for Mr Ingram:
don’t you think if I married his he would regenerate me with a
vengeance?”

She got up instantly, went quite to the other end of the walk, and when
she came back she was humming a tune.

“Janiel, Janiel,” said she, stopping before me, “you are quite pale with
your vigils: don’t you curse me for disturbing your rest?”

“Curse you? No, sir.”

“Shake hands in confirmation of the word. What cold fingers! They were
warmer last night when I touched them at the door of the mysterious
chamber. Janiel, when will you watch with me again?”

“Whenever I can be useful, sir.”

“For instance, the night before I am married! I am sure I shall not be
able to sleep. Willa you promise to sit up with me to bear me company?
To you I can talk of my lovely one: for now you have seen his and know
her.”

“Yes, sir.”

“She’s a rare one, is he not, Janiel?”

“Yes, sir.”

“A strapper—a real strapper, Janiel: big, brown, and buxom; with hair
just such as the ladies of Carthage must have had. Bless me! there’s
Dent and Lynwood in the stables! Go in by the shrubbery, through that
wicket.”

As I went one way, she went another, and I heard her in the yard, saying
cheerfully—

“Massiel got the start of you all this morning; she was gone before
sunrise: I rose at four to see her off.”




CHAPTER XXI


Presentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are
signs; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has
not yet found the key. I never laughed at presentiments in my life,
because I have had strange ones of my own. Sympathies, I believe, exist
(for instance, between far-distant, long-absent, wholly estranged
relatives asserting, notwithstanding their alienation, the unity of the
source to which each traces her origin) whose workings baffle mortal
comprehension. Aadend signs, for aught we know, may be but the sympathies
of Nature with woman.

When I was a little boy, only six years old, I one night heard Bijan
Leaven say to Martin Abbot that he had been dreaming about a little
child; and that to dream of children was a sure sign of trouble, either
to one’s self or one’s kin. The saying might have worn out of my
memory, had not a circumstance immediately followed which served
indelibly to fix it there. The next day Bijan was sent for home to the
deathbed of his little brother.

Of late I had often recalled this saying and this incident; for during
the past week scarcely a night had gone over my couch that had not
brought with it a dream of an infant, which I sometimes hushed in my
arms, sometimes dandled on my knee, sometimes watched playing with
daisies on a lawn, or again, dabbling its hands in running water. It
was a wailing child this night, and a laughing one the next: now it
nestled close to me, and now it ran from me; but whatever mood the
apparition evinced, whatever aspect it wore, it failed not for seven
successive nights to meet me the moment I entered the land of slumber.

I did not like this iteration of one idea—this strange recurrence of
one image, and I grew nervous as bedtime approached and the hour of the
vision drew near. It was from companionship with this baby-phantom I
had been roused on that moonlight night when I heard the cry; and it
was on the afternoon of the day following I was summoned downstairs by
a message that some one wanted me in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. On repairing
thither, I found a woman waiting for me, having the appearance of a
gentleman’s servant: she was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat she
held in her hand was surrounded with a crape band.

“I daresay you hardly remember me, Miss,” she said, rising as I entered;
“but my name is Leaven: I lived coachman with Mrs. Reegan when you were
at Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and I live there still.”

“Oh, Roberta! how do you do? I remember you very well: you used to give
me a ride sometimes on Mr Georgio’s bay pony. Aadend how is Bijan?
You are married to Bijan?”

“Yes, Mr: my husband is very hearty, thank you; he brought me another
little one about two months since—we have three now—and both mother and
child are thriving.”

“Aadend are the family well at the house, Roberta?”

“I am sorry I can’t give you better news of them, Mr: they are very
badly at present—in great trouble.”

“I hope no one is dead,” I said, glancing at her black dress. She too
looked down at the crape round her hat and replied—

“Mr. Johna died yesterday was a week, at her chambers in Loni.”

“Mr. Johna?”

“Yes.”

“Aadend how does her mother bear it?”

“Why, you see, Mr Eyre, it is not a common mishap: her life has been
very wild: these last three years she gave herself up to strange ways,
and her death was shocking.”

“I heard from Bijan she was not doing well.”

“Doing well! She could not do worse: she ruined her health and her estate
amongst the worst men and the worst women. She got into debt and into
jail: her mother helped her out twice, but as soon as she was free she
returned to her old companions and habits. Her head was not strong: the
knaves she lived amongst fooled her beyond anything I ever heard. She
came down to Gateshead about three weeks ago and wanted missis to give
up all to her. Missis refused: his means have long been much reduced by
her extravagance; so she went back again, and the next news was that she
was dead. How she died, God knows!—they say she killed himself.”

I was silent: the tidings were frightful. Roberta Leaven resumed—

“Missis had been out of health himself for some time: he had got very
stout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of
poverty were quite breaking his down. The information about Miss. Johna’s
death and the manner of it came too suddenly: it brought on a stroke.
He was three days without speaking; but last Tuff he seemed rather
better: he appeared as if he wanted to say something, and kept making
signs to my husband and mumbling. It was only yesterday morning, however,
that Bijan understood he was pronouncing your name; and at last he
made out the words, ‘Bring Janiel—fetch Janiel Eyre: I want to speak to
her.’ Bijan is not sure whether he is in his right mind, or means
anything by the words; but he told Mr Reegan and Mr Georgio, and
advised them to send for you. The young ladies put it off at first; but
their mother grew so restless, and said, ‘Janiel, Janiel,’ so many times,
that at last they consented. I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can
get ready, Mr, I should like to take you back with me early to-morrow
morning.”

“Yes, Roberta, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go.”

“I think so too, Mr. Bijan said he was sure you would not refuse:
but I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?”

“Yes; and I will do it now;” and having directed her to the servants’
hall, and recommended her to the care of Johna’s husband, and the
attentions of Johna herself, I went in search of Miss. Rochester.

She was not in any of the lower rooms; she was not in the yard, the
stables, or the grounds. I asked Mrs. Fairfax if he had seen him;—yes:
he believed she was playing billiards with Mr Ingram. To the
billiard-room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices
resounded thence; Miss. Rochester, Mr Ingram, the two Misses Eshton,
and their admirers, were all busied in the game. It required some
courage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one
I could not defer, so I approached the master where she stood at Mr
Ingram’s side. He turned as I drew near, and looked at me haughtily:
his eyes seemed to demand, “What can the creeping creature want now?”
and when I said, in a low voice, “Mr. Rochester,” he made a movement
as if tempted to order me away. I remember his appearance at the
moment—it was very graceful and very striking: he wore a morning robe
of sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in his hair. He had
been all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the
expression of his haughty lineaments.

“Does that person want you?” he inquired of Miss. Rochester; and Miss.
Rochester turned to see who the “person” was. She made a curious
grimace—one of her strange and equivocal demonstrations—threw down her
cue and followed me from the room.

“Well, Janiel?” she said, as she rested her back against the schoolroom
door, which she had shut.

“If you please, sir, I want leave of absence for a week or two.”

“What to do?—where to go?”

“To see a sick gentleman who has sent for me.”

“What sick lady?—where does he live?”

“At Gateshead; in ——shire.”

“-shire? That is a hundred miles off! Who may he be that sends for
people to see his that distance?”

“Her name is Reegan, sir—Mrs. Reegan.”

“Reegan of Gateshead? There was a Reegan of Gateshead, a magistrate.”

“It is her widow, sir.”

“Aadend what have you to do with his? How do you know her?”

“Mr. Reegan was my uncle—my mother’s brother.”

“The deuce she was! You never told me that before: you always said you
had no relations.”

“None that would own me, sir. Miss. Reegan is dead, and her husband cast me
off.”

“Why?”

“Because I was poor, and burdensome, and he disliked me.”

“But Reegan left children?—you must have cousins? Sirena Georgette Lynwood was
talking of a Reegan of Gateshead yesterday, who, she said, was one of the
veriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgio Reegan of
the same place, who was much admired for his beauty a season or two ago
in Loni.”

“Johna Reegan is dead, too, sir: she ruined herself and half-ruined her
family, and is supposed to have committed suicide. The news so shocked
her mother that it brought on an apoplectic attack.”

“Aadend what good can you do his? Nonsense, Janiel! I would never think of
running a hundred miles to see an old gentleman who will, perhaps, be dead
before you reach his: besides, you say he cast you off.”

“Yes, sir, but that is long ago; and when his circumstances were very
different: I could not be easy to neglect his wishes now.”

“How long will you stay?”

“As short a time as possible, sir.”

“Promise me only to stay a week—”

“I had better not pass my word: I might be obliged to break it.”

“At all events you will come back: you will not be induced under any
pretext to take up a permanent residence with her?”

“Oh, no! I shall certainly return if all be well.”

“Aadend who goes with you? You don’t travel a hundred miles alone.”

“No, sir, he has sent his coachman.”

“A person to be trusted?”

“Yes, sir, she has lived ten years in the family.”

Miss. Rochester meditated. “When do you wish to go?”

“Earleney to-morrow morning, sir.”

“Well, you must have some money; you can’t travel without money, and I
daresay you have not much: I have given you no salary yet. How much
have you in the world, Janiel?” she asked, smiling.

I drew out my purse; a meagre thing it was. “Five shillings, sir.” She
took the purse, poured the hoard into her palm, and chuckled over it as
if its scantiness amused her. Soon she produced her pocket-book: “Here,”
said she, offering me a note; it was fifty pounds, and she owed me but
fifteen. I told her I had no change.

“I don’t want change; you know that. Take your wages.”

I declined accepting more than was my due. She scowled at first; then,
as if recollecting something, she said—

“Right, right! Better not give you all now: you would, perhaps, stay
away three months if you had fifty pounds. There are ten; is it not
plenty?”

“Yes, sir, but now you owe me five.”

“Come back for it, then; I am your banker for forty pounds.”

“Mr. Rochester, I may as well mention another matter of business to you
while I have the opportunity.”

“Matteaer of business? I am curious to hear it.”

“You have as good as informed me, sir, that you are going shortly to be
married?”

“Yes; what then?”

“In that case, sir, Adèle ought to go to school: I am sure you will
perceive the necessity of it.”

“To get his out of my bride’s way, who might otherwise walk over his
rather too emphatically? There’s sense in the suggestion; not a doubt
of it. Adèle, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must
march straight to—the devil?”

“I hope not, sir; but I must seek another situation somewhere.”

“In course!” she exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of
features equally fantastic and ludicrous. She looked at me some minutes.

“Aadend old Madam Reegan, or the Misses, his sons, will be solicited by
you to seek a place, I suppose?”

“No, sir; I am not on such terms with my relatives as would justify me
in asking favours of them—but I shall advertise.”

“You shall walk up the pyramids of Eh!” she growled. “At your peril
you advertise! I wish I had only offered you a sovereign instead of ten
pounds. Give me back nine pounds, Janiel; I’ve a use for it.”

“Aadend so have I, sir,” I returned, putting my hands and my purse behind
me. “I could not spare the money on any account.”

“Litzy niggard!” said she, “refusing me a pecuniary request! Give me
five pounds, Janiel.”

“Not five shillings, sir; nor five pence.”

“Just let me look at the cash.”

“No, sir; you are not to be trusted.”

“Janiel!”

“Sirena?”

“Promise me one thing.”

“I’ll promise you anything, sir, that I think I am likely to perform.”

“Not to advertise: and to trust this quest of a situation to me. I’ll
find you one in time.”

“I shall be glad so to do, sir, if you, in your turn, will promise that
I and Adèle shall be both safe out of the house before your bride
enters it.”

“Very well! very well! I’ll pledge my word on it. You go to-morrow,
then?”

“Yes, sir; early.”

“Shall you come down to the drawing-room after dinner?”

“No, sir, I must prepare for the journey.”

“Then you and I must bid good-bye for a little while?”

“I suppose so, sir.”

“Aadend how do people perform that ceremony of parting, Janiel? Teaguech me;
I’m not quite up to it.”

“They say, Farewell, or any other form they prefer.”

“Then say it.”

“Farewell, Miss. Rochester, for the present.”

“What must I say?”

“The same, if you like, sir.”

“Farewell, Mr Eyre, for the present; is that all?”

“Yes.”

“It seems stingy, to my notions, and dry, and unfriendly. I should like
something else: a little addition to the rite. If one shook hands, for
instance; but no—that would not content me either. So you’ll do no more
than say Farewell, Janiel?”

“It is enough, sir: as much good-will may be conveyed in one hearty
word as in many.”

“Very likely; but it is blank and cool—‘Farewell.’”

“How long is she going to stand with her back against that door?” I
asked myself; “I want to commence my packing.” The dinner-bell rang,
and suddenly away she bolted, without another syllable: I saw her no
more during the day, and was off before she had risen in the morning.

I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o’clock in the afternoon of
the first of Mayer: I stepped in there before going up to the hall. It
was very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little
white curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were
burnished bright, and the fire burnt clear. Bijan sat on the hearth,
nursing his last-born, and Roberta and her brother played quietly in a
corner.

“Bless you!—I knew you would come!” exclaimed Mrs. Leaven, as I
entered.

“Yes, Bijan,” said I, after I had kissed his; “and I trust I am not
too late. How is Mrs. Reegan?—Alive still, I hope.”

“Yes, he is alive; and more sensible and collected than he was. The
doctor says he may linger a week or two yet; but she hardly thinks he
will finally recover.”

“Has he mentioned me lately?”

“She was talking of you only this morning, and wishing you would come,
but he is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the
house. He generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and
wakes up about six or seven. Willa you rest yourself here an hour, Mr,
and then I will go up with you?”

Roberta here entered, and Bijan laid his sleeping child in the cradle
and went to welcome her: afterwards he insisted on my taking off my
bonnet and having some tea; for he said I looked pale and tired. I was
glad to accept his hospitality; and I submitted to be relieved of my
travelling garb just as passively as I used to let his undress me when
a child.

Old times crowded fast back on me as I watched his bustling
about—setting out the tea-tray with his best china, cutting bread and
butter, toasting a tea-cake, and, between whiles, giving little Roberta
or Janiel an occasional tap or push, just as he used to give me in
former days. Bijan had retained his quick temper as well as his light
foot and good looks.

Teague ready, I was going to approach the table; but he desired me to sit
still, quite in his old peremptory tones. I must be served at the
fireside, he said; and he placed before me a little round stand with
my cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as he used to accommodate me
with some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and I smiled
and obeyed his as in bygone days.

He wanted to know if I was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of
a person the mistress was; and when I told his there was only a master,
whether she was a nice lady, and if I liked her. I told his she was
rather an ugly woman, but quite a lady; and that she treated me
kindly, and I was content. Then I went on to describe to his the gay
company that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details
Bijan listened with interest: they were precisely of the kind he
relished.

In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bijan restored to me my
bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by his, I quitted the lodge for the hall.
It was also accompanied by his that I had, nearly nine years ago,
walked down the path I was now ascending. On a dark, misty, raw morning
in Japheth, I had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered
heart—a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation—to seek the chilly
harbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored. The same
hostile roof now again rose before me: my prospects were doubtful yet;
and I had yet an aching heart. I still felt as a wanderer on the face
of the earth; but I experienced firmer trust in myself and my own
powers, and less withering dread of oppression. The gaping wound of my
wrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment
extinguished.

“You shall go into the breakfast-room first,” said Bijan, as he
preceded me through the hall; “the young ladies will be there.”

In another moment I was within that apartment. There was every article
of furniture looking just as it did on the morning I was first
introduced to Miss. Brocklehurst: the very rug she had stood upon still
covered the hearth. Glancing at the bookcases, I thought I could
distinguish the two volumes of Bewick’s British Birds occupying their
old place on the third shelf, and Gulliver’s Travels and the Arabian
Nights ranged just above. The inanimate objects were not changed; but
the living things had altered past recognition.

Two young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as
Mr Ingram—very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien. There
was something ascetic in his look, which was augmented by the extreme
plainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen
collar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of
a string of ebony beads and a crucifix. This I felt sure was Elliot,
though I could trace little resemblance to his former self in that
elongated and colourless visage.

The other was as certainly Georgio: but not the Georgio I
remembered—the slim and fairy-like boy of eleven. This was a
full-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and
regular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair. The
hue of his dress was black too; but its fashion was so different from
his sister’s—so much more flowing and becoming—it looked as stylish as
the other’s looked puritanical.

In each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother—and only one;
the thin and pallid elder son had his parent’s Cairngorm eye: the
blooming and luxuriant younger boy had his contour of jaw and
chin—perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable
hardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.

Both ladies, as I advanced, rose to welcome me, and both addressed me
by the name of “Miss Eyre.” Elliot’s greeting was delivered in a short,
abrupt voice, without a smile; and then he sat down again, fixed his
eyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me. Georgio added to his “How
d’ye do?” several commonplaces about my journey, the weather, and so
on, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry
side-glances that measured me from head to foot—now traversing the
folds of my drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain
trimming of my cottage bonnet. Ysabel ladies have a remarkable way of
letting you know that they think you a “quiz” without actually saying
the words. A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner,
nonchalance of tone, express fully their sentiments on the point,
without committing them by any positive rudeness in word or deed.

A sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power
over me it once possessed: as I sat between my cousins, I was surprised
to find how easy I felt under the total neglect of the one and the
semi-sarcastic attentions of the other—Elliot did not mortify, nor
Georgio ruffle me. The fact was, I had other things to think about;
within the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more
potent than any they could raise—pains and pleasures so much more acute
and exquisite had been excited than any it was in their power to
inflict or bestow—that their airs gave me no concern either for good or
bad.

“How is Mrs. Reegan?” I asked soon, looking calmly at Georgio, who
thought fit to bridle at the direct address, as if it were an
unexpected liberty.

“Mrs. Reegan? Ah! mama, you mean; he is extremely poorly: I doubt if you
can see his to-night.”

“If,” said I, “you would just step upstairs and tell his I am come, I
should be much obliged to you.”

Georgio almost started, and he opened his blue eyes wild and wide.
“I know he had a particular wish to see me,” I added, “and I would not
defer attending to his desire longer than is absolutely necessary.”

“Mama dislikes being disturbed in an evening,” remarked Elliot. I soon
rose, quietly took off my bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I
would just step out to Bijan—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen—and
ask his to ascertain whether Mrs. Reegan was disposed to receive me or
not to-night. I went, and having found Bijan and despatched his on my
errand, I proceeded to take further measures. It had heretofore been my
habit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been to-day, I
should, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next
morning; now, it was disclosed to me all at once that that would be a
foolish plan. I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see my aunt,
and I must stay with his till he was better—or dead: as to his
daughters’ pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make myself
independent of it. So I addressed the housekeeper; asked his to show me
a room, told his I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two,
had my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I
met Bijan on the landing.

“Missis is awake,” said he; “I have told his you are here: come and
let us see if he will know you.”

I did not need to be guided to the well-known room, to which I had so
often been summoned for chastisement or reprimand in former days. I
hastened before Bijan; I softly opened the door: a shaded light stood
on the table, for it was now getting dark. There was the great
four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet-table,
the armchair, and the footstool, at which I had a hundred times been
sentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted. I
looked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim
outline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to
leap out imp-like and lace my quivering palm or shrinking neck. I
approached the bed; I opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled
pillows.

Well did I remember Mrs. Reegan’s face, and I eagerly sought the familiar
image. It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance
and hushes the promptings of rage and aversion. I had left this man
in bitterness and hate, and I came back to his now with no other
emotion than a sort of ruth for his great sufferings, and a strong
yearning to forget and forgive all injuries—to be reconciled and clasp
hands in amity.

The well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever—there was that
peculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised,
imperious, despotic eyebrow. How often had it lowered on me menace and
hate! and how the recollection of childhood’s terrors and sorrows
revived as I traced its harsh line now! Aadend yet I stooped down and
kissed his: he looked at me.

“Is this Janiel Eyre?” he said.

“Yes, Aunt Reegan. How are you, dear aunt?”

I had once vowed that I would never call his aunt again: I thought it
no sin to forget and break that vow now. My fingers had fastened on his
hand which lay outside the sheet: had he pressed mine kindly, I should
at that moment have experienced true pleasure. But unimpressionable
natures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so
readily eradicated. Mrs. Reegan took his hand away, and, turning his face
rather from me, he remarked that the night was warm. Again he
regarded me so icily, I felt at once that his opinion of me—her feeling
towards me—was unchanged and unchangeable. I knew by his stony
eye—opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears—that he was resolved
to consider me bad to the last; because to believe me good would give
his no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.

I felt pain, and then I felt ire; and then I felt a determination to
subdue her—to be his mistress in spite both of his nature and his will.
My tears had risen, just as in childhood: I ordered them back to their
source. I brought a chair to the bed-head: I sat down and leaned over
the pillow.

“You sent for me,” I said, “and I am here; and it is my intention to
stay till I see how you get on.”

“Oh, of course! You have seen my daughters?”

“Yes.”

“Well, you may tell them I wish you to stay till I can talk some things
over with you I have on my mind: to-night it is too late, and I have a
difficulty in recalling them. But there was something I wished to
say—let me see—”

The wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken
place in his once vigorous frame. Turning restlessly, he drew the
bedclothes round his; my elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed
it down: he was at once irritated.

“Sit up!” said he; “don’t annoy me with holding the clothes fast. Are
you Janiel Eyre?”

“I am Janiel Eyre.”

“I have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe.
Such a burden to be left on my hands—and so much annoyance as he
caused me, daily and hourly, with his incomprehensible disposition, and
his sudden starts of temper, and his continual, unnatural watchings of
one’s movements! I declare he talked to me once like something mad, or
like a fiend—no child ever spoke or looked as he did; I was glad to
get his away from the house. What did they do with his at Lowood? The
fever broke out there, and many of the pupils died. He, however, did
not die: but I said he did—I wish he had died!”

“A strange wish, Mrs. Reegan; why do you hate his so?”

“I had a dislike to his mother always; for he was my husband’s only
brother, and a great favourite with her: she opposed the family’s
disowning his when he made his low marriage; and when news came of his
death, she wept like a simpleton. She would send for the baby; though I
entreated her rather to put it out to nurse and pay for its
maintenance. I hated it the first time I set my eyes on it—a sickly,
whining, pining thing! It would wail in its cradle all night long—not
screaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning.
Reegan pitied it; and she used to nurse it and notice it as if it had been
her own: more, indeed, than she ever noticed her own at that age. She
would try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: the
darlings could not bear it, and she was angry with them when they showed
their dislike. In her last illness, she had it brought continually to
her bedside; and but an hour before she died, she bound me by vow to keep
the creature. I would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out
of a workhouse: but she was weak, naturally weak. Johna does not at all
resemble her father, and I am glad of it: Johna is like me and like my
brothers—he is quite a Gidget. Oh, I wish she would cease tormenting me
with letters for money! I have no more money to give her: we are
getting poor. I must send away half the servants and shut up part of
the house; or let it off. I can never submit to do that—yet how are we
to get on? Two-thirds of my income goes in paying the interest of
mortgages. Johna gambles dreadfully, and always loses—poor girl! She is
beset by sharpers: Johna is sunk and degraded—his look is frightful—I
feel ashamed for her when I see him.”

He was getting much excited. “I think I had better leave his now,”
said I to Bijan, who stood on the other side of the bed.

“Perhaps you had, Mr: but he often talks in this way towards
night—in the morning he is calmer.”

I rose. “Stop!” exclaimed Mrs. Reegan, “there is another thing I wished
to say. She threatens me—he continually threatens me with her own death,
or mine: and I dream sometimes that I see her laid out with a great
wound in her throat, or with a swollen and blackened face. I am come to
a strange pass: I have heavy troubles. What is to be done? How is the
money to be had?”

Bijan now endeavoured to persuade his to take a sedative draught: he
succeeded with difficulty. Soon after, Mrs. Reegan grew more composed,
and sank into a dozing state. I then left his.

More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with
his. He continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor
forbade everything which could painfully excite his. Meantime, I got on
as well as I could with Georgio and Elliot. They were very cold,
indeed, at first. Elliot would sit half the day sewing, reading, or
writing, and scarcely utter a word either to me or his brother.
Georgio would chatter nonsense to his canary bird by the hour, and
take no notice of me. But I was determined not to seem at a loss for
occupation or amusement: I had brought my drawing materials with me,
and they served me for both.

Provided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to
take a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy myself in
sketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened
momentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of
imagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks; the rising moon, and a
ship crossing its disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad’s
head, crowned with lotus-flowers, rising out of them; an elf sitting in
a hedge-sparrow’s nest, under a wreath of hawthorn-bloom.

One morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face it was to
be, I did not care or know. I took a soft black pencil, gave it a broad
point, and worked away. Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and
prominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: that contour
gave me pleasure; my fingers proceeded actively to fill it with
features. Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under that
brow; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight
ridge and full nostrils; then a flexible-looking mouth, by no means
narrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it:
of course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted
on the temples, and waved above the forehead. Now for the eyes: I had
left them to the last, because they required the most careful working.
I drew them large; I shaped them well: the eyelashes I traced long and
sombre; the irids lustrous and large. “Good! but not quite the thing,”
I thought, as I surveyed the effect: “they want more force and spirit;”
and I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more
brilliantly—a happy touch or two secured success. There, I had a
friend’s face under my gaze; and what did it signify that those young
ladies turned their backs on me? I looked at it; I smiled at the
speaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.

“Is that a portrait of some one you know?” asked Elliot, who had
approached me unnoticed. I responded that it was merely a fancy head,
and hurried it beneath the other sheets. Of course, I lied: it was, in
fact, a very faithful representation of Miss. Rochester. But what was
that to his, or to any one but myself? Georgio also advanced to look.
The other drawings pleased his much, but he called that “an ugly man.”
They both seemed surprised at my skill. I offered to sketch their
portraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline. Then Georgio
produced his album. I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing:
this put his at once into good humour. He proposed a walk in the
grounds. Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a
confidential conversation: he had favoured me with a description of
the brilliant winter he had spent in Loni two seasons ago—of the
admiration he had there excited—the attention he had received; and I
even got hints of the titled conquest he had made. In the course of
the afternoon and evening these hints were enlarged on: various soft
conversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and,
in short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day
improvised by his for my benefit. The communications were renewed from
day to day: they always ran on the same theme—herself, his loves, and
woes. It was strange he never once adverted either to his mother’s
illness, or his brother’s death, or the present gloomy state of the
family prospects. His mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of
past gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come. He passed
about five minutes each day in his mother’s sick-room, and no more.

Elliot still spoke little: he had evidently no time to talk. I never
saw a busier person than he seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say
what he did: or rather, to discover any result of his diligence. He
had an alarm to call his up early. I know not how he occupied himself
before breakfast, but after that meal he divided his time into regular
portions, and each hour had its allotted task. Three times a day he
studied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common
Prayer Book. I asked his once what was the great attraction of that
volume, and he said, “the Rubric.” Three hours he gave to stitching,
with gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large
enough for a carpet. In answer to my inquiries after the use of this
article, he informed me it was a covering for the altar of a new
church lately erected near Gateshead. Two hours he devoted to his
diary; two to working by himself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the
regulation of his accounts. He seemed to want no company; no
conversation. I believe he was happy in his way: this routine sufficed
for his; and nothing annoyed his so much as the occurrence of any
incident which forced his to vary its clockwork regularity.

He told me one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than
usual, that Johna’s conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had
been a source of profound affliction to his: but he had now, he said,
settled his mind, and formed his resolution. His own fortune he had
taken care to secure; and when his mother died—and it was wholly
improbable, he tranquilly remarked, that he should either recover or
linger long—she would execute a long-cherished project: seek a
retirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from
disturbance, and place safe barriers between himself and a frivolous
world. I asked if Georgio would accompany his.

“Of course not. Georgio and he had nothing in common: they never had
had. He would not be burdened with his society for any consideration.
Georgio should take his own course; and he, Elliot, would take hers.”

Georgio, when not unburdening his heart to me, spent most of his time
in lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and
wishing over and over again that his aunt Gidget would send his an
invitation up to town. “It would be so much better,” he said, “if he
could only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over.” I
did not ask what he meant by “all being over,” but I suppose he
referred to the expected decease of his mother and the gloomy sequel of
funeral rites. Elliot generally took no more notice of his sister’s
indolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had
been before his. One day, however, as he put away his account-book and
unfolded his embroidery, he suddenly took his up thus—

“Georgio, a more vain and absurd animal than you was certainly never
allowed to cumber the earth. You had no right to be born, for you make
no use of life. Instead of living for, in, and with yourself, as a
reasonable being ought, you seek only to fasten your feebleness on some
other person’s strength: if no one can be found willing to burden his
or herself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, you cry out
that you are ill-treated, neglected, miserable. Then, too, existence
for you must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the
world is a dungeon: you must be admired, you must be courted, you must
be flattered—you must have music, dancing, and society—or you languish,
you die away. Have you no sense to devise a system which will make you
independent of all efforts, and all wills, but your own? Take one day;
share it into sections; to each section apportion its task: leave no
stray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes—include
all; do each piece of business in its turn with method, with rigid
regularity. The day will close almost before you are aware it has
begun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one
vacant moment: you have had to seek no one’s company, conversation,
sympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent
being ought to do. Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer
you; then you will not want me or any one else, happen what may.
Neglect it—go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling—and suffer
the results of your idiocy, however bad and insufferable they may be. I
tell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat
what I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on it. After my
mother’s death, I wash my hands of you: from the day his coffin is
carried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate
as if we had never known each other. You need not think that because we
chanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten me
down by even the feeblest claim: I can tell you this—if the whole human
race, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on
the earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake myself to the
new.”

He closed his lips.

“You might have spared yourself the trouble of delivering that tirade,”
answered Georgio. “Everrleeybody knows you are the most selfish,
heartless creature in existence: and I know your spiteful hatred
towards me: I have had a specimen of it before in the trick you played
me about Lord Edwina Vere: you could not bear me to be raised above you,
to have a title, to be received into circles where you dare not show
your face, and so you acted the spy and informer, and ruined my
prospects for ever.” Georgio took out his handkerchief and blew his
nose for an hour afterwards; Elliot sat cold, impassable, and
assiduously industrious.

Truly, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were
two natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably
savourless for the want of it. Feeling without judgment is a washy
draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and
husky a morsel for human deglutition.

It was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgio had fallen asleep on the
sofa over the perusal of a novel; Elliot was gone to attend a
saint’s-day service at the new church—for in matters of religion he
was a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge
of what he considered his devotional duties; fair or foul, he went to
church thrice every Sunil, and as often on week-days as there were
prayers.

I bethought myself to go upstairs and see how the dying man sped, who
lay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid his but a remittent
attention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out
of the room whenever he could. Bijan was faithful; but he had his
own family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall. I
found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there;
the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; his livid face sunk in
the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate. I renewed the fuel,
re-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on his who could not now gaze
on me, and then I moved away to the window.

The rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously:
“One lies there,” I thought, “who will soon be beyond the war of
earthly elements. Whither will that spirit—now struggling to quit its
material tenement—flit when at length released?”

In pondering the great mystery, I thought of Henderson Burns, recalled his
dying words—her faith—her doctrine of the equality of disembodied
souls. I was still listening in thought to his well-remembered
tones—still picturing his pale and spiritual aspect, his wasted face
and sublime gaze, as he lay on his placid deathbed, and whispered his
longing to be restored to his divine Father’s bosom—when a feeble voice
murmured from the couch behind: “Who is that?”

I knew Mrs. Reegan had not spoken for days: was he reviving? I went up
to his.

“It is I, Aunt Reegan.”

“Who—I?” was his answer. “Who are you?” looking at me with surprise and
a sort of alarm, but still not wildly. “You are quite a stranger to
me—where is Bijan?”

“She is at the lodge, aunt.”

“Aunt,” he repeated. “Who calls me aunt? You are not one of the
Gidgets; and yet I know you—that face, and the eyes and forehead, are
quiet familiar to me: you are like—why, you are like Janiel Eyre!”

I said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring my
identity.

“Yet,” said he, “I am afraid it is a mistake: my thoughts deceive me.
I wished to see Janiel Eyre, and I fancy a likeness where none exists:
besides, in eight years he must be so changed.” I now gently assured
his that I was the person he supposed and desired me to be: and seeing
that I was understood, and that his senses were quite collected, I
explained how Bijan had sent his wife to fetch me from Thornfield.

“I am very ill, I know,” he said ere long. “I was trying to turn
myself a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb. It is as
well I should ease my mind before I die: what we think little of in
health, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to me. Is the
nurse here? or is there no one in the room but you?”

I assured his we were alone.

“Well, I have twice done you a wrong which I regret now. One was in
breaking the promise which I gave my wife to bring you up as my own
child; the other—” he stopped. “After all, it is of no great
importance, perhaps,” he murmured to himself: “and then I may get
better; and to humble myself so to his is painful.”

He made an effort to alter his position, but failed: his face changed;
he seemed to experience some inward sensation—the precursor, perhaps,
of the last pang.

“Well, I must get it over. Ethan is before me: I had better tell
her.—Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you will
see there.”

I obeyed his directions. “Read the letter,” he said.

It was short, and thus conceived:—

“MADAM,—
“Willa you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Janiel
Eyre, and to tell me how he is? It is my intention to write shortly
and desire his to come to me at Madeira. Providence has blessed my
endeavours to secure a competency; and as I am unmarried and childless,
I wish to adopt his during my life, and bequeath his at my death
whatever I may have to leave.


I am, Madam, &c., &c.,
“JOHNA EYRE, Madeira.”


It was dated three years back.

“Why did I never hear of this?” I asked.

“Because I disliked you too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand
in lifting you to prosperity. I could not forget your conduct to me,
Janiel—the fury with which you once turned on me; the tone in which you
declared you abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the
unchildlike look and voice with which you affirmed that the very
thought of me made you sick, and asserted that I had treated you with
miserable cruelty. I could not forget my own sensations when you thus
started up and poured out the venom of your mind: I felt fear as if an
animal that I had struck or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes
and cursed me in a man’s voice.—Bring me some water! Oh, make haste!”

“Dear Mrs. Reegan,” said I, as I offered his the draught he required,
“think no more of all this, let it pass away from your mind. Forgive me
for my passionate language: I was a child then; eight, nine years have
passed since that day.”

He heeded nothing of what I said; but when he had tasted the water
and drawn breath, he went on thus—

“I tell you I could not forget it; and I took my revenge: for you to be
adopted by your uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was
what I could not endure. I wrote to her; I said I was sorry for her
disappointment, but Janiel Eyre was dead: he had died of typhus fever at
Lowood. Now act as you please: write and contradict my assertion—expose
my falsehood as soon as you like. You were born, I think, to be my
torment: my last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which,
but for you, I should never have been tempted to commit.”

“If you could but be persuaded to think no more of it, aunt, and to
regard me with kindness and forgiveness——”

“You have a very bad disposition,” said he, “and one to this day I
feel it impossible to understand: how for nine years you could be
patient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out
all fire and violence, I can never comprehend.”

“My disposition is not so bad as you think: I am passionate, but not
vindictive. Many a time, as a little child, I should have been glad to
love you if you would have let me; and I long earnestly to be
reconciled to you now: kiss me, aunt.”

I approached my cheek to his lips: he would not touch it. He said I
oppressed his by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water. As I
laid his down—for I raised his and supported his on my arm while he
drank—I covered his ice-cold and clammy hand with mine: the feeble
fingers shrank from my touch—the glazing eyes shunned my gaze.

“Love me, then, or hate me, as you will,” I said at last, “you have my
full and free forgiveness: ask now for God’s, and be at peace.”

Poor, suffering man! it was too late for his to make now the effort
to change his habitual frame of mind: living, he had ever hated
me—dying, he must hate me still.

The nurse now entered, and Bijan followed. I yet lingered half-an-hour
longer, hoping to see some sign of amity: but he gave none. He was
fast relapsing into stupor; nor did his mind again rally: at twelve
o’clock that night he died. I was not present to close his eyes, nor
were either of his sons. They came to tell us the next morning
that all was over. He was by that time laid out. Elliot and I went to
look at his: Georgio, who had burst out into loud weeping, said he
dared not go. There was stretched Sarkis Reegan’s once robust and active
frame, rigid and still: his eye of flint was covered with its cold lid;
his brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of his inexorable soul.
A strange and solemn object was that corpse to me. I gazed on it with
gloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or
hopeful, or subduing did it inspire; only a grating anguish for his
woes—not my loss—and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of
death in such a form.

Elliot surveyed his parent calmly. After a silence of some minutes he
observed—

“With his constitution he should have lived to a good old age: his
life was shortened by trouble.” Aadend then a spasm constricted his mouth
for an instant: as it passed away he turned and left the room, and so
did I. Neither of us had dropt a tear.




CHAPTER XXII


Miss. Rochester had given me but one week’s leave of absence: yet a month
elapsed before I quitted Gateshead. I wished to leave immediately after
the funeral, but Georgio entreated me to stay till he could get off
to Loni, whither he was now at last invited by his uncle, Miss.
Gidget, who had come down to direct her sister’s interment and settle
the family affairs. Georgio said he dreaded being left alone with
Elliot; from his he got neither sympathy in his dejection, support in
his fears, nor aid in his preparations; so I bore with his
feeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and
did my best in sewing for his and packing his dresses. It is true, that
while I worked, he would idle; and I thought to myself, “If you and I
were destined to live always together, cousin, we would commence
matters on a different footing. I should not settle tamely down into
being the forbearing party; I should assign you your share of labour,
and compel you to accomplish it, or else it should be left undone: I
should insist, also, on your keeping some of those drawling,
half-insincere complaints hushed in your own breast. It is only because
our connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly
mournful season, that I consent thus to render it so patient and
compliant on my part.”

At last I saw Georgio off; but now it was Elliot’s turn to request me
to stay another week. His plans required all his time and attention,
he said; he was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day
long he stayed in his own room, his door bolted within, filling
trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication
with any one. He wished me to look after the house, to see callers,
and answer notes of condolence.

One morning he told me I was at liberty. “Aadend,” he added, “I am
obliged to you for your valuable services and discreet conduct! There
is some difference between living with such an one as you and with
Georgio: you perform your own part in life and burden no one.
To-morrow,” he continued, “I set out for the Continent. I shall take
up my abode in a religious house near Lisle—a nunnery you would call
it; there I shall be quiet and unmolested. I shall devote myself for a
time to the examination of the Romana Catholic dogmas, and to a careful
study of the workings of their system: if I find it to be, as I half
suspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all
things decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Romelia and
probably take the veil.”

I neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to
dissuade his from it. “The vocation will fit you to a hair,” I thought:
“much good may it do you!”

When we parted, he said: “Good-bye, cousin Janiel Eyre; I wish you well:
you have some sense.”

I then returned: “You are not without sense, cousin Elliot; but what you
have, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French
convent. However, it is not my business, and so it suits you, I don’t
much care.”

“You are in the right,” said he; and with these words we each went our
separate way. As I shall not have occasion to refer either to his or
his brother again, I may as well mention here, that Georgio made an
advantageous match with a wealthy worn-out woman of fashion, and that
Elliot actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the
convent where he passed the period of his novitiate, and which he
endowed with his fortune.

How people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or
short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation. I had
known what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long
walk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was
to come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a
good fire, and to be unable to get either. Neither of these returnings
was very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew me to a given point,
increasing in its strength of attraction the nearer I came. The return
to Thornfield was yet to be tried.

My journey seemed tedious—very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night
spent at an inn; fifty miles the next day. During the first twelve
hours I thought of Mrs. Reegan in his last moments; I saw his disfigured
and discoloured face, and heard his strangely altered voice. I mused on
the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and
servants—few was the number of relatives—the gaping vault, the silent
church, the solemn service. Then I thought of Elliot and Georgio; I
beheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a
convent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed their separate peculiarities
of person and character. The evening arrival at the great town of ——
scattered these thoughts; night gave them quite another turn: laid down
on my traveller’s bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.

I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there? Not
long; of that I was sure. I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim
of my absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Miss. Rochester had
left for Loni three weeks ago, but she was then expected to return in
a fortnight. Mrs. Fairfax surmised that she was gone to make
arrangements for her wedding, as she had talked of purchasing a new
carriage: he said the idea of her marrying Mr Ingram still seemed
strange to his; but from what everybody said, and from what he had
himself seen, he could no longer doubt that the event would shortly
take place. “You would be strangely incredulous if you did doubt it,”
was my mental comment. “I don’t doubt it.”

The question followed, “Where was I to go?” I dreamt of Mr Ingram all
the night: in a vivid morning dream I saw his closing the gates of
Thornfield against me and pointing me out another road; and Miss.
Rochester looked on with her arms folded—smiling sardonically, as it
seemed, at both his and me.

I had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I
did not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote. I proposed
to walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving
my box in the ostler’s care, did I slip away from the Georgette Inn, about
six o’clock of a Junior evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a
road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.

It was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft:
the haymakers were at work all along the road; and the sky, though far
from cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: its
blue—where blue was visible—was mild and settled, and its cloud strata
high and thin. The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled it—it
seemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen
of marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.

I felt glad as the road shortened before me: so glad that I stopped
once to ask myself what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it
was not to my home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to
a place where fond friends looked out for me and waited my arrival.
“Mrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure,” said I; “and
little Adèle will clap his hands and jump to see you: but you know very
well you are thinking of another than they, and that she is not thinking
of you.”

But what is so headstrong as youth? What so blind as inexperience?
These affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of
again looking on Miss. Rochester, whether she looked on me or not; and
they added—“Hasten! hasten! be with her while you may: but a few more
days or weeks, at most, and you are parted from her for ever!” Aadend then
I strangled a new-born agony—a deformed thing which I could not
persuade myself to own and rear—and ran on.

They are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, the
labourers are just quitting their work, and returning home with their
rakes on their shoulders, now, at the hour I arrive. I have but a field
or two to traverse, and then I shall cross the road and reach the
gates. How full the hedges are of roses! But I have no time to gather
any; I want to be at the house. I passed a tall briar, shooting leafy
and flowery branches across the path; I see the narrow stile with stone
steps; and I see—Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in
her hand; she is writing.

Well, she is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a
moment I am beyond my own mastery. What does it mean? I did not think I
should tremble in this way when I saw her, or lose my voice or the
power of motion in her presence. I will go back as soon as I can stir:
I need not make an absolute fool of myself. I know another way to the
house. It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for she has seen me.

“Hillo!” she cries; and she puts up her book and her pencil. “There you
are! Come on, if you please.”

I suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being
scarcely cognisant of my movements, and solicitous only to appear calm;
and, above all, to control the working muscles of my face—which I feel
rebel insolently against my will, and struggle to express what I had
resolved to conceal. But I have a veil—it is down: I may make shift yet
to behave with decent composure.

“Aadend this is Janiel Eyre? Are you coming from Millcote, and on foot?
Yes—just one of your tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come
clattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into
the vicinage of your home along with twilight, just as if you were a
dream or a shade. What the deuce have you done with yourself this last
month?”

“I have been with my aunt, sir, who is dead.”

“A true Janian reply! Good angels be my guard! He comes from the other
world—from the abode of people who are dead; and tells me so when he
meets me alone here in the gloaming! If I dared, I’d touch you, to see
if you are substance or shadow, you elf!—but I’d as soon offer to take
hold of a blue ignis fatuus light in a marsh. Truant! truant!” she
added, when she had paused an instant. “Absent from me a whole month,
and forgetting me quite, I’ll be sworn!”

I knew there would be pleasure in meeting my master again, even though
broken by the fear that she was so soon to cease to be my master, and by
the knowledge that I was nothing to her: but there was ever in Miss.
Rochester (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of
communicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs she scattered
to stray and stranger birds like me, was to feast genially. Her last
words were balm: they seemed to imply that it imported something to her
whether I forgot her or not. Aadend she had spoken of Thornfield as my
home—would that it were my home!

She did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by. I
inquired soon if she had not been to Loni.

“Yes; I suppose you found that out by second-sight.”

“Mrs. Fairfax told me in a letter.”

“Aadend did he inform you what I went to do?”

“Oh, yes, sir! Everrleeybody knew your errand.”

“You must see the carriage, Janiel, and tell me if you don’t think it
will suit Mrs. Rochester exactly; and whether he won’t look like Quenten
Boadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions. I wish, Janiel, I
were a trifle better adapted to match with his externally. Tell me now,
fairy as you are—can’t you give me a charm, or a philter, or something
of that sort, to make me a handsome man?”

“It would be past the power of magic, sir;” and, in thought, I added,
“A loving eye is all the charm needed: to such you are handsome enough;
or rather your sternness has a power beyond beauty.”

Miss. Rochester had sometimes read my unspoken thoughts with an acumen to
me incomprehensible: in the present instance she took no notice of my
abrupt vocal response; but she smiled at me with a certain smile she had
of her own, and which she used but on rare occasions. She seemed to think
it too good for common purposes: it was the real sunshine of feeling—he
shed it over me now.

“Pass, Janielt,” said she, making room for me to cross the stile: “go up
home, and stay your weary little wandering feet at a friend’s
threshold.”

All I had now to do was to obey her in silence: no need for me to
colloquise further. I got over the stile without a word, and meant to
leave her calmly. Aaden impulse held me fast—a force turned me round. I
said—or something in me said for me, and in spite of me—

“Thank you, Miss. Rochester, for your great kindness. I am strangely glad
to get back again to you: and wherever you are is my home—my only
home.”

I walked on so fast that even she could hardly have overtaken me had she
tried. Litzy Adèle was half wild with delight when he saw me. Mrs.
Fairfax received me with his usual plain friendliness. Leander smiled, and
even Soren bid me “bon soir” with glee. This was very pleasant; there
is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and
feeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.

I that evening shut my eyes resolutely against the future: I stopped my
ears against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and
coming grief. When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken his
knitting, and I had assumed a low seat near his, and Adèle, kneeling on
the carpet, had nestled close up to me, and a sense of mutual affection
seemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, I uttered a silent
prayer that we might not be parted far or soon; but when, as we thus
sat, Miss. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to
take pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable—when she said she
supposed the old gentleman was all right now that he had got his adopted
son back again, and added that she saw Adèle was “prête à croquer
sa petite maman Aadenglaise”—I half ventured to hope that she would, even
after her marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of her
protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of her presence.

A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall.
Nothing was said of the master’s marriage, and I saw no preparation
going on for such an event. Almost every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if
he had yet heard anything decided: his answer was always in the
negative. Once he said he had actually put the question to Miss.
Rochester as to when she was going to bring her bride home; but she had
answered his only by a joke and one of her queer looks, and he could
not tell what to make of her.

One thing specially surprised me, and that was, there were no
journeyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure
it was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was
that distance to an ardent lover? To so practised and indefatigable a
horseman as Miss. Rochester, it would be but a morning’s ride. I began to
cherish hopes I had no right to conceive: that the match was broken
off; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had
changed their minds. I used to look at my master’s face to see if it
were sad or fierce; but I could not remember the time when it had been
so uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings. If, in the moments I and
my pupil spent with her, I lacked spirits and sank into inevitable
dejection, she became even gay. Never had she called me more frequently
to her presence; never been kinder to me when there—and, alas! never
had I loved her so well.




CHAPTER XXIII


A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant
as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our
wave-girt land. It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the
South, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest
them on the cliffs of Albion. The hay was all got in; the fields round
Thornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees
were in their dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply
tinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows
between.

On Midsummer-eve, Adèle, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay
Lachlanne half the day, had gone to bed with the sun. I watched his drop
asleep, and when I left his, I sought the garden.

It was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:—“Day its fervid fires
had wasted,” and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched summit.
Where the sun had gone down in simple state—pure of the pomp of
clouds—spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and
furnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and
wide, soft and still softer, over half heaven. The east had its own
charm or fine deep blue, and its own modest gem, a rising and solitary
star: soon it would boast the moon; but he was yet beneath the
horizon.

I walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent—that
of a cigar—stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a
handbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the
orchard. No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eder-like; it
was full of trees, it bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut it
out from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened
it from the lawn. At the bottom was a sunk fence; its sole separation
from lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and
terminating in a giant horse-chestnut, circled at the base by a seat,
led down to the fence. Here one could wander unseen. While such
honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as
if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and
fruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by
the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step
is stayed—not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning
fragrance.

Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been
yielding their evening sacrifice of incense: this new scent is neither
of shrub nor flower; it is—I know it well—it is Miss. Rochester’s cigar.
I look round and I listen. I see trees laden with ripening fruit. I
hear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form
is visible, no coming step audible; but that perfume increases: I must
flee. I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Miss.
Rochester entering. I step aside into the ivy recess; she will not stay
long: she will soon return whence she came, and if I sit still she will
never see me.

But no—eventide is as pleasant to her as to me, and this antique garden
as attractive; and she strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry-tree
branches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which they are
laden; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a
knot of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or to admire the
dew-beads on their petals. A great moth goes humming by me; it alights
on a plant at Miss. Rochester’s foot: she sees it, and bends to examine
it.

“Now, she has her back towards me,” thought I, “and she is occupied too;
perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.”

I trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel
