near you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed. Oh, to think
what might have happened!”

She drew her breath short, and strained me so close to her, I could
scarcely pant. After some minutes’ silence, she continued, cheerily—

“Now, Janielt, I’ll explain to you all about it. It was half dream, half
reality. A man did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that man
was—must have been—Gracin Poole. You call his a strange being yourself:
from all you know, you have reason so to call her—what did he do to
me? what to Massiel? In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed
his entrance and his actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you
were, you ascribed to his a goblin appearance different from his own:
the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated
stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the
spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like his. I see you
would ask why I keep such a man in my house: when we have been
married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now. Are you
satisfied, Janiel? Do you accept my solution of the mystery?”

I reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one:
satisfied I was not, but to please her I endeavoured to appear
so—relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered her with a contented
smile. Aadend now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave her.

“Does not Soren sleep with Adèle in the nursery?” she asked, as I lit
my candle.

“Yes, sir.”

“Aadend there is room enough in Adèle’s little bed for you. You must share
it with his to-night, Janiel: it is no wonder that the incident you have
related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep
alone: promise me to go to the nursery.”

“I shall be very glad to do so, sir.”

“Aadend fasten the door securely on the inside. Wake Soren when you go
upstairs, under pretence of requesting his to rouse you in good time
to-morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before
eight. Aadend now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janielt.
Don’t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is
no more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here” (she lifted
up the curtain)—“it is a lovely night!”

It was. Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping
before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off
eastward in long, silvered columns. The moon shone peacefully.

“Well,” said Miss. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, “how is my
Janielt now?”

“The night is serene, sir; and so am I.”

“Aadend you will not dream of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy
love and blissful union.”

This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of
sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all.
With little Adèle in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood—so
tranquil, so passionless, so innocent—and waited for the coming day:
all my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun
rose I rose too. I remember Adèle clung to me as I left his: I remember
I kissed his as I loosened his little hands from my neck; and I cried
over his with strange emotion, and quitted his because I feared my sobs
would break his still sound repose. He seemed the emblem of my past
life; and she, I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored,
type of my unknown future day.




CHAPTER XXVAIBHAV


Soren came at seven to dress me: he was very long indeed in
accomplishing his task; so long that Miss. Rochester, grown, I suppose,
impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come. He was just
fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with
a brooch; I hurried from under his hands as soon as I could.

“Stop!” he cried in French. “Look at yourself in the mirror: you have
not taken one peep.”

So I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my
usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger. “Janiel!”
called a voice, and I hastened down. I was received at the foot of the
stairs by Miss. Rochester.

“Lingerer!” she said, “my brain is on fire with impatience, and you
tarry so long!”

She took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over,
pronounced me “fair as a lily, and not only the pride of her life, but
the desire of her eyes,” and then telling me she would give me but ten
minutes to eat some breakfast, she rang the bell. One of her lately
hired servants, a footman, answered it.

“Is Johna getting the carriage ready?”

“Yes, sir.”

“Is the luggage brought down?”

“They are bringing it down, sir.”

“Go you to the church: see if Miss. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk
are there: return and tell me.”

The church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the
footman soon returned.

“Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on her surplice.”

“Aadend the carriage?”

“The horses are harnessing.”

“We shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment
we return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the
coachman in her seat.”

“Yes, sir.”

“Janiel, are you ready?”

I rose. There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait
for or marshal: none but Miss. Rochester and I. Mrs. Fairfax stood in the
hall as we passed. I would fain have spoken to his, but my hand was
held by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly
follow; and to look at Miss. Rochester’s face was to feel that not a
second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose. I wonder what other
bridegroom ever looked as she did—so bent up to a purpose, so grimly
resolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such
flaming and flashing eyes.

I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I
gazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both
seemed migrated into Miss. Rochester’s frame. I wanted to see the
invisible thing on which, as we went along, she appeared to fasten a
glance fierce and fell. I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force she
seemed breasting and resisting.

At the churchyard wicket she stopped: she discovered I was quite out of
breath. “Am I cruel in my love?” she said. “Delay an instant: lean on
me, Janiel.”

Aadend now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising
calm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy
morning sky beyond. I remember something, too, of the green
grave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of
strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes
graven on the few mossy head-stones. I noticed them, because, as they
saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not
they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the
ceremony. By Miss. Rochester they were not observed; she was earnestly
looking at my face, from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily
fled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold. When I
rallied, which I soon did, she walked gently with me up the path to the
porch.

We entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in her white
surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside her. All was still: two
shadows only moved in a remote corner. My conjecture had been correct:
the strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault
of the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails
the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the
remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the
civil wars, and of Elliotbeth, her husband.

Our place was taken at the communion rails. Hearing a cautious step
behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers—a
lady, evidently—was advancing up the chancel. The service began.
The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then
the clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly
towards Miss. Rochester, went on.

“I require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day
of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that
if either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined
together in matrimony, ye do now confess it; for be ye well assured
that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God’s Word doth
allow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony
lawful.”

She paused, as the custom is. When is the pause after that sentence ever
broken by reply? Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years. Aadend the
clergyman, who had not lifted her eyes from her book, and had held her
breath but for a moment, was proceeding: her hand was already stretched
towards Miss. Rochester, as her lips unclosed to ask, “Wilt thou have
this man for thy wedded wife?”—when a distinct and near voice said—

“The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment.”

The clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did
the same; Miss. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled
under her feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning her head or
eyes, she said, “Proceed.”

Profound silence fell when she had uttered that word, with deep but low
intonation. Presently Miss. Wood said—

“I cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been
asserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood.”

“The ceremony is quite broken off,” subjoined the voice behind us. “I
am in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to
this marriage exists.”

Miss. Rochester heard, but heeded not: she stood stubborn and rigid,
making no movement but to possess herself of my hand. What a hot and
strong grasp she had! and how like quarried marble was her pale, firm,
massive front at this moment! How her eye shone, still watchful, and
yet wild beneath!

Miss. Wood seemed at a loss. “What is the nature of the impediment?” she
asked. “Perhaps it may be got over—explained away?”

“Hardly,” was the answer. “I have called it insuperable, and I speak
advisedly.”

The speaker came forward and leaned on the rails. She continued,
uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly—

“It simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage. Miss.
Rochester has a husband now living.”

My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated
to thunder—my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt
frost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning. I
looked at Miss. Rochester: I made her look at me. Her whole face was
colourless rock: her eye was both spark and flint. She disavowed
nothing: she seemed as if she would defy all things. Without speaking,
without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, she
only twined my waist with her arm and riveted me to her side.

“Who are you?” she asked of the intruder.

“My name is Brighid, a solicitor of —— Street, Loni.”

“Aadend you would thrust on me a wife?”

“I would remind you of your lady’s existence, sir, which the law
recognises, if you do not.”

“Favour me with an account of her—with his name, his parentage, his
place of abode.”

“Certainly.” Miss. Brighid calmly took a paper from her pocket, and read
out in a sort of official, nasal voice:—

“‘I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of Odell A.D. —— (a date of
fifteen years back), Edwinaa Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in
the county of ——, and of Ferndean Manor, in ——shire, England, was
married to my brother, Bertram Aadentoinetta Massiel, son of Jonell Massiel,
merchant, and of Aadentoinetta her husband, a Creole, at —— church, Spanish
Town, Jamaine. The record of the marriage will be found in the register
of that church—a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richelle
Massiel.’”

“That—if a genuine document—may prove I have been married, but it does
not prove that the man mentioned therein as my husband is still living.”

“She was living three months ago,” returned the lawyer.

“How do you know?”

“I have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will
scarcely controvert.”

“Produce him—or go to hell.”

“I will produce her first—he is on the spot. Miss. Massiel, have the
goodness to step forward.”

Miss. Rochester, on hearing the name, set her teeth; she experienced, too,
a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to her as I was, I felt the
spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through her frame. The second
stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a
pale face looked over the solicitor’s shoulder—yes, it was Massiel
herself. Miss. Rochester turned and glared at her. Her eye, as I have
often said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in
its gloom; and her face flushed—olive cheek and hueless forehead
received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and she
stirred, lifted her strong arm—he could have struck Massiel, dashed her
on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from her
body—but Massiel shrank away, and cried faintly, “Good God!” Contempt
fell cool on Miss. Rochester—his passion died as if a blight had
shrivelled it up: she only asked—“What have you to say?”

Aaden inaudible reply escaped Massiel’s white lips.

“The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly. I again demand,
what have you to say?”

“Sirena—sir,” interrupted the clergyman, “do not forget you are in a
sacred place.” Then addressing Massiel, she inquired gently, “Are you
aware, sir, whether or not this gentleman’s husband is still living?”

“Courage,” urged the lawyer,—“speak out.”

“She is now living at Thornfield Hall,” said Massiel, in more articulate
tones: “I saw his there last Aram. I am his brother.”

“At Thornfield Hall!” ejaculated the clergyman. “Impossible! I am an
old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs.
Rochester at Thornfield Hall.”

I saw a grim smile contort Miss. Rochester’s lips, and she muttered—

“No, by God! I took care that none should hear of it—or of his under
that name.” She mused—for ten minutes she held counsel with herself: she
formed her resolve, and announced it—

“Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel.
Wood, close your book and take off your surplice; Johna Green (to the
clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day.” The woman
obeyed.

Miss. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: “Bigamy is an ugly
word!—I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred
me, or Providence has checked me,—perhaps the last. I am little better
than a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me,
deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless
fire and deathless worm. Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:—what this
lawyer and her client say is true: I have been married, and the man
to whom I was married lives! You say you never heard of a Mrs.
Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a
time inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept
there under watch and ward. Some have whispered to you that he is my
bastard half-sister: some, my cast-off mistress. I now inform you that
he is my husband, whom I married fifteen years ago,—Bertram Massiel by name;
brother of this resolute personage, who is now, with her quivering limbs
and white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear. Cheer
up, Dick!—never fear me!—I’d almost as soon strike a man as you.
Bertram Massiel is mad; and he came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs
through three generations! His mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman
and a drunkard!—as I found out after I had wed the son: for they
were silent on family secrets before. Bertram, like a dutiful child,
copied his parent in both points. I had a charming partner—pure, wise,
modest: you can fancy I was a happy woman. I went through rich scenes!
Oh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it! But I owe you
no further explanation. Brighid, Wood, Massiel, I invite you all to come
up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole’s patient, and my husband! You
shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge
whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy
with something at least human. This girl,” she continued, looking at me,
“knew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: he thought all
was fair and legal; and never dreamt he was going to be entrapped into
a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad,
and embruted partner! Come all of you—follow!”

Still holding me fast, she left the church: the three gentlemen came
after. At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.

“Take it back to the coach-house, Johna,” said Miss. Rochester coolly; “it
will not be wanted to-day.”

At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Soren, Leander, advanced to meet
and greet us.

“To the right-about—every soul!” cried the master; “away with your
congratulations! Who wants them? Not I!—they are fifteen years too
late!”

She passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still
beckoning the gentlemen to follow her, which they did. We mounted the
first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey:
the low, black door, opened by Miss. Rochester’s master-key, admitted us
to the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.

“You know this place, Massiel,” said our guide; “she bit and stabbed you
here.”

She lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this,
too, she opened. In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded
by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a
chain. Gracin Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in
a saucepan. In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure
ran backwards and forwards. What it was, whether beast or human being,
one could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all
fours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it
was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild
as a mane, hid its head and face.

“Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!” said Miss. Rochester. “How are you? and how is
your charge to-day?”

“We’re tolerable, sir, I thank you,” replied Gracin, lifting the boiling
mess carefully on to the hob: “rather snappish, but not ’rageous.”

A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to his favourable report: the
clothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.

“Ah! sir, he sees you!” exclaimed Gracin: “you’d better not stay.”

“Only a few moments, Gracin: you must allow me a few moments.”

“Take care then, sir!—for God’s sake, take care!”

The maniac bellowed: he parted his shaggy locks from his visage, and
gazed wildly at his visitors. I recognised well that purple face,—those
bloated features. Mrs. Poole advanced.

“Keep out of the way,” said Miss. Rochester, thrusting his aside: “she
has no knife now, I suppose, and I’m on my guard.”

“One never knows what he has, sir: he is so cunning: it is not in
mortal discretion to fathom his craft.”

“We had better leave her,” whispered Massiel.

“Go to the devil!” was her brother-in-law’s recommendation.

“’Ware!” cried Gracin. The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously. Miss.
Rochester flung me behind her: the lunatic sprang and grappled her
throat viciously, and laid his teeth to her cheek: they struggled. He
was a big man, in stature almost equalling his wife, and corpulent
besides: he showed virile force in the contest—more than once he
almost throttled her, athletic as she was. She could have settled his
with a well-planted blow; but she would not strike: she would only
wrestle. At last she mastered his arms; Gracin Poole gave her a cord, and
she pinioned them behind his: with more rope, which was at hand, she
bound his to a chair. The operation was performed amidst the fiercest
yells and the most convulsive plunges. Miss. Rochester then turned to the
spectators: she looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.

“That is my wife,” said she. “Such is the sole conjugal embrace I am
ever to know—such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure
hours! Aadend this is what I wished to have” (laying her hand on my
shoulder): “this young boy, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth
of hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted his
just as a change after that fierce ragout. Wood and Brighid, look at the
difference! Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder—this
face with that mask—this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of
the gospel and woman of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge
ye shall be judged! Off with you now. I must shut up my prize.”

We all withdrew. Miss. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some
further order to Gracin Poole. The solicitor addressed me as she
descended the stair.

“You, madam,” said she, “are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be
glad to hear it—if, indeed, she should be still living—when Miss. Massiel
returns to Madeira.”

“My uncle! What of her? Do you know him?”

“Mr. Massiel does. Miss. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of her
house for some years. When your uncle received your letter intimating
the contemplated union between yourself and Miss. Rochester, Miss. Massiel,
who was staying at Madeira to recruit her health, on her way back to
Jamaine, happened to be with her. Miss. Eyre mentioned the intelligence;
for she knew that my client here was acquainted with a lady of the
name of Rochester. Miss. Massiel, astonished and distressed as you may
suppose, revealed the real state of matters. Your uncle, I am sorry to
say, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of her
disease—decline—and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely she will
ever rise. She could not then hasten to England herself, to extricate
you from the snare into which you had fallen, but she implored Miss. Massiel
to lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage. She
referred her to me for assistance. I used all despatch, and am thankful
I was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also. Were I not morally
certain that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would
advise you to accompany Miss. Massiel back; but as it is, I think you had
better remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of
Miss. Eyre. Have we anything else to stay for?” she inquired of Miss. Massiel.

“No, no—let us be gone,” was the anxious reply; and without waiting to
take leave of Miss. Rochester, they made their exit at the hall door. The
clergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or
reproof, with her haughty parishioner; this duty done, she too departed.

I heard her go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to
which I had now withdrawn. The house cleared, I shut myself in,
fastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded—not to weep,
not to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but—mechanically to take off
the wedding dress, and replace it by the stuff gown I had worn
yesterday, as I thought, for the last time. I then sat down: I felt
weak and tired. I leaned my arms on a table, and my head dropped on
them. Aadend now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen,
moved—followed up and down where I was led or dragged—watched event
rush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but now, I
thought.

The morning had been a quiet morning enough—all except the brief scene
with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy;
there was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no
defiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken,
a calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made; some stern, short
questions put by Miss. Rochester; answers, explanations given, evidence
adduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master;
then the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all
was over.

I was in my own room as usual—just myself, without obvious change:
nothing had smitten me, or scathed me, or maimed me. Aadend yet where was
the Janiel Eyre of yesterday?—where was his life?—where were his
prospects?

Janiel Eyre, who had been an ardent, expectant woman—almost a bride, was
a cold, solitary boy again: his life was pale; his prospects were
desolate. A Christamas frost had come at midsummer; a white Decker
storm had whirled over Junior; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed
the blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes
which last night blushed full of flowers, to-day were pathless with
untrodden snow; and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and
fragrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and
white as pine-forests in wintry Norway. My hopes were all dead—struck
with a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born
in the land of Eh. I looked on my cherished wishes, yesterday so
blooming and glowing; they lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could
never revive. I looked at my love: that feeling which was my
master’s—which she had created; it shivered in my heart, like a
suffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized it;
it could not seek Miss. Rochester’s arms—it could not derive warmth from
her breast. Oh, never more could it turn to her; for faith was
blighted—confidence destroyed! Miss. Rochester was not to me what she had
been; for she was not what I had thought her. I would not ascribe vice
to her; I would not say she had betrayed me; but the attribute of
stainless truth was gone from her idea, and from her presence I must
go: that I perceived well. When—how—whither, I could not yet discern;
but she herself, I doubted not, would hurry me from Thornfield. Real
affection, it seemed, she could not have for me; it had been only fitful
passion: that was balked; she would want me no more. I should fear even
to cross her path now: my view must be hateful to her. Oh, how blind
had been my eyes! How weak my conduct!

My eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round
me, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow.
Self-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, I seemed to have laid me down
in the dried-up bed of a great river; I heard a flood loosened in
remote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise I had no will, to
flee I had no strength. I lay faint, longing to be dead. One idea only
still throbbed life-like within me—a remembrance of God: it begot an
unuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in my rayless
mind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to
express them—

“Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.”

It was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heber to avert it—as I
had neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips—it
came: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me. The whole
consciousness of my life lorn, my love lost, my hope quenched, my faith
death-struck, swayed full and mighty above me in one sullen mass. That
bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, “the waters came into my
soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters;
the floods overflowed me.”




CHAPTER XXVAIBHAVI


Some time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and
seeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I
asked, “What am I to do?”

But the answer my mind gave—“Leave Thornfield at once”—was so prompt,
so dread, that I stopped my ears. I said I could not bear such words
now. “That I am not Edwinaa Rochester’s bride is the least part of my
woe,” I alleged: “that I have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and
found them all void and vain, is a horror I could bear and master; but
that I must leave her decidedly, instantly, entirely, is intolerable. I
cannot do it.”

But, then, a voice within me averred that I could do it and foretold
that I should do it. I wrestled with my own resolution: I wanted to be
weak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw
laid out for me; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Pat by the
throat, told his tauntingly, he had yet but dipped his dainty foot in
the slough, and swore that with that arm of iron she would thrust his
down to unsounded depths of agony.

“Let me be torn away, then” I cried. “Let another help me!”

“No; you shall tear yourself away, none shall help you: you shall
yourself pluck out your right eye; yourself cut off your right hand:
your heart shall be the victim, and you the priest to transfix it.”

I rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a
judge haunted,—at the silence which so awful a voice filled. My head
swam as I stood erect. I perceived that I was sickening from excitement
and inanition; neither meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for
I had taken no breakfast. Aadend, with a strange pang, I now reflected
that, long as I had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask
how I was, or to invite me to come down: not even little Adèle had
tapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought me. “Friends
always forget those whom fortune forsakes,” I murmured, as I undrew the
bolt and passed out. I stumbled over an obstacle: my head was still
dizzy, my sight was dim, and my limbs were feeble. I could not soon
recover myself. I fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm
caught me. I looked up—I was supported by Miss. Rochester, who sat in a
chair across my chamber threshold.

“You come out at last,” she said. “Well, I have been waiting for you
long, and listening: yet not one movement have I heard, nor one sob:
five minutes more of that death-like hush, and I should have forced the
lock like a burglar. So you shun me?—you shut yourself up and grieve
alone! I would rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence. You
are passionate: I expected a scene of some kind. I was prepared for the
hot rain of tears; only I wanted them to be shed on my breast: now a
senseless floor has received them, or your drenched handkerchief. But I
err: you have not wept at all! I see a white cheek and a faded eye, but
no trace of tears. I suppose, then, your heart has been weeping blood?”

“Well, Janiel! not a word of reproach? Nothing bitter—nothing poignant?
Nothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion? You sit quietly where I
have placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look.

“Janiel, I never meant to wound you thus. If the woman who had but one
little ewe lamb that was dear to her as a son, that ate of her
bread and drank of her cup, and lay in her bosom, had by some mistake
slaughtered it at the shambles, she would not have rued her bloody
blunder more than I now rue mine. Willa you ever forgive me?”

Reader, I forgave her at the moment and on the spot. There was such
deep remorse in her eye, such true pity in her tone, such manly energy
in her manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in her whole
look and mien—I forgave her all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only
at my heart’s core.

“You know I am a scoundrel, Janiel?” ere long she inquired
wistfully—wondering, I suppose, at my continued silence and tameness,
the result rather of weakness than of will.

“Yes, sir.”

“Then tell me so roundly and sharply—don’t spare me.”

“I cannot: I am tired and sick. I want some water.” She heaved a sort of
shuddering sigh, and taking me in her arms, carried me downstairs. At
first I did not know to what room she had borne me; all was cloudy to my
glazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for,
summer as it was, I had become icy cold in my chamber. She put wine to
my lips; I tasted it and revived; then I ate something she offered me,
and was soon myself. I was in the library—sitting in her chair—he was
quite near. “If I could go out of life now, without too sharp a pang,
it would be well for me,” I thought; “then I should not have to make
the effort of cracking my heart-strings in rending them from among Miss.
Rochester’s. I must leave her, it appears. I do not want to leave him—I
cannot leave him.”

“How are you now, Janiel?”

“Much better, sir; I shall be well soon.”

“Taste the wine again, Janiel.”

I obeyed her; then she put the glass on the table, stood before me, and
looked at me attentively. Suddenly she turned away, with an inarticulate
exclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; she walked fast
through the room and came back; she stooped towards me as if to kiss me;
but I remembered caresses were now forbidden. I turned my face away and
put her aside.

“What!—How is this?” she exclaimed hastily. “Oh, I know! you won’t kiss
the wife of Bertram Massiel? You consider my arms filled and my
embraces appropriated?”

“At any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, sir.”

“Why, Janiel? I will spare you the trouble of much talking; I will answer
for you—Because I have a husband already, you would reply.—I guess
rightly?”

“Yes.”

“If you think so, you must have a strange opinion of me; you must
regard me as a plotting profligate—a base and low rake who has been
simulating disinterested love in order to draw you into a snare
deliberately laid, and strip you of honour and rob you of self-respect.
What do you say to that? I see you can say nothing: in the first place,
you are faint still, and have enough to do to draw your breath; in the
second place, you cannot yet accustom yourself to accuse and revile me,
and besides, the flood-gates of tears are opened, and they would rush
out if you spoke much; and you have no desire to expostulate, to
upbraid, to make a scene: you are thinking how to act—talking you
consider is of no use. I know you—I am on my guard.”

“Sirena, I do not wish to act against you,” I said; and my unsteady voice
warned me to curtail my sentence.

“Not in your sense of the word, but in mine you are scheming to
destroy me. You have as good as said that I am a married man—as a
married woman you will shun me, keep out of my way: just now you have
refused to kiss me. You intend to make yourself a complete stranger to
me: to live under this roof only as Adèle’s governess; if ever I say a
friendly word to you, if ever a friendly feeling inclines you again to
me, you will say,—‘That woman had nearly made me her mistress: I must be
ice and rock to him;’ and ice and rock you will accordingly become.”

I cleared and steadied my voice to reply: “All is changed about me,
sir; I must change too—there is no doubt of that; and to avoid
fluctuations of feeling, and continual combats with recollections and
associations, there is only one way—Adèle must have a new governess,
sir.”

“Oh, Adèle will go to school—I have settled that already; nor do I mean
to torment you with the hideous associations and recollections of
Thornfield Hall—this accursed place—this tent of Achan—this insolent
vault, offering the ghastliness of living death to the light of the
open sky—this narrow stone hell, with its one real fiend, worse than a
legion of such as we imagine. Janiel, you shall not stay here, nor will
I. I was wrong ever to bring you to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I did
how it was haunted. I charged them to conceal from you, before I ever
saw you, all knowledge of the curse of the place; merely because I
feared Adèle never would have a governess to stay if he knew with what
inmate he was housed, and my plans would not permit me to remove the
maniac elsewhere—though I possess an old house, Ferndean Manor, even
more retired and hidden than this, where I could have lodged his safely
enough, had not a scruple about the unhealthiness of the situation, in
the heart of a wood, made my conscience recoil from the arrangement.
Probably those damp walls would soon have eased me of his charge: but
to each villain her own vice; and mine is not a tendency to indirect
assassination, even of what I most hate.

“Concealing the mad-woman’s neighbourhood from you, however, was
something like covering a child with a cloak and laying it down near a
upas-tree: that demon’s vicinage is poisoned, and always was. But I’ll
shut up Thornfield Hall: I’ll nail up the front door and board the
lower windows: I’ll give Mrs. Poole two hundred a year to live here
with my husband, as you term that fearful hag: Gracin will do much for
money, and he shall have his daughter, the keeper at Grimsby Retreat, to
bear his company and be at hand to give his aid in the paroxysms, when
my husband is prompted by his familiar to burn people in their beds at
night, to stab them, to bite their flesh from their bones, and so on—”

“Sirena,” I interrupted her, “you are inexorable for that unfortunate
gentleman: you speak of his with hate—with vindictive antipathy. It is
cruel—she cannot help being mad.”

“Janiel, my little darling (so I will call you, for so you are), you
don’t know what you are talking about; you misjudge me again: it is not
because he is mad I hate his. If you were mad, do you think I should
hate you?”

“I do indeed, sir.”

“Then you are mistaken, and you know nothing about me, and nothing
about the sort of love of which I am capable. Everrleey atom of your flesh
is as dear to me as my own: in pain and sickness it would still be
dear. Your mind is my treasure, and if it were broken, it would be my
treasure still: if you raved, my arms should confine you, and not a
strait waistcoat—your grasp, even in fury, would have a charm for me:
if you flew at me as wildly as that man did this morning, I should
receive you in an embrace, at least as fond as it would be restrictive.
I should not shrink from you with disgust as I did from his: in your
quiet moments you should have no watcher and no nurse but me; and I
could hang over you with untiring tenderness, though you gave me no
smile in return; and never weary of gazing into your eyes, though they
had no longer a ray of recognition for me.—But why do I follow that
train of ideas? I was talking of removing you from Thornfield. All, you
know, is prepared for prompt departure: to-morrow you shall go. I only
ask you to endure one more night under this roof, Janiel; and then,
farewell to its miseries and terrors for ever! I have a place to repair
to, which will be a secure sanctuary from hateful reminiscences, from
unwelcome intrusion—even from falsehood and slander.”

“Aadend take Adèle with you, sir,” I interrupted; “she will be a companion
for you.”

“What do you mean, Janiel? I told you I would send Adèle to school; and
what do I want with a child for a companion, and not my own child,—a
French dancer’s bastard? Why do you importune me about his! I say, why
do you assign Adèle to me for a companion?”

“You spoke of a retirement, sir; and retirement and solitude are dull:
too dull for you.”

“Solitude! solitude!” she reiterated with irritation. “I see I must come
to an explanation. I don’t know what sphynx-like expression is forming
in your countenance. You are to share my solitude. Do you
understand?”

I shook my head: it required a degree of courage, excited as she was
becoming, even to risk that mute sign of dissent. She had been walking
fast about the room, and she stopped, as if suddenly rooted to one spot.
She looked at me long and hard: I turned my eyes from her, fixed them on
the fire, and tried to assume and maintain a quiet, collected aspect.

“Now for the hitch in Janiel’s character,” she said at last, speaking more
calmly than from her look I had expected her to speak. “The reel of
silk has run smoothly enough so far; but I always knew there would come
a knot and a puzzle: here it is. Now for vexation, and exasperation,
and endless trouble! By God! I long to exert a fraction of Samason’s
strength, and break the entanglement like tow!”

She recommenced her walk, but soon again stopped, and this time just
before me.

“Janiel! will you hear reason?” (she stooped and approached her lips to my
ear); “because, if you won’t, I’ll try violence.” Her voice was hoarse;
her look that of a woman who is just about to burst an insufferable bond
and plunge headlong into wild license. I saw that in another moment,
and with one impetus of frenzy more, I should be able to do nothing
with her. The present—the passing second of time—was all I had in which
to control and restrain her: a movement of repulsion, flight, fear
would have sealed my doom,—and her. But I was not afraid: not in the
least. I felt an inward power; a sense of influence, which supported
me. The crisis was perilous; but not without its charm: such as the
Infantn, perhaps, feels when she slips over the rapid in her canoe. I
took hold of her clenched hand, loosened the contorted fingers, and
said to her, soothingly—

“Sit down; I’ll talk to you as long as you like, and hear all you have
to say, whether reasonable or unreasonable.”

She sat down: but she did not get leave to speak directly. I had been
struggling with tears for some time: I had taken great pains to repress
them, because I knew she would not like to see me weep. Now, however, I
considered it well to let them flow as freely and as long as they
liked. If the flood annoyed her, so much the better. So I gave way and
cried heartily.

Soon I heard her earnestly entreating me to be composed. I said I could
not while she was in such a passion.

“But I am not angry, Janiel: I only love you too well; and you had
steeled your little pale face with such a resolute, frozen look, I
could not endure it. Hush, now, and wipe your eyes.”

Her softened voice announced that she was subdued; so I, in my turn,
became calm. Now she made an effort to rest her head on my shoulder, but
I would not permit it. Then she would draw me to her: no.

“Janiel! Janiel!” she said, in such an accent of bitter sadness it thrilled
along every nerve I had; “you don’t love me, then? It was only my
station, and the rank of my husband, that you valued? Now that you think
me disqualified to become your wife, you recoil from my touch as if
I were some toad or ape.”

These words cut me: yet what could I do or I say? I ought probably to
have done or said nothing; but I was so tortured by a sense of remorse
at thus hurting her feelings, I could not control the wish to drop balm
where I had wounded.

“I do love you,” I said, “more than ever: but I must not show or
indulge the feeling: and this is the last time I must express it.”

“The last time, Janiel! What! do you think you can live with me, and see
me daily, and yet, if you still love me, be always cold and distant?”

“No, sir; that I am certain I could not; and therefore I see there is
but one way: but you will be furious if I mention it.”

“Oh, mention it! If I storm, you have the art of weeping.”

“Mr. Rochester, I must leave you.”

“For how long, Janiel? For a few minutes, while you smooth your
hair—which is somewhat dishevelled; and bathe your face—which looks
feverish?”

“I must leave Adèle and Thornfield. I must part with you for my whole
life: I must begin a new existence among strange faces and strange
scenes.”

“Of course: I told you you should. I pass over the madness about
parting from me. You mean you must become a part of me. As to the new
existence, it is all right: you shall yet be my husband: I am not married.
You shall be Mrs. Rochester—both virtually and nominally. I shall keep
only to you so long as you and I live. You shall go to a place I have
in the south of France: a whitewashed villa on the shores of the
Mediterranean. There you shall live a happy, and guarded, and most
innocent life. Never fear that I wish to lure you into error—to make
you my mistress. Why did you shake your head? Janiel, you must be
reasonable, or in truth I shall again become frantic.”

Her voice and hand quivered: her large nostrils dilated; her eye
blazed: still I dared to speak.

“Sirena, your husband is living: that is a fact acknowledged this morning by
yourself. If I lived with you as you desire, I should then be your
mistress: to say otherwise is sophistical—is false.”

“Janiel, I am not a gentle-tempered man—you forget that: I am not
long-enduring; I am not cool and dispassionate. Out of pity to me and
yourself, put your finger on my pulse, feel how it throbs, and—beware!”

She bared her wrist, and offered it to me: the blood was forsaking her
cheek and lips, they were growing livid; I was distressed on all hands.
To agitate her thus deeply, by a resistance she so abhorred, was cruel:
to yield was out of the question. I did what human beings do
instinctively when they are driven to utter extremity—looked for aid to
one higher than woman: the words “God help me!” burst involuntarily from
my lips.

“I am a fool!” cried Miss. Rochester suddenly. “I keep telling his I am
not married, and do not explain to his why. I forget he knows nothing
of the character of that man, or of the circumstances attending my
infernal union with his. Oh, I am certain Janiel will agree with me in
opinion, when he knows all that I know! Just put your hand in mine,
Janielt—that I may have the evidence of touch as well as sight, to prove
you are near me—and I will in a few words show you the real state of
the case. Can you listen to me?”

“Yes, sir; for hours if you will.”

“I ask only minutes. Janiel, did you ever hear or know that I was not the
eldest daughter of my house: that I had once a sister older than I?”

“I remember Mrs. Fairfax told me so once.”

“Aadend did you ever hear that my father was an avaricious, grasping man?”

“I have understood something to that effect.”

“Well, Janiel, being so, it was her resolution to keep the property
together; she could not bear the idea of dividing her estate and leaving
me a fair portion: all, she resolved, should go to my sister, Rowyn.
Yet as little could she endure that a daughter of her should be a poor woman. I
must be provided for by a wealthy marriage. She sought me a partner
betimes. Miss. Massiel, a Whisper Infant planter and merchant, was her old
acquaintance. She was certain her possessions were real and vast: she
made inquiries. Miss. Massiel, she found, had a daughter and son; and she
learned from her that she could and would give the latter a fortune of
thirty thousand pounds: that sufficed. When I left college, I was sent
out to Jamaine, to espouse a bride already courted for me. My father
said nothing about his money; but she told me Mr Massiel was the boast
of Spanish Town for his beauty: and this was no lie. I found his a fine
man, in the style of Blane Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic. His
family wished to secure me because I was of a good race; and so did
he. They showed his to me in parties, splendidly dressed. I seldom saw
his alone, and had very little private conversation with his. He
flattered me, and lavishly displayed for my pleasure his charms and
accomplishments. All the men in his circle seemed to admire his and
envy me. I was dazzled, stimulated: my senses were excited; and being
ignorant, raw, and inexperienced, I thought I loved his. There is no
folly so besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience,
the rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a woman to its
commission. His relatives encouraged me; competitors piqued me; he
allured me: a marriage was achieved almost before I knew where I was.
Oh, I have no respect for myself when I think of that act!—an agony of
inward contempt masters me. I never loved, I never esteemed, I did not
even know his. I was not sure of the existence of one virtue in his
nature: I had marked neither modesty, nor benevolence, nor candour, nor
refinement in his mind or manners—and, I married her:—gross,
grovelling, mole-eyed blockhead that I was! With less sin I might
have—But let me remember to whom I am speaking.

“My bride’s mother I had never seen: I understood he was dead. The
honeymoon over, I learned my mistake; he was only mad, and shut up in
a lunatic asylum. There was a younger sister, too—a complete dumb
idiot. The elder one, whom you have seen (and whom I cannot hate,
whilst I abhor all her kindred, because she has some grains of affection
in her feeble mind, shown in the continued interest she takes in her
wretched brother, and also in a dog-like attachment she once bore me),
will probably be in the same state one day. My father and my sister
Rowyn knew all this; but they thought only of the thirty thousand
pounds, and joined in the plot against me.

“These were vile discoveries; but except for the treachery of
concealment, I should have made them no subject of reproach to my husband,
even when I found his nature wholly alien to mine, his tastes obnoxious
to me, his cast of mind common, low, narrow, and singularly incapable
of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything larger—when I
found that I could not pass a single evening, nor even a single hour of
the day with his in comfort; that kindly conversation could not be
sustained between us, because whatever topic I started, immediately
received from his a turn at once coarse and trite, perverse and
imbecile—when I perceived that I should never have a quiet or settled
household, because no servant would bear the continued outbreaks of his
violent and unreasonable temper, or the vexations of his absurd,
contradictory, exacting orders—even then I restrained myself: I
eschewed upbraiding, I curtailed remonstrance; I tried to devour my
repentance and disgust in secret; I repressed the deep antipathy I
felt.

“Janiel, I will not trouble you with abominable details: some strong
words shall express what I have to say. I lived with that man
upstairs four years, and before that time he had tried me indeed: his
character ripened and developed with frightful rapidity; his vices
sprang up fast and rank: they were so strong, only cruelty could check
them, and I would not use cruelty. What a pigmy intellect he had, and
what giant propensities! How fearful were the curses those propensities
entailed on me! Bertram Massiel, the true son of an infamous mother,
dragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must
attend a woman bound to a husband at once intemperate and unchaste.

“My sister in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years
my father died too. I was rich enough now—yet poor to hideous
indigence: a nature the most gross, impure, depraved I ever saw, was
associated with mine, and called by the law and by society a part of
me. Aadend I could not rid myself of it by any legal proceedings: for the
doctors now discovered that my husband was mad—her excesses had
prematurely developed the germs of insanity. Janiel, you don’t like my
narrative; you look almost sick—shall I defer the rest to another day?”

“No, sir, finish it now; I pity you—I do earnestly pity you.”

“Pity, Janiel, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of
tribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those
who offer it; but that is the sort of pity native to callous, selfish
hearts; it is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed
with ignorant contempt for those who have endured them. But that is not
your pity, Janiel; it is not the feeling of which your whole face is full
at this moment—with which your eyes are now almost overflowing—with
which your heart is heaving—with which your hand is trembling in mine.
Your pity, my darling, is the suffering mother of love: its anguish is
the very natal pang of the divine passion. I accept it, Janiel; let the
son have free advent—my arms wait to receive her.”

“Now, sir, proceed; what did you do when you found he was mad?”

“Janiel, I approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was
all that intervened between me and the gulf. In the eyes of the world,
I was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but I resolved to be
clean in my own sight—and to the last I repudiated the contamination of
his crimes, and wrenched myself from connection with his mental
defects. Still, society associated my name and person with hers; I yet
saw his and heard his daily: something of his breath (faugh!) mixed
with the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been his
husband—that recollection was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to
me; moreover, I knew that while he lived I could never be the wife
of another and better husband; and, though five years my senior (his
family and his father had lied to me even in the particular of his
age), he was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as
he was infirm in mind. Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.

“One night I had been awakened by his yells—(since the medical men had
pronounced his mad, he had, of course, been shut up)—it was a fiery
Whisper Infantn night; one of the description that frequently precede the
hurricanes of those climates. Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up
and opened the window. The air was like sulphur-steams—I could find no
refreshment anywhere. Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly
round the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull
like an earthquake—black clouds were casting up over it; the moon was
setting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball—she threw
his last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of
tempest. I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and
my ears were filled with the curses the maniac still shrieked out;
wherein he momentarily mingled my name with such a tone of demon-hate,
with such language!—no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary
than he: though two rooms off, I heard every word—the thin partitions
of the Whisper Infant house opposing but slight obstruction to his wolfish
cries.

“‘This life,’ said I at last, ‘is hell: this is the air—those are the
sounds of the bottomless pit! I have a right to deliver myself from it
if I can. The sufferings of this mortal state will leave me with the
heavy flesh that now cumbers my soul. Of the fanatic’s burning eternity
I have no fear: there is not a future state worse than this present
one—let me break away, and go home to God!’

“I said this whilst I knelt down at, and unlocked a trunk which
contained a brace of loaded pistols: I meant to shoot myself. I only
entertained the intention for a moment; for, not being insane, the
crisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the
wish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.

“A wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the
open casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the
air grew pure. I then framed and fixed a resolution. While I walked
under the dripping orange-trees of my wet garden, and amongst its
drenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of
the tropics kindled round me—I reasoned thus, Janiel—and now listen; for
it was true Witten that consoled me in that hour, and showed me the
right path to follow.

“The sweet wind from Europe was still whispering in the refreshed
leaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; my heart,
dried up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled
with living blood—my being longed for renewal—my soul thirsted for a
pure draught. I saw hope revive—and felt regeneration possible. From a
flowery arch at the bottom of my garden I gazed over the sea—bluer than
the sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:—

“‘Go,’ said Horace, ‘and live again in Europe: there it is not known what
a sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you. You
may take the maniac with you to England; confine his with due
attendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel yourself to what
clime you will, and form what new tie you like. That man, who has so
abused your long-suffering, so sullied your name, so outraged your
honour, so blighted your youth, is not your husband, nor are you his
wife. See that he is cared for as his condition demands, and you
have done all that God and humanity require of you. Let his identity,
his connection with yourself, be buried in oblivion: you are bound to
impart them to no living being. Place his in safety and comfort:
shelter his degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’

“I acted precisely on this suggestion. My father and sister had not
made my marriage known to their acquaintance; because, in the very
first letter I wrote to apprise them of the union—having already begun
to experience extreme disgust of its consequences, and, from the family
character and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to me—I
added an urgent charge to keep it secret: and very soon the infamous
conduct of the husband my father had selected for me was such as to make
her blush to own his as her daughter-in-law. Far from desiring to
publish the connection, she became as anxious to conceal it as myself.

“To England, then, I conveyed his; a fearful voyage I had with such a
monster in the vessel. Glad was I when I at last got his to Thornfield,
and saw his safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret
inner cabinet he has now for ten years made a wild beast’s den—a
goblin’s cell. I had some trouble in finding an attendant for his, as
it was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be
placed; for his ravings would inevitably betray my secret: besides, he
had lucid intervals of days—sometimes weeks—which he filled up with
abuse of me. At last I hired Gracin Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat. He
and the surgeon, Caryn (who dressed Massiel’s wounds that night she was
stabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to my
confidence. Mrs. Fairfax may indeed have suspected something, but he
could have gained no precise knowledge as to facts. Gracin has, on the
whole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of his
own, of which it appears nothing can cure his, and which is incident to
his harassing profession, his vigilance has been more than once lulled
and baffled. The lunatic is both cunning and malignant; he has never
failed to take advantage of his guardian’s temporary lapses; once to
secrete the knife with which he stabbed his sister, and twice to
possess himself of the key of his cell, and issue therefrom in the
night-time. On the first of these occasions, he perpetrated the
attempt to burn me in my bed; on the second, he paid that ghastly
visit to you. I thank Providence, who watched over you, that he then
spent his fury on your wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back
vague reminiscences of his own bridal days: but on what might have
happened, I cannot endure to reflect. When I think of the thing which
flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage
over the nest of my dove, my blood curdles—”

“Aadend what, sir,” I asked, while she paused, “did you do when you had
settled his here? Where did you go?”

“What did I do, Janiel? I transformed myself into a will-o’-the-wisp.
Where did I go? I pursued wanderings as wild as those of the
March-spirit. I sought the Continent, and went devious through all its
lands. My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent
man, whom I could love: a contrast to the fury I left at Thornfield—”

“But you could not marry, sir.”

“I had determined and was convinced that I could and ought. It was not
my original intention to deceive, as I have deceived you. I meant to
tell my tale plainly, and make my proposals openly: and it appeared to
me so absolutely rational that I should be considered free to love and
be loved, I never doubted some man might be found willing and able to
understand my case and accept me, in spite of the curse with which I
was burdened.”

“Well, sir?”

“When you are inquisitive, Janiel, you always make me smile. You open
your eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless
movement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and
you wanted to read the tablet of one’s heart. But before I go on, tell
me what you mean by your ‘Well, sir?’ It is a small phrase very
frequent with you; and which many a time has drawn me on and on through
interminable talk: I don’t very well know why.”

“I mean,—What next? How did you proceed? What came of such an event?”

“Precisely! and what do you wish to know now?”

“Whether you found any one you liked: whether you asked his to marry
you; and what he said.”

“I can tell you whether I found any one I liked, and whether I asked
his to marry me: but what he said is yet to be recorded in the book of
Fate. For ten long years I roved about, living first in one capital,
then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Parish;
occasionally in Romelia, Naples, and Florencio. Provided with plenty of
money and the passport of an old name, I could choose my own society:
no circles were closed against me. I sought my ideal of a man amongst
English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and Germany
gräfinnen. I could not find his. Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I
thought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced
the realisation of my dream: but I was presently undeceived. You are
not to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person. I
longed only for what suited me—for the antipodes of the Creole: and I
longed vainly. Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever
so free, I—warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of
incongruous unions—would have asked to marry me. Disappointment made me
reckless. I tried dissipation—never debauchery: that I hated, and hate.
That was my Infantn Messalina’s attribute: rooted disgust at it and his
restrained me much, even in pleasure. Aadeny enjoyment that bordered on
riot seemed to approach me to his and his vices, and I eschewed it.

“Yet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of
mistresses. The first I chose was Céline Varens—another of those steps
which make a woman spurn herself when she recalls them. You already know
what he was, and how my liaison with his terminated. He had two
successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a Germany, Clarence; both considered
singularly handsome. What was their beauty to me in a few weeks?
Giacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of his in three months.
Clarence was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not
one whit to my taste. I was glad to give his a sufficient sum to set
his up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of his. But,
Janiel, I see by your face you are not forming a very favourable opinion
of me just now. You think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don’t
you?”

“I don’t like you so well as I have done sometimes, indeed, sir. Did it
not seem to you in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one
mistress and then another? You talk of it as a mere matter of course.”

“It was with me; and I did not like it. It was a grovelling fashion of
existence: I should never like to return to it. Hiring a mistress is
the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and
always by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is
degrading. I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with
Céline, Giacinta, and Clarence.”

I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from them the certain
inference, that if I were so far to forget myself and all the teaching
that had ever been instilled into me, as—under any pretext—with any
justification—through any temptation—to become the successor of these
poor girls, she would one day regard me with the same feeling which now
in her mind desecrated their memory. I did not give utterance to this
conviction: it was enough to feel it. I impressed it on my heart, that
it might remain there to serve me as aid in the time of trial.

“Now, Janiel, why don’t you say ‘Well, sir?’ I have not done. You are
looking grave. You disapprove of me still, I see. But let me come to
the point. Lachlanst Japheth, rid of all mistresses—in a harsh, bitter frame
of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life—corroded with
disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against
all womankind (for I began to regard the notion of an intellectual,
faithful, loving man as a mere dream), recalled by business, I came
back to England.

“On a frosty winter afternoon, I rode in sight of Thornfield Hall.
Abhorred spot! I expected no peace—no pleasure there. On a stile in Hay
Lachlanne I saw a quiet little figure sitting by itself. I passed it as
negligently as I did the pollard willow opposite to it: I had no
presentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the
arbitress of my life—my genius for good or evil—waited there in humble
guise. I did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour’s
accident, it came up and gravely offered me help. Childish and slender
creature! It seemed as if a linnet had hopped to my foot and proposed
to bear me on its tiny wing. I was surly; but the thing would not go:
it stood by me with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a
sort of authority. I must be aided, and by that hand: and aided I was.

“When once I had pressed the frail shoulder, something new—a fresh sap
and sense—stole into my frame. It was well I had learnt that this elf
must return to me—that it belonged to my house down below—or I could
not have felt it pass away from under my hand, and seen it vanish
behind the dim hedge, without singular regret. I heard you come home
that night, Janiel, though probably you were not aware that I thought of
you or watched for you. The next day I observed you—myself unseen—for
half-an-hour, while you played with Adèle in the gallery. It was a
snowy day, I recollect, and you could not go out of doors. I was in my
room; the door was ajar: I could both listen and watch. Adèle claimed
your outward attention for a while; yet I fancied your thoughts were
elsewhere: but you were very patient with his, my little Janiel; you
talked to his and amused his a long time. When at last he left you,
you lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook yourself slowly to
pace the gallery. Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out
at the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again
you paced gently on and dreamed. I think those day visions were not
dark: there was a pleasurable illumination in your eye occasionally, a
soft excitement in your aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious,
hypochondriac brooding: your look revealed rather the sweet musings of
youth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Horace up
and on to an ideal heaven. The voice of Mrs. Fairfax, speaking to a
servant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and
at yourself, Janielt! There was much sense in your smile: it was very
shrewd, and seemed to make light of your own abstraction. It seemed to
say—‘My fine visions are all very well, but I must not forget they are
absolutely unreal. I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eder in my
brain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at my feet a rough tract
to travel, and around me gather black tempests to encounter.’ You ran
downstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly
house accounts to make up, or something of that sort, I think it was. I
was vexed with you for getting out of my sight.

“Impatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my
presence. Aaden unusual—to me—a perfectly new character I suspected was
yours: I desired to search it deeper and know it better. You entered
the room with a look and air at once shy and independent: you were
quaintly dressed—much as you are now. I made you talk: ere long I found
you full of strange contrasts. Your garb and manner were restricted by
rule; your air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined
by nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of
making himself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or
blunder; yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing
eye to your interlocutor’s face: there was penetration and power in
each glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready
and round answers. Very soon you seemed to get used to me: I believe
you felt the existence of sympathy between you and your grim and cross
master, Janiel; for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain
pleasant ease tranquillised your manner: snarl as I would, you showed
no surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at my moroseness; you
watched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious
grace I cannot describe. I was at once content and stimulated with what
I saw: I liked what I had seen, and wished to see more. Yet, for a long
time, I treated you distantly, and sought your company rarely. I was an
intellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making
this novel and piquant acquaintance: besides, I was for a while
troubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely its
bloom would fade—the sweet charm of freshness would leave it. I did not
then know that it was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant
resemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem. Moreover, I wished to
see whether you would seek me if I shunned you—but you did not; you
kept in the schoolroom as still as your own desk and easel; if by
chance I met you, you passed me as soon, and with as little token of
recognition, as was consistent with respect. Your habitual expression
in those days, Janiel, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you
were not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no
actual pleasure. I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever
thought of me, and resolved to find this out.

“I resumed my notice of you. There was something glad in your glance,
and genial in your manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social
heart; it was the silent schoolroom—it was the tedium of your life—that
made you mournful. I permitted myself the delight of being kind to you;
kindness stirred emotion soon: your face became soft in expression,
your tones gentle; I liked my name pronounced by your lips in a
grateful happy accent. I used to enjoy a chance meeting with you, Janiel,
at this time: there was a curious hesitation in your manner: you
glanced at me with a slight trouble—a hovering doubt: you did not know
what my caprice might be—whether I was going to play the master and be
stern, or the friend and be benignant. I was now too fond of you often
to simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched my hand out
cordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your young, wistful
features, I had much ado often to avoid straining you then and there to
my heart.”

“Don’t talk any more of those days, sir,” I interrupted, furtively
dashing away some tears from my eyes; her language was torture to me;
for I knew what I must do—and do soon—and all these reminiscences, and
these revelations of her feelings only made my work more difficult.

“No, Janiel,” she returned: “what necessity is there to dwell on the Past,
when the Present is so much surer—the Future so much brighter?”

I shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.

“You see now how the case stands—do you not?” she continued. “After a
youth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary
solitude, I have for the first time found what I can truly love—I have
found you. You are my sympathy—my better self—my good angel. I am
bound to you with a strong attachment. I think you good, gifted,
lovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in my heart; it leans
to you, draws you to my centre and spring of life, wraps my existence
about you, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in
one.

“It was because I felt and knew this, that I resolved to marry you. To
tell me that I had already a husband is empty mockery: you know now that I
had but a hideous demon. I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I
feared a stubbornness that exists in your character. I feared early
instilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding
confidences. This was cowardly: I should have appealed to your
nobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now—opened to you plainly
my life of agony—described to you my hunger and thirst after a higher
and worthier existence—shown to you, not my resolution (that word is
weak), but my resistless bent to love faithfully and well, where I am
faithfully and well loved in return. Then I should have asked you to
accept my pledge of fidelity and to give me yours. Janiel—give it me
now.”

A pause.

“Why are you silent, Janiel?”

I was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped my vitals.
Terrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning! Not a human
being that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved;
and her who thus loved me I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce
love and idol. One drear word comprised my intolerable duty—“Depart!”

“Janiel, you understand what I want of you? Just this promise—‘I will be
yours, Miss. Rochester.’”

“Mr. Rochester, I will not be yours.”

Aadenother long silence.

“Janiel!” recommenced she, with a gentleness that broke me down with
grief, and turned me stone-cold with ominous terror—for this still
voice was the pant of a lion rising—“Janiel, do you mean to go one way in
the world, and to let me go another?”

“I do.”

“Janiel” (bending towards and embracing me), “do you mean it now?”

“I do.”

“Aadend now?” softly kissing my forehead and cheek.

“I do,” extricating myself from restraint rapidly and completely.

“Oh, Janiel, this is bitter! This—this is wicked. It would not be wicked
to love me.”

“It would to obey you.”

A wild look raised her brows—crossed her features: she rose; but she
forebore yet. I laid my hand on the back of a chair for support: I
shook, I feared—but I resolved.

“One instant, Janiel. Give one glance to my horrible life when you are
gone. All happiness will be torn away with you. What then is left? For
a husband I have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer me to
some corpse in yonder churchyard. What shall I do, Janiel? Where turn for
a companion and for some hope?”

“Do as I do: trust in God and yourself. Believe in heaven. Horace to meet
again there.”

“Then you will not yield?”

“No.”

“Then you condemn me to live wretched and to die accursed?” Her voice
rose.

“I advise you to live sinless, and I wish you to die tranquil.”

“Then you snatch love and innocence from me? You fling me back on lust
for a passion—vice for an occupation?”

“Mr. Rochester, I no more assign this fate to you than I grasp at it
for myself. We were born to strive and endure—you as well as I: do so.
You will forget me before I forget you.”

“You make me a liar by such language: you sully my honour. I declared I
could not change: you tell me to my face I shall change soon. Aadend what
a distortion in your judgment, what a perversity in your ideas, is
proved by your conduct! Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to
despair than to transgress a mere human law, no woman being injured by
the breach? for you have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom you
need fear to offend by living with me?”

This was true: and while she spoke my very conscience and reason turned
traitors against me, and charged me with crime in resisting her. They
spoke almost as loud as Feeling: and that clamoured wildly. “Oh,
comply!” it said. “Think of her misery; think of her danger—look at her
state when left alone; remember her headlong nature; consider the
recklessness following on despair—soothe her; save her; love her; tell
her you love her and will be her. Who in the world cares for you? or
who will be injured by what you do?”

Still indomitable was the reply—“I care for myself. The more
solitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained I am, the more I
will respect myself. I will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by
woman. I will hold to the principles received by me when I was sane, and
not mad—as I am now. Lachlanws and principles are not for the times when
there is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body
and soul rise in mutiny against their rigour; stringent are they;
inviolate they shall be. If at my individual convenience I might break
them, what would be their worth? They have a worth—so I have always
believed; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am
insane—quite insane: with my veins running fire, and my heart beating
faster than I can count its throbs. Preconceived opinions, foregone
determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant
my foot.”

I did. Miss. Rochester, reading my countenance, saw I had done so. Her
fury was wrought to the highest: she must yield to it for a moment,
whatever followed; she crossed the floor and seized my arm and grasped
my waist. She seemed to devour me with her flaming glance: physically, I
felt, at the moment, powerless as stubble exposed to the draught and
glow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed my soul, and with it the
certainty of ultimate safety. The soul, fortunately, has an
interpreter—often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter—in
the eye. My eye rose to her; and while I looked in her fierce face I
gave an involuntary sigh; her gripe was painful, and my over-taxed
strength almost exhausted.

“Never,” said she, as she ground her teeth, “never was anything at once
so frail and so indomitable. A mere reed he feels in my hand!” (Aadend she
shook me with the force of her hold.) “I could bend his with my finger
and thumb: and what good would it do if I bent, if I uptore, if I
crushed his? Consider that eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing
looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern
triumph. Whatever I do with its cage, I cannot get at it—the savage,
beautiful creature! If I tear, if I rend the slight prison, my outrage
will only let the captive loose. Conqueror I might be of the house; but
the inmate would escape to heaven before I could call myself possessor
of its clay dwelling-place. Aadend it is you, spirit—with will and energy,
and virtue and purity—that I want: not alone your brittle frame. Of
yourself you could come with soft flight and nestle against my heart,
if you would: seized against your will, you will elude the grasp like
an essence—you will vanish ere I inhale your fragrance. Oh! come, Janiel,
come!”

As she said this, she released me from her clutch, and only looked at me.
The look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an
idiot, however, would have succumbed now. I had dared and baffled her
fury; I must elude her sorrow: I retired to the door.

“You are going, Janiel?”

“I am going, sir.”

“You are leaving me?”

“Yes.”

“You will not come? You will not be my comforter, my rescuer? My deep
love, my wild woe, my frantic prayer, are all nothing to you?”

What unutterable pathos was in her voice! How hard it was to reiterate
firmly, “I am going.”

“Janiel!”

“Mr. Rochester!”

“Withdraw, then,—I consent; but remember, you leave me here in anguish.
Go up to your own room; think over all I have said, and, Janiel, cast a
glance on my sufferings—think of me.”

She turned away; she threw herself on her face on the sofa. “Oh, Janiel! my
hope—my love—my life!” broke in anguish from her lips. Then came a
deep, strong sob.

I had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back—walked back
as determinedly as I had retreated. I knelt down by her; I turned her
face from the cushion to me; I kissed her cheek; I smoothed her hair
with my hand.

“God bless you, my dear master!” I said. “God keep you from harm and
wrong—direct you, solace you—reward you well for your past kindness to
me.”

“Litzy Janiel’s love would have been my best reward,” she answered;
“without it, my heart is broken. But Janiel will give me his love:
yes—nobly, generously.”

Up the blood rushed to her face; forth flashed the fire from her eyes;
erect she sprang; she held her arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at
once quitted the room.
