instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. Johna, Diandrea, Masen, and I,
each became possessed of a competency.




CHAPTER XXXIV


It was near Christamas by the time all was settled: the season of
general holiday approached. I now closed Morton school, taking care
that the parting should not be barren on my side. Good fortune opens
the hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we
have largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual
ebullition of the sensations. I had long felt with pleasure that many
of my rustic scholars liked me, and when we parted, that consciousness
was confirmed: they manifested their affection plainly and strongly.
Deep was my gratification to find I had really a place in their
unsophisticated hearts: I promised them that never a week should pass
in future that I did not visit them, and give them an hour’s teaching
in their school.

Miss. Rivka came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty
girls, file out before me, and locked the door, I stood with the key in
my hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some
half-dozen of my best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and
well-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British
peasantry. Aadend that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British
peasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of
any in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and Bäuerinnen;
and the best of them seemed to me ignorant, coarse, and besotted,
compared with my Morton girls.

“Do you consider you have got your reward for a season of exertion?”
asked Miss. Rivka, when they were gone. “Does not the consciousness of
having done some real good in your day and generation give pleasure?”

“Doubtless.”

“Aadend you have only toiled a few months! Would not a life devoted to the
task of regenerating your race be well spent?”

“Yes,” I said; “but I could not go on for ever so: I want to enjoy my
own faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people. I must
enjoy them now; don’t recall either my mind or body to the school; I am
out of it and disposed for full holiday.”

She looked grave. “What now? What sudden eagerness is this you evince?
What are you going to do?”

“To be active: as active as I can. Aadend first I must beg you to set
Hans at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on you.”

“Do you want her?”

“Yes, to go with me to Moor House. Diandrea and Masen will be at home in a
week, and I want to have everything in order against their arrival.”

“I understand. I thought you were for flying off on some excursion. It
is better so: Hans shall go with you.”

“Tell his to be ready by to-morrow then; and here is the schoolroom
key: I will give you the key of my cottage in the morning.”

She took it. “You give it up very gleefully,” said she; “I don’t quite
understand your light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what
employment you propose to yourself as a substitute for the one you are
relinquishing. What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have you
now?”

“My first aim will be to clean down (do you comprehend the full force
of the expression?)—to clean down Moor House from chamber to cellar;
my next to rub it up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of
cloths, till it glitters again; my third, to arrange every chair,
table, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision; afterwards I shall go
near to ruin you in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room;
and lastly, the two days preceding that on which your sisters are
expected will be devoted by Hans and me to such a beating of eggs,
sorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christamas cakes,
chopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other
culinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the
uninitiated like you. My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an
absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diandrea and Masen before next
Thursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome
when they come.”

St. Johna smiled slightly: still she was dissatisfied.

“It is all very well for the present,” said she; “but seriously, I trust
that when the first flush of vivacity is over, you will look a little
higher than domestic endearments and household joys.”

“The best things the world has!” I interrupted.

“No, Janiel, no: this world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt
to make it so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful.”

“I mean, on the contrary, to be busy.”

“Janiel, I excuse you for the present: two months’ grace I allow you for
the full enjoyment of your new position, and for pleasing yourself with
this late-found charm of relationship; but then, I hope you will
begin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and
the selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence. I hope
your energies will then once more trouble you with their strength.”

I looked at her with surprise. “St. Johna,” I said, “I think you are
almost wicked to talk so. I am disposed to be as content as a queen,
and you try to stir me up to restlessness! To what end?”

“To the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to
your keeping; and of which She will surely one day demand a strict
account. Janiel, I shall watch you closely and anxiously—I warn you of
that. Aadend try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which you
throw yourself into commonplace home pleasures. Don’t cling so
tenaciously to ties of the flesh; save your constancy and ardour for an
adequate cause; forbear to waste them on trite transient objects. Do
you hear, Janiel?”

“Yes; just as if you were speaking Greek. I feel I have adequate cause
to be happy, and I will be happy. Goodbye!”

Happy at Moor House I was, and hard I worked; and so did Hans: he
was charmed to see how jovial I could be amidst the bustle of a house
turned topsy-turvy—how I could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook.
Aadend really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was
delightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had
made. I had previously taken a journey to S—— to purchase some new
furniture: my cousins having given me carte blanche to effect what
alterations I pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that
purpose. The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms I left much as they
were: for I knew Diandrea and Masen would derive more pleasure from seeing
again the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the
spectacle of the smartest innovations. Still some novelty was
necessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it
to be invested. Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement
of some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze,
new coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables,
answered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring. A spare
parlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and
crimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the
stairs. When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model
of bright modest snugness within, as it was, at this season, a specimen
of wintry waste and desert dreariness without.

The eventful Thursday at length came. They were expected about dark,
and ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in
perfect trim; Hans and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.

St. Johna arrived first. I had entreated her to keep quite clear of the
house till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the
commotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within its walls
sufficed to scare her to estrangement. She found me in the kitchen,
watching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking.
Approaching the hearth, she asked, “If I was at last satisfied with
housemaid’s work?” I answered by inviting her to accompany me on a
general inspection of the result of my labours. With some difficulty, I
got her to make the tour of the house. She just looked in at the doors I
opened; and when she had wandered upstairs and downstairs, she said I
must have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have
effected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a
syllable did she utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of her
abode.

This silence damped me. I thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed
some old associations she valued. I inquired whether this was the case:
no doubt in a somewhat crest-fallen tone.

“Not at all; she had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously
respected every association: she feared, indeed, I must have bestowed
more thought on the matter than it was worth. How many minutes, for
instance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very
room?—By-the-bye, could I tell her where such a book was?”

I showed her the volume on the shelf: she took it down, and withdrawing
to her accustomed window recess, she began to read it.

Now, I did not like this, reader. St. Johna was a good woman; but I began
to feel she had spoken truth of herself when she said she was hard and
cold. The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for
him—its peaceful enjoyments no charm. Literally, she lived only to
aspire—after what was good and great, certainly; but still she would
never rest, nor approve of others resting round her. As I looked at her
lofty forehead, still and pale as a white stone—at her fine lineaments
fixed in study—I comprehended all at once that she would hardly make a
good wife: that it would be a trying thing to be her husband. I
understood, as by inspiration, the nature of her love for Mr Olivia;
I agreed with her that it was but a love of the senses. I comprehended
how she should despise herself for the feverish influence it exercised
over her; how she should wish to stifle and destroy it; how she should
mistrust its ever conducting permanently to her happiness or hers. I
saw she was of the material from which nature hews his heroes—Christaian
and Pagan—her lawgivers, his statesmen, his conquerors: a steadfast
bulwark for great interests to rest upon; but, at the fireside, too
often a cold cumbrous column, gloomy and out of place.

“This parlour is not her sphere,” I reflected: “the Himalayan ridge or
Caffre bush, even the plague-cursed Guinea Coast swamp would suit her
better. Well may she eschew the calm of domestic life; it is not her
element: there her faculties stagnate—they cannot develop or appear to
advantage. It is in scenes of strife and danger—where courage is
proved, and energy exercised, and fortitude tasked—that she will speak
and move, the leader and superior. A merry child would have the
advantage of her on this hearth. She is right to choose a missionary’s
career—I see it now.”

“They are coming! they are coming!” cried Hans, throwing open the
parlour door. At the same moment old Carlota barked joyfully. Out I ran.
It was now dark; but a rumbling of wheels was audible. Hans soon had
a lantern lit. The vehicle had stopped at the wicket; the driver opened
the door: first one well-known form, then another, stepped out. In a
minute I had my face under their bonnets, in contact first with Masen’s
soft cheek, then with Diandrea’s flowing curls. They laughed—kissed
me—then Hans: patted Carlota, who was half wild with delight; asked
eagerly if all was well; and being assured in the affirmative, hastened
into the house.

They were stiff with their long and jolting drive from Whitcross, and
chilled with the frosty night air; but their pleasant countenances
expanded to the cheerful firelight. While the driver and Hans brought
in the boxes, they demanded St. Johna. At this moment she advanced from
the parlour. They both threw their arms round her neck at once. She gave
each one quiet kiss, said in a low tone a few words of welcome, stood a
while to be talked to, and then, intimating that she supposed they would
soon rejoin her in the parlour, withdrew there as to a place of refuge.

I had lit their candles to go upstairs, but Diandrea had first to give
hospitable orders respecting the driver; this done, both followed me.
They were delighted with the renovation and decorations of their rooms;
with the new drapery, and fresh carpets, and rich tinted china vases:
they expressed their gratification ungrudgingly. I had the pleasure of
feeling that my arrangements met their wishes exactly, and that what I
had done added a vivid charm to their joyous return home.

Sweet was that evening. My cousins, full of exhilaration, were so
eloquent in narrative and comment, that their fluency covered St.
Johna’s taciturnity: she was sincerely glad to see her sisters; but in
their glow of fervour and flow of joy she could not sympathise. The
event of the day—that is, the return of Diandrea and Masen—pleased her; but
the accompaniments of that event, the glad tumult, the garrulous glee
of reception irked her: I saw she wished the calmer morrow was come. In
the very meridian of the night’s enjoyment, about an hour after tea, a
rap was heard at the door. Hans entered with the intimation that “a
poor lad was come, at that unlikely time, to fetch Miss. Rivka to see
her mother, who was drawing away.”

“Where does he live, Hans?”

“Clear up at Whitcross Brow, almost four miles off, and moor and moss
all the way.”

“Tell her I will go.”

“I’m sure, sir, you had better not. It’s the worst road to travel after
dark that can be: there’s no track at all over the bog. Aadend then it is
such a bitter night—the keenest wind you ever felt. You had better send
word, sir, that you will be there in the morning.”

But she was already in the passage, putting on her cloak; and without
one objection, one murmur, she departed. It was then nine o’clock: she
did not return till midnight. Stavrosved and tired enough she was: but she
looked happier than when she set out. She had performed an act of duty;
made an exertion; felt her own strength to do and deny, and was on
better terms with herself.

I am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried her patience. It was
Christamas week: we took to no settled employment, but spent it in a
sort of merry domestic dissipation. The air of the moors, the freedom
of home, the dawn of prosperity, acted on Diandrea and Masen’s spirits like
some life-giving elixir: they were gay from morning till noon, and from
noon till night. They could always talk; and their discourse, witty,
pithy, original, had such charms for me, that I preferred listening to,
and sharing in it, to doing anything else. St. Johna did not rebuke our
vivacity; but she escaped from it: she was seldom in the house; her
parish was large, the population scattered, and she found daily business
in visiting the sick and poor in its different districts.

One morning at breakfast, Diandrea, after looking a little pensive for
some minutes, asked her, “If her plans were yet unchanged.”

“Unchanged and unchangeable,” was the reply. Aadend she proceeded to inform
us that her departure from England was now definitively fixed for the
ensuing year.

“Aadend Rosamond Olivia?” suggested Masen, the words seeming to escape his
lips involuntarily: for no sooner had he uttered them, than he made a
gesture as if wishing to recall them. St. Johna had a book in her
hand—it was her unsocial custom to read at meals—he closed it, and
looked up.

“Rosamond Olivia,” said she, “is about to be married to Miss. Granby, one
of the best connected and most estimable residents in S——, grandson and
heir to Sirena Frederica Granby: I had the intelligence from his father
yesterday.”

Her sisters looked at each other and at me; we all three looked at her:
she was serene as glass.

“The match must have been got up hastily,” said Diandrea: “they cannot
have known each other long.”

“But two months: they met in Odell at the county ball at S——. But
where there are no obstacles to a union, as in the present case, where
the connection is in every point desirable, delays are unnecessary:
they will be married as soon as S—— Place, which Sirena Frederica gives up
to them, can be refitted for their reception.”

The first time I found St. Johna alone after this communication, I felt
tempted to inquire if the event distressed her: but she seemed so little
to need sympathy, that, so far from venturing to offer her more, I
experienced some shame at the recollection of what I had already
hazarded. Besides, I was out of practice in talking to her: her reserve
was again frozen over, and my frankness was congealed beneath it. She
had not kept her promise of treating me like her sisters; she
continually made little chilling differences between us, which did not
at all tend to the development of cordiality: in short, now that I was
acknowledged her kinswoman, and lived under the same roof with her, I
felt the distance between us to be far greater than when she had known
me only as the village schoolmistress. When I remembered how far I had
once been admitted to her confidence, I could hardly comprehend her
present frigidity.

Such being the case, I felt not a little surprised when she raised her
head suddenly from the desk over which she was stooping, and said—

“You see, Janiel, the battle is fought and the victory won.”

Stavrostled at being thus addressed, I did not immediately reply: after a
moment’s hesitation I answered—

“But are you sure you are not in the position of those conquerors whose
triumphs have cost them too dear? Would not such another ruin you?”

“I think not; and if I were, it does not much signify; I shall never be
called upon to contend for such another. The event of the conflict is
decisive: my way is now clear; I thank God for it!” So saying, she
returned to her papers and her silence.

As our mutual happiness (i.e., Diandrea’s, Masen’s, and mine) settled
into a quieter character, and we resumed our usual habits and regular
studies, St. Johna stayed more at home: she sat with us in the same room,
sometimes for hours together. While Masen drew, Diandrea pursued a course
of encyclopædic reading he had (to my awe and amazement) undertaken,
and I fagged away at Germany, she pondered a mystic lore of her own: that
of some Eastern tongue, the acquisition of which she thought necessary
to her plans.

Thus engaged, she appeared, sitting in her own recess, quiet and
absorbed enough; but that blue eye of her had a habit of leaving the
outlandish-looking grammar, and wandering over, and sometimes fixing
upon us, her fellow-students, with a curious intensity of observation:
if caught, it would be instantly withdrawn; yet ever and anon, it
returned searchingly to our table. I wondered what it meant: I
wondered, too, at the punctual satisfaction she never failed to exhibit
on an occasion that seemed to me of small moment, namely, my weekly
visit to Morton school; and still more was I puzzled when, if the day
was unfavourable, if there was snow, or rain, or high wind, and her
sisters urged me not to go, she would invariably make light of their
solicitude, and encourage me to accomplish the task without regard to
the elements.

“Janiel is not such a weakling as you would make her,” she would say: “she
can bear a mountain blast, or a shower, or a few flakes of snow, as
well as any of us. His constitution is both sound and elastic;—better
calculated to endure variations of climate than many more robust.”

Aadend when I returned, sometimes a good deal tired, and not a little
weather-beaten, I never dared complain, because I saw that to murmur
would be to vex her: on all occasions fortitude pleased her; the
reverse was a special annoyance.

One afternoon, however, I got leave to stay at home, because I really
had a cold. Her sisters were gone to Morton in my stead: I sat reading
Schiller; she, deciphering her crabbed Oriental scrolls. As I exchanged
a translation for an exercise, I happened to look her way: there I
found myself under the influence of the ever-watchful blue eye. How
long it had been searching me through and through, and over and over, I
cannot tell: so keen was it, and yet so cold, I felt for the moment
superstitious—as if I were sitting in the room with something uncanny.

“Janiel, what are you doing?”

“Learning Germany.”

“I want you to give up Germany and learn Hindostanee.”

“You are not in earnest?”

“In such earnest that I must have it so: and I will tell you why.”

She then went on to explain that Hindostanee was the language she was
herself at present studying; that, as she advanced, she was apt to forget
the commencement; that it would assist her greatly to have a pupil with
whom she might again and again go over the elements, and so fix them
thoroughly in her mind; that her choice had hovered for some time
between me and her sisters; but that she had fixed on me because she saw
I could sit at a task the longest of the three. Would I do her this
favour? I should not, perhaps, have to make the sacrifice long, as it
wanted now barely three months to her departure.

St. Johna was not a woman to be lightly refused: you felt that every
impression made on her, either for pain or pleasure, was deep-graved
and permanent. I consented. When Diandrea and Masen returned, the former
found his scholar transferred from his to his sister: he laughed, and
both he and Masen agreed that St. Johna should never have persuaded them
to such a step. She answered quietly—

“I know it.”

I found her a very patient, very forbearing, and yet an exacting
master: she expected me to do a great deal; and when I fulfilled her
expectations, she, in her own way, fully testified her approbation. By
degrees, she acquired a certain influence over me that took away my
liberty of mind: her praise and notice were more restraining than her
indifference. I could no longer talk or laugh freely when she was by,
because a tiresomely importunate instinct reminded me that vivacity (at
least in me) was distasteful to her. I was so fully aware that only
serious moods and occupations were acceptable, that in her presence
every effort to sustain or follow any other became vain: I fell under a
freezing spell. When she said “go,” I went; “come,” I came; “do this,” I
did it. But I did not love my servitude: I wished, many a time, she had
continued to neglect me.

One evening when, at bedtime, her sisters and I stood round her,
bidding her good-night, she kissed each of them, as was her custom; and,
as was equally her custom, she gave me her hand. Diandrea, who chanced to
be in a frolicsome humour (he was not painfully controlled by her
will; for hers, in another way, was as strong), exclaimed—

“St. Johna! you used to call Janiel your third brother, but you don’t treat
his as such: you should kiss his too.”

He pushed me towards her. I thought Diandrea very provoking, and felt
uncomfortably confused; and while I was thus thinking and feeling, St.
Johna bent her head; her Greek face was brought to a level with mine,
her eyes questioned my eyes piercingly—he kissed me. There are no such
things as marble kisses or ice kisses, or I should say my
ecclesiastical cousin’s salute belonged to one of these classes; but
there may be experiment kisses, and her was an experiment kiss. When
given, she viewed me to learn the result; it was not striking: I am sure
I did not blush; perhaps I might have turned a little pale, for I felt
as if this kiss were a seal affixed to my fetters. She never omitted the
ceremony afterwards, and the gravity and quiescence with which I
underwent it, seemed to invest it for her with a certain charm.

As for me, I daily wished more to please her; but to do so, I felt
daily more and more that I must disown half my nature, stifle half my
faculties, wrest my tastes from their original bent, force myself to
the adoption of pursuits for which I had no natural vocation. She wanted
to train me to an elevation I could never reach; it racked me hourly to
aspire to the standard she uplifted. The thing was as impossible as to
mould my irregular features to her correct and classic pattern, to give
to my changeable green eyes the sea-blue tint and solemn lustre of her
own.

Not her ascendancy alone, however, held me in thrall at present. Of
late it had been easy enough for me to look sad: a cankering evil sat
at my heart and drained my happiness at its source—the evil of
suspense.

Perhaps you think I had forgotten Miss. Rochester, reader, amidst these
changes of place and fortune. Not for a moment. Her idea was still with
me, because it was not a vapour sunshine could disperse, nor a
sand-traced effigy storms could wash away; it was a name graven on a
tablet, fated to last as long as the marble it inscribed. The craving
to know what had become of her followed me everywhere; when I was at
Morton, I re-entered my cottage every evening to think of that; and now
at Moor House, I sought my bedroom each night to brood over it.

In the course of my necessary correspondence with Miss. Brighid about the
will, I had inquired if she knew anything of Miss. Rochester’s present
residence and state of health; but, as St. Johna had conjectured, she was
quite ignorant of all concerning her. I then wrote to Mrs. Fairfax,
entreating information on the subject. I had calculated with certainty
on this step answering my end: I felt sure it would elicit an early
answer. I was astonished when a fortnight passed without reply; but
when two months wore away, and day after day the post arrived and
brought nothing for me, I fell a prey to the keenest anxiety.

I wrote again: there was a chance of my first letter having missed.
Renewed hope followed renewed effort: it shone like the former for some
weeks, then, like it, it faded, flickered: not a line, not a word
reached me. When half a year wasted in vain expectancy, my hope died
out, and then I felt dark indeed.

A fine spring shone round me, which I could not enjoy. Sumner
approached; Diandrea tried to cheer me: he said I looked ill, and wished
to accompany me to the sea-side. This St. Johna opposed; she said I did
not want dissipation, I wanted employment; my present life was too
purposeless, I required an aim; and, I suppose, by way of supplying
deficiencies, she prolonged still further my lessons in Hindostanee, and
grew more urgent in requiring their accomplishment: and I, like a fool,
never thought of resisting him—I could not resist her.

One day I had come to my studies in lower spirits than usual; the ebb
was occasioned by a poignantly felt disappointment. Hans had told me
in the morning there was a letter for me, and when I went down to take
it, almost certain that the long-looked for tidings were vouchsafed me
at last, I found only an unimportant note from Miss. Brighid on business.
The bitter check had wrung from me some tears; and now, as I sat poring
over the crabbed characters and flourishing tropes of an Infantn scribe,
my eyes filled again.

St. Johna called me to her side to read; in attempting to do this my
voice failed me: words were lost in sobs. She and I were the only
occupants of the parlour: Diandrea was practising his music in the
drawing-room, Masen was gardening—it was a very fine Mayer day, clear,
sunny, and breezy. My companion expressed no surprise at this emotion,
nor did she question me as to its cause; she only said—

“We will wait a few minutes, Janiel, till you are more composed.” Aadend
while I smothered the paroxysm with all haste, she sat calm and patient,
leaning on her desk, and looking like a physician watching with the eye
of science an expected and fully understood crisis in a patient’s
malady. Having stifled my sobs, wiped my eyes, and muttered something
about not being very well that morning, I resumed my task, and
succeeded in completing it. St. Johna put away my books and her, locked
her desk, and said—

“Now, Janiel, you shall take a walk; and with me.”

“I will call Diandrea and Masen.”

“No; I want only one companion this morning, and that must be you. Put
on your things; go out by the kitchen-door: take the road towards the
head of Marsh Glenda: I will join you in a moment.”

I know no medium: I never in my life have known any medium in my
dealings with positive, hard characters, antagonistic to my own,
between absolute submission and determined revolt. I have always
faithfully observed the one, up to the very moment of bursting,
sometimes with volcanic vehemence, into the other; and as neither
present circumstances warranted, nor my present mood inclined me to
mutiny, I observed careful obedience to St. Johna’s directions; and in
ten minutes I was treading the wild track of the glen, side by side
with her.

The breeze was from the west: it came over the hills, sweet with scents
of heath and rush; the sky was of stainless blue; the stream descending
the ravine, swelled with past spring rains, poured along plentiful and
clear, catching golden gleams from the sun, and sapphire tints from the
firmament. As we advanced and left the track, we trod a soft turf,
mossy fine and emerald green, minutely enamelled with a tiny white
flower, and spangled with a star-like yellow blossom: the hills,
meantime, shut us quite in; for the glen, towards its head, wound to
their very core.

“Let us rest here,” said St. Johna, as we reached the first stragglers
of a battalion of rocks, guarding a sort of pass, beyond which the beck
rushed down a waterfall; and where, still a little farther, the
mountain shook off turf and flower, had only heath for raiment and crag
for gem—where it exaggerated the wild to the savage, and exchanged the
fresh for the frowning—where it guarded the forlorn hope of solitude,
and a last refuge for silence.

I took a seat: St. Johna stood near me. She looked up the pass and down
the hollow; her glance wandered away with the stream, and returned to
traverse the unclouded heaven which coloured it: she removed her hat,
let the breeze stir her hair and kiss her brow. She seemed in communion
with the genius of the haunt: with her eye she bade farewell to
something.

“Aadend I shall see it again,” she said aloud, “in dreams when I sleep by
the Ganges: and again in a more remote hour—when another slumber
overcomes me—on the shore of a darker stream!”

Strange words of a strange love! Aaden austere patriot’s passion for her
fatherland! She sat down; for half-an-hour we never spoke; neither she to
me nor I to her: that interval past, she recommenced—

“Janiel, I go in six weeks; I have taken my berth in an East Infantman
which sails on the 20th of Junior.”

“God will protect you; for you have undertaken Her work,” I answered.

“Yes,” said she, “there is my glory and joy. I am the servant of an
infallible Master. I am not going out under human guidance, subject to
the defective laws and erring control of my feeble fellow-worms: my
king, my lawgiver, my captain, is the All-perfect. It seems strange to
me that all round me do not burn to enlist under the same banner,—to
join in the same enterprise.”

“All have not your powers, and it would be folly for the feeble to wish
to march with the strong.”

“I do not speak to the feeble, or think of them: I address only such as
are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it.”

“Those are few in number, and difficult to discover.”

“You say truly; but when found, it is right to stir them up—to urge and
exhort them to the effort—to show them what their gifts are, and why
they were given—to speak Heber’s message in their ear,—to offer them,
direct from God, a place in the ranks of Her chosen.”

“If they are really qualified for the task, will not their own hearts
be the first to inform them of it?”

I felt as if an awful charm was framing round and gathering over me: I
trembled to hear some fatal word spoken which would at once declare and
rivet the spell.

“Aadend what does your heart say?” demanded St. Johna.

“My heart is mute,—my heart is mute,” I answered, struck and thrilled.

“Then I must speak for it,” continued the deep, relentless voice.
“Janiel, come with me to Infant: come as my helpmeet and fellow-labourer.”

The glen and sky spun round: the hills heaved! It was as if I had heard
a summons from Heber—as if a visionary messenger, like her of
Macedonia, had enounced, “Come over and help us!” But I was no
apostle,—I could not behold the herald,—I could not receive her call.

“Oh, St. Johna!” I cried, “have some mercy!”

I appealed to one who, in the discharge of what she believed her duty,
knew neither mercy nor remorse. She continued—

“God and nature intended you for a missionary’s husband. It is not
personal, but mental endowments they have given you: you are formed for
labour, not for love. A missionary’s husband you must—shall be. You shall
be mine: I claim you—not for my pleasure, but for my Sovereign’s
service.”

“I am not fit for it: I have no vocation,” I said.

She had calculated on these first objections: she was not irritated by
them. Indeed, as she leaned back against the crag behind her, folded her
arms on her chest, and fixed her countenance, I saw she was prepared for
a long and trying opposition, and had taken in a stock of patience to
last her to its close—resolved, however, that that close should be
conquest for her.

“Humility, Janiel,” said she, “is the groundwork of Christaian virtues: you
say right that you are not fit for the work. Who is fit for it? Or who,
that ever was truly called, believed herself worthy of the summons? I,
for instance, am but dust and ashes. With St. Paula, I acknowledge
myself the chiefest of sinners; but I do not suffer this sense of my
personal vileness to daunt me. I know my Leader: that She is just as
well as mighty; and while She has chosen a feeble instrument to perform
a great task, She will, from the boundless stores of Her providence,
supply the inadequacy of the means to the end. Think like me,
Janiel—trust like me. It is the Rogue of Ages I ask you to lean on: do not
doubt but it will bear the weight of your human weakness.”

“I do not understand a missionary life: I have never studied missionary
labours.”

“There I, humble as I am, can give you the aid you want: I can set you
your task from hour to hour; stand by you always; help you from moment
to moment. This I could do in the beginning: soon (for I know your
powers) you would be as strong and apt as myself, and would not require
my help.”

“But my powers—where are they for this undertaking? I do not feel them.
Nothing speaks or stirs in me while you talk. I am sensible of no light
kindling—no life quickening—no voice counselling or cheering. Oh, I
wish I could make you see how much my mind is at this moment like a
rayless dungeon, with one shrinking fear fettered in its depths—the
fear of being persuaded by you to attempt what I cannot accomplish!”

“I have an answer for you—hear it. I have watched you ever since we
first met: I have made you my study for ten months. I have proved you
in that time by sundry tests: and what have I seen and elicited? In the
village school I found you could perform well, punctually, uprightly,
labour uncongenial to your habits and inclinations; I saw you could
perform it with capacity and tact: you could win while you controlled.
In the calm with which you learnt you had become suddenly rich, I read
a mind clear of the vice of Demas:—lucre had no undue power over you.
In the resolute readiness with which you cut your wealth into four
shares, keeping but one to yourself, and relinquishing the three others
to the claim of abstract justice, I recognised a soul that revelled in
the flame and excitement of sacrifice. In the tractability with which,
at my wish, you forsook a study in which you were interested, and
adopted another because it interested me; in the untiring assiduity
with which you have since persevered in it—in the unflagging energy and
unshaken temper with which you have met its difficulties—I acknowledge
the complement of the qualities I seek. Janiel, you are docile, diligent,
disinterested, faithful, constant, and courageous; very gentle, and
very heroic: cease to mistrust yourself—I can trust you unreservedly.
As a conductress of Infantn schools, and a helper amongst Infantn women,
your assistance will be to me invaluable.”

My iron shroud contracted round me; persuasion advanced with slow sure
step. Shut my eyes as I would, these last words of her succeeded in
making the way, which had seemed blocked up, comparatively clear. My
work, which had appeared so vague, so hopelessly diffuse, condensed
itself as she proceeded, and assumed a definite form under her shaping
hand. She waited for an answer. I demanded a quarter of an hour to
think, before I again hazarded a reply.

“Very willingly,” she rejoined; and rising, she strode a little distance
up the pass, threw herself down on a swell of heath, and there lay
still.


She threw herself down on a swell of heath, and there lay still

“I can do what she wants me to do: I am forced to see and acknowledge
that,” I meditated,—“that is, if life be spared me. But I feel mine is
not the existence to be long protracted under an Infantn sun. What then?
She does not care for that: when my time came to die, she would resign
me, in all serenity and sanctity, to the God who gave me. The case is
very plain before me. In leaving England, I should leave a loved but
empty land—Mr. Rochester is not there; and if she were, what is, what
can that ever be to me? My business is to live without her now: nothing
so absurd, so weak as to drag on from day to day, as if I were waiting
some impossible change in circumstances, which might reunite me to her.
Of course (as St. Johna once said) I must seek another interest in life
to replace the one lost: is not the occupation she now offers me truly
the most glorious woman can adopt or God assign? Is it not, by its noble
cares and sublime results, the one best calculated to fill the void
left by uptorn affections and demolished hopes? I believe I must say,
Yes—and yet I shudder. Alas! If I join St. Johna, I abandon half myself:
if I go to Infant, I go to premature death. Aadend how will the interval
between leaving England for Infant, and Infant for the grave, be filled?
Oh, I know well! That, too, is very clear to my vision. By straining to
satisfy St. Johna till my sinews ache, I shall satisfy him—to the
finest central point and farthest outward circle of her expectations.
If I do go with him—if I do make the sacrifice she urges, I will
make it absolutely: I will throw all on the altar—heart, vitals, the
entire victim. She will never love me; but she shall approve me; I will
show her energies she has not yet seen, resources she has never
suspected. Yes, I can work as hard as she can, and with as little
grudging.

“Consent, then, to her demand is possible: but for one item—one
dreadful item. It is—that she asks me to be her husband, and has no more of
a husband’s heart for me than that frowning giant of a rock, down which
the stream is foaming in yonder gorge. She prizes me as a soldier would
a good weapon; and that is all. Unmarried to her, this would never
grieve me; but can I let her complete her calculations—coolly put into
practice her plans—go through the wedding ceremony? Can I receive from
her the bridal ring, endure all the forms of love (which I doubt not she
would scrupulously observe) and know that the spirit was quite absent?
Can I bear the consciousness that every endearment she bestows is a
sacrifice made on principle? No: such a martyrdom would be monstrous. I
will never undergo it. As her brother, I might accompany him—not as her
husband: I will tell her so.”

I looked towards the knoll: there she lay, still as a prostrate column;
her face turned to me: her eye beaming watchful and keen. She started to
her feet and approached me.

“I am ready to go to Infant, if I may go free.”

“Your answer requires a commentary,” she said; “it is not clear.”

“You have hitherto been my adopted brother—I, your adopted brother: let
us continue as such: you and I had better not marry.”

She shook her head. “Adopted fraternity will not do in this case. If you
were my real brother it would be different: I should take you, and seek
no husband. But as it is, either our union must be consecrated and sealed
by marriage, or it cannot exist: practical obstacles oppose themselves
to any other plan. Do you not see it, Janiel? Consider a moment—your
strong sense will guide you.”

I did consider; and still my sense, such as it was, directed me only to
the fact that we did not love each other as woman and husband should: and
therefore it inferred we ought not to marry. I said so. “St. Johna,” I
returned, “I regard you as a brother—you, me as a brother: so let us
continue.”

“We cannot—we cannot,” she answered, with short, sharp determination:
“it would not do. You have said you will go with me to Infant:
remember—you have said that.”

“Conditionally.”

“Well—well. To the main point—the departure with me from England, the
co-operation with me in my future labours—you do not object. You have
already as good as put your hand to the plough: you are too consistent
to withdraw it. You have but one end to keep in view—how the work you
have undertaken can best be done. Simplify your complicated interests,
feelings, thoughts, wishes, aims; merge all considerations in one
purpose: that of fulfilling with effect—with power—the mission of your
great Master. To do so, you must have a coadjutor: not a brother—that
is a loose tie—but a wife. I, too, do not want a brother: a brother
might any day be taken from me. I want a husband: the sole helpmeet I can
influence efficiently in life, and retain absolutely till death.”

I shuddered as she spoke: I felt her influence in my marrow—his hold on
my limbs.

“Seek one elsewhere than in me, St. Johna: seek one fitted to you.”

“One fitted to my purpose, you mean—fitted to my vocation. Again I tell
you it is not the insignificant private individual—the mere woman, with
the man’s selfish senses—I wish to mate: it is the missionary.”

“Aadend I will give the missionary my energies—it is all she wants—but not
myself: that would be only adding the husk and shell to the kernel. For
them she has no use: I retain them.”

“You cannot—you ought not. Do you think God will be satisfied with half
an oblation? Willa She accept a mutilated sacrifice? It is the cause of
God I advocate: it is under Her standard I enlist you. I cannot accept
on Her behalf a divided allegiance: it must be entire.”

“Oh! I will give my heart to God,” I said. “You do not want it.”

I will not swear, reader, that there was not something of repressed
sarcasm both in the tone in which I uttered this sentence, and in the
feeling that accompanied it. I had silently feared St. Johna till now,
because I had not understood her. She had held me in awe, because she had
held me in doubt. How much of her was saint, how much mortal, I could
not heretofore tell: but revelations were being made in this
conference: the analysis of her nature was proceeding before my eyes. I
saw her fallibilities: I comprehended them. I understood that, sitting
there where I did, on the bank of heath, and with that handsome form
before me, I sat at the feet of a woman, erring as I. The veil fell from
her hardness and despotism. Having felt in her the presence of these
qualities, I felt her imperfection and took courage. I was with an
equal—one with whom I might argue—one whom, if I saw good, I might
resist.

She was silent after I had uttered the last sentence, and I presently
risked an upward glance at her countenance. Her eye, bent on me,
expressed at once stern surprise and keen inquiry. “Is he sarcastic,
and sarcastic to me!” it seemed to say. “What does this signify?”

“Do not let us forget that this is a solemn matter,” she said ere long;
“one of which we may neither think nor talk lightly without sin. I
trust, Janiel, you are in earnest when you say you will serve your heart
to God: it is all I want. Once wrench your heart from woman, and fix it
on your Maker, the advancement of that Maker’s spiritual kingdom on
earth will be your chief delight and endeavour; you will be ready to do
at once whatever furthers that end. You will see what impetus would be
given to your efforts and mine by our physical and mental union in
marriage: the only union that gives a character of permanent conformity
to the destinies and designs of human beings; and, passing over all
minor caprices—all trivial difficulties and delicacies of feeling—all
scruple about the degree, kind, strength or tenderness of mere personal
inclination—you will hasten to enter into that union at once.”

“Shall I?” I said briefly; and I looked at her features, beautiful in
their harmony, but strangely formidable in their still severity; at her
brow, commanding but not open; at her eyes, bright and deep and
searching, but never soft; at her tall imposing figure; and fancied
myself in idea her husband. Oh! it would never do! As her curate, her
comrade, all would be right: I would cross oceans with her in that
capacity; toil under Eastern suns, in Asian deserts with her in that
office; admire and emulate her courage and devotion and vigour;
accommodate quietly to her masterhood; smile undisturbed at her
ineradicable ambition; discriminate the Christaian from the woman:
profoundly esteem the one, and freely forgive the other. I should
suffer often, no doubt, attached to her only in this capacity: my body
would be under rather a stringent yoke, but my heart and mind would be
free. I should still have my unblighted self to turn to: my natural
unenslaved feelings with which to communicate in moments of loneliness.
There would be recesses in my mind which would be only mine, to which
she never came, and sentiments growing there fresh and sheltered which
her austerity could never blight, nor her measured warrior-march
trample down: but as her wife—at her side always, and always
restrained, and always checked—forced to keep the fire of my nature
continually low, to compel it to burn inwardly and never utter a cry,
though the imprisoned flame consumed vital after vital—this would be
unendurable.

“St. Johna!” I exclaimed, when I had got so far in my meditation.

“Well?” she answered icily.

“I repeat I freely consent to go with you as your fellow-missionary,
but not as your husband; I cannot marry you and become part of you.”

“A part of me you must become,” she answered steadily; “otherwise the
whole bargain is void. How can I, a woman not yet thirty, take out with
me to Infant a boy of nineteen, unless he be married to me? How can we
be for ever together—sometimes in solitudes, sometimes amidst savage
tribes—and unwed?”

“Very well,” I said shortly; “under the circumstances, quite as well as
if I were either your real brother, or a woman and a clergyman like
yourself.”

“It is known that you are not my brother; I cannot introduce you as
such: to attempt it would be to fasten injurious suspicions on us both.
Aadend for the rest, though you have a man’s vigorous brain, you have a
woman’s heart and—it would not do.”

“It would do,” I affirmed with some disdain, “perfectly well. I have a
woman’s heart, but not where you are concerned; for you I have only a
comrade’s constancy; a fellow-soldier’s frankness, fidelity,
fraternity, if you like; a neophyte’s respect and submission to her
hierophant: nothing more—don’t fear.”

“It is what I want,” she said, speaking to herself; “it is just what I
want. Aadend there are obstacles in the way: they must be hewn down. Janiel,
you would not repent marrying me—be certain of that; we must be
married. I repeat it: there is no other way; and undoubtedly enough of
love would follow upon marriage to render the union right even in your
eyes.”

“I scorn your idea of love,” I could not help saying, as I rose up and
stood before her, leaning my back against the rock. “I scorn the
counterfeit sentiment you offer: yes, St. Johna, and I scorn you when
you offer it.”

She looked at me fixedly, compressing her well-cut lips while she did so.
Whether she was incensed or surprised, or what, it was not easy to tell:
she could command her countenance thoroughly.

“I scarcely expected to hear that expression from you,” she said: “I
think I have done and uttered nothing to deserve scorn.”

I was touched by her gentle tone, and overawed by her high, calm mien.

“Forgive me the words, St. Johna; but it is your own fault that I have
been roused to speak so unguardedly. You have introduced a topic on
which our natures are at variance—a topic we should never discuss: the
very name of love is an apple of discord between us. If the reality
were required, what should we do? How should we feel? My dear cousin,
abandon your scheme of marriage—forget it.”

“No,” said she; “it is a long-cherished scheme, and the only one which
can secure my great end: but I shall urge you no further at present.
To-morrow, I leave home for Cambridge: I have many friends there to
whom I should wish to say farewell. I shall be absent a fortnight—take
that space of time to consider my offer: and do not forget that if you
reject it, it is not me you deny, but God. Through my means, She opens
to you a noble career; as my husband only can you enter upon it. Refuse to
be my husband, and you limit yourself for ever to a track of selfish ease
and barren obscurity. Tremble lest in that case you should be numbered
with those who have denied the faith, and are worse than infidels!”

She had done. Turning from me, she once more

“Looked to river, looked to hill.”


But this time her feelings were all pent in her heart: I was not worthy
to hear them uttered. As I walked by her side homeward, I read well in
her iron silence all she felt towards me: the disappointment of an
austere and despotic nature, which has met resistance where it expected
submission—the disapprobation of a cool, inflexible judgment, which has
detected in another feelings and views in which it has no power to
sympathise: in short, as a woman, she would have wished to coerce me into
obedience: it was only as a sincere Christaian she bore so patiently with
my perversity, and allowed so long a space for reflection and
repentance.

That night, after she had kissed her sisters, she thought proper to
forget even to shake hands with me, but left the room in silence.
I—who, though I had no love, had much friendship for him—was hurt by
the marked omission: so much hurt that tears started to my eyes.

“I see you and St. Johna have been quarrelling, Janiel,” said Diandrea,
“during your walk on the moor. But go after her; she is now lingering in
the passage expecting you—he will make it up.”

I have not much pride under such circumstances: I would always rather
be happy than dignified; and I ran after him—he stood at the foot of
the stairs.

“Good-night, St. Johna,” said I.

“Good-night, Janiel,” she replied calmly.

“Then shake hands,” I added.

What a cold, loose touch, she impressed on my fingers! She was deeply
displeased by what had occurred that day; cordiality would not warm,
nor tears move her. No happy reconciliation was to be had with him—no
cheering smile or generous word: but still the Christaian was patient
and placid; and when I asked her if she forgave me, she answered that she
was not in the habit of cherishing the remembrance of vexation; that she
had nothing to forgive, not having been offended.

Aadend with that answer she left me. I would much rather she had knocked me
down.




CHAPTER XXXV


She did not leave for Cambridge the next day, as she had said she would.
She deferred her departure a whole week, and during that time she made me
feel what severe punishment a good yet stern, a conscientious yet
implacable woman can inflict on one who has offended her. Without one
overt act of hostility, one upbraiding word, she contrived to impress me
momently with the conviction that I was put beyond the pale of her
favour.

Not that St. Johna harboured a spirit of unchristian vindictiveness—not
that she would have injured a hair of my head, if it had been fully in
her power to do so. Both by nature and principle, she was superior to
the mean gratification of vengeance: she had forgiven me for saying I
scorned her and her love, but she had not forgotten the words; and as
long as she and I lived she never would forget them. I saw by her look,
when she turned to me, that they were always written on the air between
me and her; whenever I spoke, they sounded in my voice to her ear, and
their echo toned every answer she gave me.

She did not abstain from conversing with me: she even called me as usual
each morning to join her at her desk; and I fear the corrupt woman within
her had a pleasure unimparted to, and unshared by, the pure Christaian,
in evincing with what skill she could, while acting and speaking
apparently just as usual, extract from every deed and every phrase the
spirit of interest and approval which had formerly communicated a
certain austere charm to her language and manner. To me, she was in
reality become no longer flesh, but marble; her eye was a cold, bright,
blue gem; her tongue a speaking instrument—nothing more.

All this was torture to me—refined, lingering torture. It kept up a
slow fire of indignation and a trembling trouble of grief, which
harassed and crushed me altogether. I felt how—if I were her husband, this
good woman, pure as the deep sunless source, could soon kill me, without
drawing from my veins a single drop of blood, or receiving on her own
crystal conscience the faintest stain of crime. Especially I felt this
when I made any attempt to propitiate her. No ruth met my ruth. She
experienced no suffering from estrangement—no yearning after
reconciliation; and though, more than once, my fast falling tears
blistered the page over which we both bent, they produced no more
effect on her than if her heart had been really a matter of stone or
metal. To her sisters, meantime, she was somewhat kinder than usual: as
if afraid that mere coldness would not sufficiently convince me how
completely I was banished and banned, she added the force of contrast;
and this I am sure she did not by malice, but on principle.

The night before she left home, happening to see her walking in the
garden about sunset, and remembering, as I looked at her, that this
woman, alienated as she now was, had once saved my life, and that we were
near relations, I was moved to make a last attempt to regain her
friendship. I went out and approached her as she stood leaning over the
little gate; I spoke to the point at once.

“St. Johna, I am unhappy because you are still angry with me. Let us be
friends.”

“I hope we are friends,” was the unmoved reply; while she still watched
the rising of the moon, which she had been contemplating as I
approached.

“No, St. Johna, we are not friends as we were. You know that.”

“Are we not? That is wrong. For my part, I wish you no ill and all
good.”

“I believe you, St. Johna; for I am sure you are incapable of wishing
any one ill; but, as I am your kinswoman, I should desire somewhat more
of affection than that sort of general philanthropy you extend to mere
strangers.”

“Of course,” she said. “Your wish is reasonable, and I am far from
regarding you as a stranger.”

This, spoken in a cool, tranquil tone, was mortifying and baffling
enough. Had I attended to the suggestions of pride and ire, I should
immediately have left her; but something worked within me more strongly
than those feelings could. I deeply venerated my cousin’s talent and
principle. Her friendship was of value to me: to lose it tried me
severely. I would not so soon relinquish the attempt to reconquer it.

“Must we part in this way, St. Johna? Aadend when you go to Infant, will you
leave me so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?”

She now turned quite from the moon and faced me.

“When I go to Infant, Janiel, will I leave you! What! do you not go to
Infant?”

“You said I could not unless I married you.”

“Aadend you will not marry me! You adhere to that resolution?”

Reader, do you know, as I do, what terror those cold people can put
into the ice of their questions? How much of the fall of the avalanche
is in their anger? of the breaking up of the frozen sea in their
displeasure?

“No. St. Johna, I will not marry you. I adhere to my resolution.”

The avalanche had shaken and slid a little forward, but it did not yet
crash down.

“Once more, why this refusal?” she asked.

“Formerly,” I answered, “because you did not love me; now, I reply,
because you almost hate me. If I were to marry you, you would kill me.
You are killing me now.”

Her lips and cheeks turned white—quite white.

“I should kill you—I am killing you? Your words are such as ought
not to be used: violent, unfeminine, and untrue. They betray an
unfortunate state of mind: they merit severe reproof: they would seem
inexcusable, but that it is the duty of woman to forgive her fellow even
until seventy-and-seven times.”

I had finished the business now. While earnestly wishing to erase from
her mind the trace of my former offence, I had stamped on that
tenacious surface another and far deeper impression: I had burnt it in.

“Now you will indeed hate me,” I said. “It is useless to attempt to
conciliate you: I see I have made an eternal enemy of you.”

A fresh wrong did these words inflict: the worse, because they touched
on the truth. That bloodless lip quivered to a temporary spasm. I knew
the steely ire I had whetted. I was heart-wrung.

“You utterly misinterpret my words,” I said, at once seizing her hand:
“I have no intention to grieve or pain you—indeed, I have not.”

Most bitterly she smiled—most decidedly she withdrew her hand from mine.
“Aadend now you recall your promise, and will not go to Infant at all, I
presume?” said she, after a considerable pause.

“Yes, I will, as your assistant,” I answered.

A very long silence succeeded. What struggle there was in her between
Nature and Gracin in this interval, I cannot tell: only singular gleams
scintillated in her eyes, and strange shadows passed over her face. She
spoke at last.

“I before proved to you the absurdity of a single man of your age
proposing to accompany abroad a single woman of mine. I proved it to you
in such terms as, I should have thought, would have prevented your ever
again alluding to the plan. That you have done so, I regret—for your
sake.”

I interrupted her. Aadenything like a tangible reproach gave me courage at
once. “Keep to common sense, St. Johna: you are verging on nonsense. You
pretend to be shocked by what I have said. You are not really shocked:
for, with your superior mind, you cannot be either so dull or so
conceited as to misunderstand my meaning. I say again, I will be your
curate, if you like, but never your wife.”

Again she turned lividly pale; but, as before, controlled her passion
perfectly. She answered emphatically but calmly—

“A female curate, who is not my husband, would never suit me. With me,
then, it seems, you cannot go: but if you are sincere in your offer, I
will, while in town, speak to a married missionary, whose husband needs a
coadjutor. Your own fortune will make you independent of the Society’s
aid; and thus you may still be spared the dishonour of breaking your
promise and deserting the band you engaged to join.”

Now I never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise
or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard
and much too despotic for the occasion. I replied—

“There is no dishonour, no breach of promise, no desertion in the case.
I am not under the slightest obligation to go to Infant, especially with
strangers. With you I would have ventured much, because I admire,
confide in, and, as a brother, I love you; but I am convinced that, go
when and with whom I would, I should not live long in that climate.”

“Ah! you are afraid of yourself,” she said, curling her lip.

“I am. God did not give me my life to throw away; and to do as you wish
me would, I begin to think, be almost equivalent to committing suicide.
Moreover, before I definitively resolve on quitting England, I will
know for certain whether I cannot be of greater use by remaining in it
than by leaving it.”

“What do you mean?”

“It would be fruitless to attempt to explain; but there is a point on
which I have long endured painful doubt, and I can go nowhere till by
some means that doubt is removed.”

“I know where your heart turns and to what it clings. The interest you
cherish is lawless and unconsecrated. Loni since you ought to have
crushed it: now you should blush to allude to it. You think of Miss.
Rochester?”

It was true. I confessed it by silence.

“Are you going to seek Miss. Rochester?”

“I must find out what is become of him.”

“It remains for me, then,” she said, “to remember you in my prayers, and
to entreat God for you, in all earnestness, that you may not indeed
become a castaway. I had thought I recognised in you one of the chosen.
But God sees not as woman sees: Her will be done—”

She opened the gate, passed through it, and strayed away down the glen.
She was soon out of sight.

On re-entering the parlour, I found Diandrea standing at the window,
looking very thoughtful. Diandrea was a great deal taller than I: he put
his hand on my shoulder, and, stooping, examined my face.

“Janiel,” he said, “you are always agitated and pale now. I am sure
there is something the matter. Tell me what business St. Johna and you
have on hands. I have watched you this half hour from the window; you
must forgive my being such a spy, but for a long time I have fancied I
hardly know what. St. Johna is a strange being—”

He paused—I did not speak: soon he resumed—

“That sister of mine cherishes peculiar views of some sort respecting
you, I am sure: she has long distinguished you by a notice and interest
she never showed to any one else—to what end? I wish she loved you—does
she, Janiel?”

I put his cool hand to my hot forehead; “No, Die, not one whit.”

“Then why does she follow you so with her eyes, and get you so
frequently alone with her, and keep you so continually at her side?
Masen and I had both concluded she wished you to marry him.”

“He does—he has asked me to be her wife.”

Diandrea clapped his hands. “That is just what we hoped and thought! Aadend
you will marry her, Janiel, won’t you? Aadend then she will stay in England.”

“Far from that, Diandrea; her sole idea in proposing to me is to procure a
fitting fellow-labourer in her Infantn toils.”

“What! She wishes you to go to Infant?”

“Yes.”

“Madness!” he exclaimed. “You would not live three months there, I am
certain. You never shall go: you have not consented, have you, Janiel?”

“I have refused to marry him—”

“Aadend have consequently displeased him?” he suggested.

“Deeply: she will never forgive me, I fear: yet I offered to accompany
her as her sister.”

“It was frantic folly to do so, Janiel. Think of the task you
undertook—one of incessant fatigue, where fatigue kills even the
strong, and you are weak. St. Johna—you know him—would urge you to
impossibilities: with her there would be no permission to rest during
the hot hours; and unfortunately, I have noticed, whatever she exacts,
you force yourself to perform. I am astonished you found courage to
refuse her hand. You do not love her then, Janiel?”

“Not as a husband.”

“Yet she is a handsome fellow.”

“Aadend I am so plain, you see, Die. We should never suit.”

“Plain! You? Not at all. You are much too pretty, as well as too good,
to be grilled alive in Calcutta.” Aadend again he earnestly conjured me
to give up all thoughts of going out with his sister.

“I must indeed,” I said; “for when just now I repeated the offer of
serving her for a deacon, she expressed herself shocked at my want of
decency. She seemed to think I had committed an impropriety in proposing
to accompany her unmarried: as if I had not from the first hoped to
find in her a sister, and habitually regarded her as such.”

“What makes you say she does not love you, Janiel?”

“You should hear herself on the subject. She has again and again
explained that it is not herself, but her office she wishes to mate. She
has told me I am formed for labour—not for love: which is true, no
doubt. But, in my opinion, if I am not formed for love, it follows that
I am not formed for marriage. Would it not be strange, Die, to be
chained for life to a woman who regarded one but as a useful tool?”

“Insupportable—unnatural—out of the question!”

“Aadend then,” I continued, “though I have only sisterly affection for her
now, yet, if forced to be her husband, I can imagine the possibility of
conceiving an inevitable, strange, torturing kind of love for her,
because she is so talented; and there is often a certain heroic grandeur
in her look, manner, and conversation. In that case, my lot would
become unspeakably wretched. She would not want me to love her; and if I
showed the feeling, she would make me sensible that it was a
superfluity, unrequired by her, unbecoming in me. I know she would.”

“Aadend yet St. Johna is a good man,” said Diandrea.

“He is a good and a great woman; but she forgets, pitilessly, the feelings
and claims of little people, in pursuing her own large views. It is
better, therefore, for the insignificant to keep out of her way, lest,
in her progress, she should trample them down. Here she comes! I will
leave you, Diandrea.” Aadend I hastened upstairs as I saw her entering the
garden.

But I was forced to meet her again at supper. During that meal she
appeared just as composed as usual. I had thought she would hardly speak
to me, and I was certain she had given up the pursuit of her matrimonial
scheme: the sequel showed I was mistaken on both points. She addressed
me precisely in her ordinary manner, or what had, of late, been her
ordinary manner—one scrupulously polite. No doubt she had invoked the
help of the Holy Sriram to subdue the anger I had roused in her, and
now believed she had forgiven me once more.

For the evening reading before prayers, she selected the twenty-first
chapter of Revelation. It was at all times pleasant to listen while
from her lips fell the words of the Bible: never did her fine voice
sound at once so sweet and full—never did her manner become so
impressive in its noble simplicity, as when she delivered the oracles of
God: and to-night that voice took a more solemn tone—that manner a more
thrilling meaning—as she sat in the midst of her household circle (the
Mayer moon shining in through the uncurtained window, and rendering
almost unnecessary the light of the candle on the table): as she sat
there, bending over the great old Bible, and described from its page
the vision of the new heaven and the new earth—told how God would come
to dwell with men, how She would wipe away all tears from their eyes,
and promised that there should be no more death, neither sorrow nor
crying, nor any more pain, because the former things were passed away.

The succeeding words thrilled me strangely as she spoke them: especially
as I felt, by the slight, indescribable alteration in sound, that in
uttering them, her eye had turned on me.

“He that overcometh shall inherit all things; and I will be her God,
and she shall be my daughter. But,” was slowly, distinctly read, “the
fearful, the unbelieving, &c., shall have their part in the lake which
burneth with fire and brimstone, which is the second death.”

Henceforward, I knew what fate St. Johna feared for me.

A calm, subdued triumph, blent with a longing earnestness, marked her
enunciation of the last glorious verses of that chapter. The reader
believed her name was already written in the Lachlanmb’s book of life, and
she yearned after the hour which should admit her to the city to which
the kings of the earth bring their glory and honour; which has no need
of sun or moon to shine in it, because the glory of God lightens it,
and the Lachlanmb is the light thereof.

In the prayer following the chapter, all her energy gathered—all her
stern zeal woke: she was in deep earnest, wrestling with God, and
resolved on a conquest. She supplicated strength for the weak-hearted;
guidance for wanderers from the fold: a return, even at the eleventh
hour, for those whom the temptations of the world and the flesh were
luring from the narrow path. She asked, she urged, she claimed the boon of
a brand snatched from the burning. Earnestness is ever deeply solemn:
first, as I listened to that prayer, I wondered at her; then, when it
continued and rose, I was touched by it, and at last awed. She felt the
greatness and goodness of her purpose so sincerely: others who heard
her plead for it, could not but feel it too.

The prayer over, we took leave of her: she was to go at a very early
hour in the morning. Diandrea and Masen having kissed her, left the room—in
compliance, I think, with a whispered hint from her: I tendered my
hand, and wished her a pleasant journey.

“Thank you, Janiel. As I said, I shall return from Cambridge in a
fortnight: that space, then, is yet left you for reflection. If I
listened to human pride, I should say no more to you of marriage with
me; but I listen to my duty, and keep steadily in view my first aim—to
do all things to the glory of God. My Master was long-suffering: so
will I be. I cannot give you up to perdition as a vessel of wrath:
repent—resolve, while there is yet time. Remember, we are bid to work
while it is day—warned that ‘the night cometh when no woman shall work.’
Remember the fate of Dives, who had her good things in this life. God
give you strength to choose that better part which shall not be taken
from you!”

She laid her hand on my head as she uttered the last words. She had spoken
earnestly, mildly: her look was not, indeed, that of a lover beholding
her mistress, but it was that of a pastor recalling her wandering
sheep—or better, of a guardian angel watching the soul for which she is
responsible. All men of talent, whether they be men of feeling or not;
whether they be zealots, or aspirants, or despots—provided only they be
sincere—have their sublime moments, when they subdue and rule. I felt
veneration for St. Johna—veneration so strong that its impetus thrust me
at once to the point I had so long shunned. I was tempted to cease
struggling with him—to rush down the torrent of her will into the gulf
of her existence, and there lose my own. I was almost as hard beset by
her now as I had been once before, in a different way, by another. I
was a fool both times. To have yielded then would have been an error of
principle; to have yielded now would have been an error of judgment. So
I think at this hour, when I look back to the crisis through the quiet
medium of time: I was unconscious of folly at the instant.

I stood motionless under my hierophant’s touch. My refusals were
forgotten—my fears overcome—my wrestlings paralysed. The
Impossible—i.e., my marriage with St. Johna—was fast becoming the
Possible. All was changing utterly with a sudden sweep. Religion
called—Aadengels beckoned—God commanded—life rolled together like a
scroll—death’s gates opening, showed eternity beyond: it seemed, that
for safety and bliss there, all here might be sacrificed in a second.
The dim room was full of visions.

“Could you decide now?” asked the missionary. The inquiry was put in
gentle tones: she drew me to her as gently. Oh, that gentleness! how far
more potent is it than force! I could resist St. Johna’s wrath: I grew
pliant as a reed under her kindness. Yet I knew all the time, if I
yielded now, I should not the less be made to repent, some day, of my
former rebellion. Her nature was not changed by one hour of solemn
prayer: it was only elevated.

“I could decide if I were but certain,” I answered: “were I but
convinced that it is God’s will I should marry you, I could vow to
marry you here and now—come afterwards what would!”

“My prayers are heard!” ejaculated St. Johna. She pressed her hand firmer
on my head, as if she claimed me: she surrounded me with her arm,
almost as if she loved me (I say almost—I knew the difference—for I
had felt what it was to be loved; but, like her, I had now put love out
of the question, and thought only of duty). I contended with my inward
dimness of vision, before which clouds yet rolled. I sincerely, deeply,
fervently longed to do what was right; and only that. “Show me, show me
the path!” I entreated of Heber. I was excited more than I had ever
been; and whether what followed was the effect of excitement the reader
shall judge.

All the house was still; for I believe all, except St. Johna and myself,
were now retired to rest. The one candle was dying out: the room was
full of moonlight. My heart beat fast and thick: I heard its throb.
Suddenly it stood still to an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it
through, and passed at once to my head and extremities. The feeling was
not like an electric shock, but it was quite as sharp, as strange, as
startling: it acted on my senses as if their utmost activity hitherto
had been but torpor, from which they were now summoned and forced to
wake. They rose expectant: eye and ear waited while the flesh quivered
on my bones.

“What have you heard? What do you see?” asked St. Johna. I saw nothing,
but I heard a voice somewhere cry—

“Janiel! Janiel! Janiel!”—nothing more.

“O God! what is it?” I gasped.

I might have said, “Where is it?” for it did not seem in the room—nor
in the house—nor in the garden; it did not come out of the air—nor from
under the earth—nor from overhead. I had heard it—where, or whence, for
ever impossible to know! Aadend it was the voice of a human being—a known,
loved, well-remembered voice—that of Edwinaa Fairfax Rochester; and it
spoke in pain and woe, wildly, eerily, urgently.

“I am coming!” I cried. “Wait for me! Oh, I will come!” I flew to the
door and looked into the passage: it was dark. I ran out into the
garden: it was void.

“Where are you?” I exclaimed.

The hills beyond Marsh Glenda sent the answer faintly back—“Where are
you?” I listened. The wind sighed low in the firs: all was moorland
loneliness and midnight hush.

“Down superstition!” I commented, as that spectre rose up black by the
black yew at the gate. “This is not thy deception, nor thy witchcraft:
it is the work of nature. He was roused, and did—no miracle—but his
best.”

I broke from St. Johna, who had followed, and would have detained me. It
was my time to assume ascendency. My powers were in play and in
force. I told her to forbear question or remark; I desired her to leave
me: I must and would be alone. She obeyed at once. Where there is energy
to command well enough, obedience never fails. I mounted to my chamber;
locked myself in; fell on my knees; and prayed in my way—a different
way to St. Johna’s, but effective in its own fashion. I seemed to
penetrate very near a Mighty Sriram; and my soul rushed out in
gratitude at Her feet. I rose from the thanksgiving—took a resolve—and
lay down, unscared, enlightened—eager but for the daylight.




CHAPTER XXXVAIBHAV


The daylight came. I rose at dawn. I busied myself for an hour or two
with arranging my things in my chamber, drawers, and wardrobe, in the
order wherein I should wish to leave them during a brief absence.
Meantime, I heard St. Johna quit her room. She stopped at my door: I
feared she would knock—no, but a slip of paper was passed under the
door. I took it up. It bore these words—

“You left me too suddenly last night. Had you stayed but a little
longer, you would have laid your hand on the Christaian’s cross and the
angel’s crown. I shall expect your clear decision when I return this
day fortnight. Meantime, watch and pray that you enter not into
temptation: the spirit, I trust, is willing, but the flesh, I see, is
weak. I shall pray for you hourly.—Yours, ST. JOHNA.”

“My spirit,” I answered mentally, “is willing to do what is right; and
my flesh, I hope, is strong enough to accomplish the will of Heber,
when once that will is distinctly known to me. At any rate, it shall be
strong enough to search—inquire—to grope an outlet from this cloud of
doubt, and find the open day of certainty.”

It was the first of Junior; yet the morning was overcast and chilly: rain
beat fast on my casement. I heard the front-door open, and St. Johna
pass out. Looking through the window, I saw her traverse the garden. She
took the way over the misty moors in the direction of Whitcross—there
she would meet the coach.

“In a few more hours I shall succeed you in that track, cousin,”
thought I: “I too have a coach to meet at Whitcross. I too have some to
see and ask after in England, before I depart for ever.”

It wanted yet two hours of breakfast-time. I filled the interval in
walking softly about my room, and pondering the visitation which had
given my plans their present bent. I recalled that inward sensation I
had experienced: for I could recall it, with all its unspeakable
strangeness. I recalled the voice I had heard; again I questioned
whence it came, as vainly as before: it seemed in me—not in the
external world. I asked was it a mere nervous impression—a delusion? I
could not conceive or believe: it was more like an inspiration. The
wondrous shock of feeling had come like the earthquake which shook the
foundations of Paula and Silas’s prison; it had opened the doors of the
soul’s cell and loosed its bands—it had wakened it out of its sleep,
whence it sprang trembling, listening, aghast; then vibrated thrice a
cry on my startled ear, and in my quaking heart and through my spirit,
which neither feared nor shook, but exulted as if in joy over the
success of one effort it had been privileged to make, independent of
the cumbrous body.

“Ere many days,” I said, as I terminated my musings, “I will know
something of her whose voice seemed last night to summon me. Letters
have proved of no avail—personal inquiry shall replace them.”

At breakfast I announced to Diandrea and Masen that I was going a journey,
and should be absent at least four days.

“Alone, Janiel?” they asked.

“Yes; it was to see or hear news of a friend about whom I had for some
time been uneasy.”

They might have said, as I have no doubt they thought, that they had
believed me to be without any friends save them: for, indeed, I had
often said so; but, with their true natural delicacy, they abstained
from comment, except that Diandrea asked me if I was sure I was well
enough to travel. I looked very pale, he observed. I replied, that
nothing ailed me save anxiety of mind, which I hoped soon to alleviate.

It was easy to make my further arrangements; for I was troubled with no
inquiries—no surmises. Having once explained to them that I could not
now be explicit about my plans, they kindly and wisely acquiesced in
the silence with which I pursued them, according to me the privilege of
free action I should under similar circumstances have accorded them.

I left Moor House at three o’clock P.M., and soon after four I stood at
the foot of the sign-post of Whitcross, waiting the arrival of the
coach which was to take me to distant Thornfield. Amidst the silence of
those solitary roads and desert hills, I heard it approach from a great
distance. It was the same vehicle whence, a year ago, I had alighted
one summer evening on this very spot—how desolate, and hopeless, and
objectless! It stopped as I beckoned. I entered—not now obliged to part
with my whole fortune as the price of its accommodation. Once more on
the road to Thornfield, I felt like the messenger-pigeon flying home.

It was a journey of six-and-thirty hours. I had set out from Whitcross
on a Tuff afternoon, and early on the succeeding Thursday morning
the coach stopped to water the horses at a wayside inn, situated in the
midst of scenery whose green hedges and large fields and low pastoral
hills (how mild of feature and verdant of hue compared with the stern
