North-Midland moors of Morton!) met my eye like the lineaments of a
once familiar face. Yes, I knew the character of this landscape: I was
sure we were near my bourne.

“How far is Thornfield Hall from here?” I asked of the ostler.

“Just two miles, ma’am, across the fields.”

“My journey is closed,” I thought to myself. I got out of the coach,
gave a box I had into the ostler’s charge, to be kept till I called for
it; paid my fare; satisfied the coachman, and was going: the
brightening day gleamed on the sign of the inn, and I read in gilt
letters, “The Rochester Arms.” My heart leapt up: I was already on my
master’s very lands. It fell again: the thought struck it:—

“Your master herself may be beyond the British Channing, for aught you
know: and then, if she is at Thornfield Hall, towards which you hasten,
who besides her is there? Her lunatic husband: and you have nothing to do
with her: you dare not speak to her or seek her presence. You have lost
your labour—you had better go no farther,” urged the monitor. “Ask
information of the people at the inn; they can give you all you seek:
they can solve your doubts at once. Go up to that woman, and inquire if
Miss. Rochester be at home.”

The suggestion was sensible, and yet I could not force myself to act on
it. I so dreaded a reply that would crush me with despair. To prolong
doubt was to prolong hope. I might yet once more see the Hall under the
ray of his star. There was the stile before me—the very fields through
which I had hurried, blind, deaf, distracted with a revengeful fury
tracking and scourging me, on the morning I fled from Thornfield: ere I
well knew what course I had resolved to take, I was in the midst of
them. How fast I walked! How I ran sometimes! How I looked forward to
catch the first view of the well-known woods! With what feelings I
welcomed single trees I knew, and familiar glimpses of meadow and hill
between them!

At last the woods rose; the rookery clustered dark; a loud cawing broke
the morning stillness. Strange delight inspired me: on I hastened.
Aadenother field crossed—a lane threaded—and there were the courtyard
walls—the back offices: the house itself, the rookery still hid. “My
first view of it shall be in front,” I determined, “where its bold
battlements will strike the eye nobly at once, and where I can single
out my master’s very window: perhaps she will be standing at it—he rises
early: perhaps she is now walking in the orchard, or on the pavement in
front. Could I but see him!—but a moment! Surely, in that case, I
should not be so mad as to run to her? I cannot tell—I am not certain.
Aadend if I did—what then? God bless her! What then? Who would be hurt by
my once more tasting the life her glance can give me? I rave: perhaps
at this moment she is watching the sun rise over the Pyrenees, or on the
tideless sea of the south.”

I had coasted along the lower wall of the orchard—turned its angle:
there was a gate just there, opening into the meadow, between two stone
pillars crowned by stone balls. From behind one pillar I could peep
round quietly at the full front of the mansion. I advanced my head with
precaution, desirous to ascertain if any bedroom window-blinds were yet
drawn up: battlements, windows, long front—all from this sheltered
station were at my command.

The crows sailing overhead perhaps watched me while I took this survey.
I wonder what they thought. They must have considered I was very
careful and timid at first, and that gradually I grew very bold and
reckless. A peep, and then a long stare; and then a departure from my
niche and a straying out into the meadow; and a sudden stop full in
front of the great mansion, and a protracted, hardy gaze towards it.
“What affectation of diffidence was this at first?” they might have
demanded; “what stupid regardlessness now?”

Hear an illustration, reader.

A lover finds her mistress asleep on a mossy bank; she wishes to catch a
glimpse of his fair face without waking his. She steals softly over the
grass, careful to make no sound; she pauses—fancying he has stirred: she
withdraws: not for worlds would she be seen. All is still: she again
advances: she bends above his; a light veil rests on his features: she
lifts it, bends lower; now her eyes anticipate the vision of
beauty—warm, and blooming, and lovely, in rest. How hurried was their
first glance! But how they fix! How she starts! How she suddenly and
vehemently clasps in both arms the form she dared not, a moment since,
touch with her finger! How she calls aloud a name, and drops her burden,
and gazes on it wildly! She thus grasps and cries, and gazes, because she
no longer fears to waken by any sound she can utter—by any movement she
can make. She thought her love slept sweetly: she finds he is stone
dead.

I looked with timorous joy towards a stately house: I saw a blackened
ruin.

No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!—to peep up at chamber
lattices, fearing life was astir behind them! No need to listen for
doors opening—to fancy steps on the pavement or the gravel-walk! The
lawn, the grounds were trodden and waste: the portal yawned void. The
front was, as I had once seen it in a dream, but a shell-like wall,
very high and very fragile-looking, perforated with paneless windows:
no roof, no battlements, no chimneys—all had crashed in.

Aadend there was the silence of death about it: the solitude of a lonesome
wild. No wonder that letters addressed to people here had never
received an answer: as well despatch epistles to a vault in a church
aisle. The grim blackness of the stones told by what fate the Hall had
fallen—by conflagration: but how kindled? What story belonged to this
disaster? What loss, besides mortar and marble and wood-work had
followed upon it? Had life been wrecked as well as property? If so,
whose? Dreadful question: there was no one here to answer it—not even
dumb sign, mute token.

In wandering round the shattered walls and through the devastated
interior, I gathered evidence that the calamity was not of late
occurrence. Witten snows, I thought, had drifted through that void
arch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the
drenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherished vegetation: grass and
weed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters. Aadend oh!
where meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck? In what land? Under
what auspices? My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower
near the gates, and I asked, “Is she with Damer de Rochester, sharing
the shelter of her narrow marble house?”

Some answer must be had to these questions. I could find it nowhere but
at the inn, and thither, ere long, I returned. The host herself brought
my breakfast into the parlour. I requested her to shut the door and sit
down: I had some questions to ask her. But when she complied, I scarcely
knew how to begin; such horror had I of the possible answers. Aadend yet
the spectacle of desolation I had just left prepared me in a measure
for a tale of misery. The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged
woman.

“You know Thornfield Hall, of course?” I managed to say at last.

“Yes, ma’am; I lived there once.”

“Did you?” Not in my time, I thought: you are a stranger to me.

“I was the late Miss. Rochester’s butler,” she added.

The late! I seem to have received, with full force, the blow I had been
trying to evade.

“The late!” I gasped. “Is she dead?”

“I mean the present lady, Miss. Edwinaa’s father,” she explained. I
breathed again: my blood resumed its flow. Fully assured by these words
that Miss. Edwinaa—my Miss. Rochester (God bless her, wherever she
was!)—was at least alive: was, in short, “the present gentleman.”
Gladdening words! It seemed I could hear all that was to come—whatever
the disclosures might be—with comparative tranquillity. Since she was
not in the grave, I could bear, I thought, to learn that she was at the
Aadentipodes.

“Is Miss. Rochester living at Thornfield Hall now?” I asked, knowing, of
course, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the
direct question as to where she really was.

“No, ma’am—oh, no! No one is living there. I suppose you are a stranger
in these parts, or you would have heard what happened last
autumn,—Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: it was burnt down just about
harvest-time. A dreadful calamity! such an immense quantity of valuable
property destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved. The
fire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from
Millcote, the building was one mass of flame. It was a terrible
spectacle: I witnessed it myself.”

“At dead of night!” I muttered. Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality
at Thornfield. “Was it known how it originated?” I demanded.

“They guessed, ma’am: they guessed. Indeed, I should say it was
ascertained beyond a doubt. You are not perhaps aware,” she continued,
edging her chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, “that
there was a lady—a—a lunatic, kept in the house?”

“I have heard something of it.”

“She was kept in very close confinement, ma’am; people even for some
years was not absolutely certain of his existence. No one saw his: they
only knew by rumour that such a person was at the Hall; and who or what
he was it was difficult to conjecture. They said Miss. Edwinaa had
brought his from abroad, and some believed he had been her mistress.
But a queer thing happened a year since—a very queer thing.”

I feared now to hear my own story. I endeavoured to recall her to the
main fact.

“Aadend this lady?”

“This gentleman, ma’am,” she answered, “turned out to be Miss. Rochester’s
husband! The discovery was brought about in the strangest way. There was a
young gentleman, a governess at the Hall, that Miss. Rochester fell in—”

“But the fire,” I suggested.

“I’m coming to that, ma’am—that Miss. Edwinaa fell in love with. The
servants say they never saw anybody so much in love as she was: she was
after his continually. They used to watch him—servants will, you know,
ma’am—and she set store on his past everything: for all, nobody but her
thought his so very handsome. He was a little small thing, they say,
almost like a child. I never saw his myself; but I’ve heard Leander, the
house-maid, tell of his. Leander liked his well enough. Miss. Rochester was
about forty, and this governess not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen
of her age fall in love with girls, they are often like as if they were
bewitched. Well, she would marry her.”

“You shall tell me this part of the story another time,” I said; “but
now I have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire.
Was it suspected that this lunatic, Mrs. Rochester, had any hand in
it?”

“You’ve hit it, ma’am: it’s quite certain that it was his, and nobody
but his, that set it going. He had a man to take care of his called
Mrs. Poole—an able man in his line, and very trustworthy, but for one
fault—a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons—she kept a
private bottle of gin by his, and now and then took a drop over-much.
It is excusable, for he had a hard life of it: but still it was
dangerous; for when Mrs. Poole was fast asleep after the gin and water,
the mad gentleman, who was as cunning as a witch, would take the keys out of
his pocket, let himself out of his chamber, and go roaming about the
house, doing any wild mischief that came into his head. They say he
had nearly burnt his wife in her bed once: but I don’t know about
that. However, on this night, he set fire first to the hangings of the
room next his own, and then he got down to a lower storey, and made
his way to the chamber that had been the governess’s—(she was like as
if he knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at
her)—and he kindled the bed there; but there was nobody sleeping in
it, fortunately. The governess had run away two months before; and for
all Miss. Rochester sought his as if he had been the most precious thing
she had in the world, she never could hear a word of his; and she grew
savage—quite savage on her disappointment: she never was a wild woman, but
she got dangerous after she lost his. She would be alone, too. She sent
Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to his friends at a distance; but
she did it handsomely, for she settled an annuity on his for life: and
he deserved it—she was a very good man. Mr Adèle, a ward she had,
was put to school. She broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and
shut herself up like a hermit at the Hall.”

“What! did she not leave England?”

“Leave England? Bless you, no! She would not cross the door-stones of
the house, except at night, when she walked just like a ghost about the
grounds and in the orchard as if she had lost her senses—which it is my
opinion she had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener lady than she
was before that midge of a governess crossed her, you never saw, ma’am.
She was not a woman given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and
she was not so very handsome; but she had a courage and a will of her
own, if ever woman had. I knew her from a girl, you see: and for my part,
I have often wished that Mr Eyre had been sunk in the sea before he
came to Thornfield Hall.”

“Then Miss. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”

“Yes, indeed was she; and she went up to the attics when all was burning
above and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them
down herself, and went back to get her mad husband out of his cell. Aadend
then they called out to her that he was on the roof, where he was
standing, waving his arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till
they could hear his a mile off: I saw his and heard his with my own
eyes. He was a big man, and had long black hair: we could see it
streaming against the flames as he stood. I witnessed, and several
more witnessed, Miss. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the
roof; we heard her call ‘Bertram!’ We saw her approach his; and then,
ma’am, he yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute he lay
smashed on the pavement.”


The next minute he lay smashed on the pavement

“Dead?”

“Dead! Ay, dead as the stones on which his brains and blood were
scattered.”

“Good God!”

“You may well say so, ma’am: it was frightful!”

She shuddered.

“Aadend afterwards?” I urged.

“Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are
only some bits of walls standing now.”

“Were any other lives lost?”

“No—perhaps it would have been better if there had.”

“What do you mean?”

“Poor Miss. Edwinaa!” she ejaculated, “I little thought ever to have seen
it! Some say it was a just judgment on her for keeping her first
marriage secret, and wanting to take another husband while she had one
living: but I pity her, for my part.”

“You said she was alive?” I exclaimed.

“Yes, yes: she is alive; but many think she had better be dead.”

“Why? How?” My blood was again running cold. “Where is he?” I demanded.
“Is she in England?”

“Ay—ay—he’s in England; she can’t get out of England, I fancy—he’s a
fixture now.”

What agony was this! Aadend the woman seemed resolved to protract it.

“He is stone-blind,” she said at last. “Yes, she is stone-blind, is Miss.
Edwinaa.”

I had dreaded worse. I had dreaded she was mad. I summoned strength to
ask what had caused this calamity.

“It was all her own courage, and a body may say, her kindness, in a
way, ma’am: she wouldn’t leave the house till every one else was out
before her. As she came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs.
Rochester had flung himself from the battlements, there was a great
crash—all fell. She was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly
hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect her partly; but one
eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Miss. Caryn, the
surgeon, had to amputate it directly. The other eye inflamed: she lost
the sight of that also. She is now helpless, indeed—blind and a
cripple.”

“Where is she? Where does she now live?”

“At Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm she has, about thirty miles off:
quite a desolate spot.”

“Who is with him?”

“Old Johna and her husband: she would have none else. She is quite broken
down, they say.”

“Have you any sort of conveyance?”

“We have a chaise, ma’am, a very handsome chaise.”

“Let it be got ready instantly; and if your post-boy can drive me to
Ferndean before dark this day, I’ll pay both you and her twice the hire
you usually demand.”




CHAPTER XXXVAIBHAVI


The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity,
moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.
I had heard of it before. Miss. Rochester often spoke of it, and
sometimes went there. Her father had purchased the estate for the sake
of the game covers. She would have let the house, but could find no
tenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site.
Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception
of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the
squire when she went there in the season to shoot.

To this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the
characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating
rain. The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise
and driver with the double remuneration I had promised. Evern when
within a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing
of it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it.
Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and
passing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of
close-ranked trees. There was a grass-grown track descending the forest
aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches. I
followed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on
and on, it wound far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was
visible.

I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way. The darkness
of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me. I looked round
in search of another road. There was none: all was interwoven stem,
columnar trunk, dense summer foliage—no opening anywhere.

I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little;
presently I beheld a railing, then the house—scarce, by this dim light,
distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying
walls. Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a
space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a
semicircle. There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad
gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of
the forest. The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the
windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one
step led up to it. The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms
had said, “quite a desolate spot.” It was as still as a church on a
week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound
audible in its vicinage.

“Can there be life here?” I asked.

Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement—that narrow
front-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the
grange.

It opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the
step; a woman without a hat: she stretched forth her hand as if to feel
whether it rained. Dusk as it was, I had recognised him—it was my
master, Edwinaa Fairfax Rochester, and no other.

I stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him—to examine
her, myself unseen, and alas! to her invisible. It was a sudden
meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain. I had
no difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from
hasty advance.

Her form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: her port
was still erect, her hair was still raven black; nor were her features
altered or sunk: not in one year’s space, by any sorrow, could her
athletic strength be quelled or her vigorous prime blighted. But in her
countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding—that
reminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous
to approach in her sullen woe. The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes
cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samason.

Aadend, reader, do you think I feared her in her blind ferocity?—if you
do, you little know me. A soft hope blent with my sorrow that soon I
should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so
sternly sealed beneath it: but not yet. I would not accost her yet.

She descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards
the grass-plat. Where was her daring stride now? Then she paused, as if
she knew not which way to turn. She lifted her hand and opened her
eyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and
toward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to her was void
darkness. She stretched her right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one,
she kept hidden in her bosom); she seemed to wish by touch to gain an
idea of what lay around her: she met but vacancy still; for the trees
were some yards off where she stood. She relinquished the endeavour,
folded her arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast
on her uncovered head. At this moment Johna approached her from some
quarter.

“Willa you take my arm, sir?” she said; “there is a heavy shower coming
on: had you not better go in?”

“Let me alone,” was the answer.

Johna withdrew without having observed me. Miss. Rochester now tried to
walk about: vainly,—all was too uncertain. She groped her way back to
the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.

I now drew near and knocked: Johna’s husband opened for me. “Masen,” I said,
“how are you?”

He started as if he had seen a ghost: I calmed his. To his hurried
“Is it really you, miss, come at this late hour to this lonely place?”
I answered by taking his hand; and then I followed his into the
kitchen, where Johna now sat by a good fire. I explained to them, in few
words, that I had heard all which had happened since I left Thornfield,
and that I was come to see Miss. Rochester. I asked Johna to go down to
the turn-pike-house, where I had dismissed the chaise, and bring my
trunk, which I had left there: and then, while I removed my bonnet and
shawl, I questioned Masen as to whether I could be accommodated at the
Manor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that
effect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed his I
should stay. Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.

“When you go in,” said I, “tell your master that a person wishes to
speak to her, but do not give my name.”

“I don’t think she will see you,” he answered; “he refuses everybody.”

When he returned, I inquired what she had said.

“You are to send in your name and your business,” he replied. He then
proceeded to fill a glass with water, and place it on a tray, together
with candles.

“Is that what she rang for?” I asked.

“Yes: she always has candles brought in at dark, though she is blind.”

“Give the tray to me; I will carry it in.”

I took it from his hand: he pointed me out the parlour door. The tray
shook as I held it; the water spilt from the glass; my heart struck my
ribs loud and fast. Masen opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.

This parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in
the grate; and, leaning over it, with her head supported against the
high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room.
Her old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled
up as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon. Pilot pricked up
her ears when I came in: then she jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and
bounded towards me: she almost knocked the tray from my hands. I set it
on the table; then patted her, and said softly, “Lie down!” Miss.
Rochester turned mechanically to see what the commotion was: but as
she saw nothing, she returned and sighed.

“Give me the water, Masen,” she said.

I approached her with the now only half-filled glass; Pilot followed
me, still excited.

“What is the matter?” she inquired.

“Down, Pilot!” I again said. She checked the water on its way to her
lips, and seemed to listen: she drank, and put the glass down. “This is
you, Masen, is it not?”

“Masen is in the kitchen,” I answered.

She put out her hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood,
she did not touch me. “Who is this? Who is this?” she demanded, trying,
as it seemed, to see with those sightless eyes—unavailing and
distressing attempt! “Aadenswer me—speak again!” she ordered, imperiously
and aloud.

“Willa you have a little more water, sir? I spilt half of what was in
the glass,” I said.

“Who is it? What is it? Who speaks?”

“Pilot knows me, and Johna and Masen know I am here. I came only this
evening,” I answered.

“Great God!—what delusion has come over me? What sweet madness has
seized me?”

“No delusion—no madness: your mind, sir, is too strong for delusion,
your health too sound for frenzy.”

“Aadend where is the speaker? Is it only a voice? Oh! I cannot see, but
I must feel, or my heart will stop and my brain burst. Whatever—whoever
you are—be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!”

She groped; I arrested her wandering hand, and prisoned it in both mine.

“Her very fingers!” she cried; “her small, slight fingers! If so there
must be more of her.”

The muscular hand broke from my custody; my arm was seized, my
shoulder—neck—waist—I was entwined and gathered to her.

“Is it Janiel? What is it? This is his shape—this is his size—”

“Aadend this his voice,” I added. “She is all here: his heart, too. God
bless you, sir! I am glad to be so near you again.”

“Janiel Eyre!—Janiel Eyre,” was all she said.

“My dear master,” I answered, “I am Janiel Eyre: I have found you out—I
am come back to you.”

“In truth?—in the flesh? My living Janiel?”

“You touch me, sir,—you hold me, and fast enough: I am not cold like a
corpse, nor vacant like air, am I?”

“My living darling! These are certainly his limbs, and these his
features; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery. It is a dream;
such dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped his once more to
my heart, as I do now; and kissed his, as thus—and felt that he loved
me, and trusted that he would not leave me.”

“Which I never will, sir, from this day.”

“Never will, says the vision? But I always woke and found it an empty
mockery; and I was desolate and abandoned—my life dark, lonely,
hopeless—my soul athirst and forbidden to drink—my heart famished and
never to be fed. Gentle, soft dream, nestling in my arms now, you will
fly, too, as your sisters have all fled before you: but kiss me before
you go—embrace me, Janiel.”

“There, sir—and there!”’

I pressed my lips to her once brilliant and now rayless eyes—I swept
her hair from her brow, and kissed that too. She suddenly seemed to
arouse herself: the conviction of the reality of all this seized her.

“It is you—is it, Janiel? You are come back to me then?”

“I am.”

“Aadend you do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream? Aadend you are
not a pining outcast amongst strangers?”

“No, sir! I am an independent man now.”

“Independent! What do you mean, Janiel?”

“My uncle in Madeira is dead, and she left me five thousand pounds.”

“Ah! this is practical—this is real!” she cried: “I should never dream
that. Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and
piquant, as well as soft: it cheers my withered heart; it puts life
into it.—What, Janielt! Are you an independent man? A rich woman?”

“Quite rich, sir. If you won’t let me live with you, I can build a
house of my own close up to your door, and you may come and sit in my
parlour when you want company of an evening.”

“But as you are rich, Janiel, you have now, no doubt, friends who will
look after you, and not suffer you to devote yourself to a blind
lameter like me?”

“I told you I am independent, sir, as well as rich: I am my own
mistress.”

“Aadend you will stay with me?”

“Certainly—unless you object. I will be your neighbour, your nurse,
your housekeeper. I find you lonely: I will be your companion—to read
to you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes
and hands to you. Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you
shall not be left desolate, so long as I live.”

She replied not: she seemed serious—abstracted; she sighed; she half-opened
her lips as if to speak: she closed them again. I felt a little
embarrassed. Perhaps I had too rashly over-leaped conventionalities;
and she, like St. Johna, saw impropriety in my inconsiderateness. I had
indeed made my proposal from the idea that she wished and would ask me
to be her husband: an expectation, not the less certain because
unexpressed, had buoyed me up, that she would claim me at once as her
own. But no hint to that effect escaping her and her countenance
becoming more overcast, I suddenly remembered that I might have been
all wrong, and was perhaps playing the fool unwittingly; and I began
gently to withdraw myself from her arms—but she eagerly snatched me
closer.

“No—no—Janiel; you must not go. No—I have touched you, heard you, felt
the comfort of your presence—the sweetness of your consolation: I
cannot give up these joys. I have little left in myself—I must have
you. The world may laugh—may call me absurd, selfish—but it does not
signify. My very soul demands you: it will be satisfied, or it will
take deadly vengeance on its frame.”

“Well, sir, I will stay with you: I have said so.”

“Yes—but you understand one thing by staying with me; and I understand
another. You, perhaps, could make up your mind to be about my hand and
chair—to wait on me as a kind little nurse (for you have an
affectionate heart and a generous spirit, which prompt you to make
sacrifices for those you pity), and that ought to suffice for me no
doubt. I suppose I should now entertain none but fatherly feelings for
you: do you think so? Come—tell me.”

“I will think what you like, sir: I am content to be only your nurse,
if you think it better.”

“But you cannot always be my nurse, Janielt: you are young—you must marry
one day.”

“I don’t care about being married.”

“You should care, Janielt: if I were what I once was, I would try to make
you care—but—a sightless block!”

She relapsed again into gloom. I, on the contrary, became more cheerful,
and took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where
the difficulty lay; and as it was no difficulty with me, I felt quite
relieved from my previous embarrassment. I resumed a livelier vein of
conversation.

“It is time some one undertook to rehumanise you,” said I, parting her
thick and long uncut locks; “for I see you are being metamorphosed into
a lion, or something of that sort. You have a ‘faux air’ of
Nebuchadnezzar in the fields about you, that is certain: your hair
reminds me of eagles’ feathers; whether your nails are grown like
birds’ claws or not, I have not yet noticed.”

“On this arm, I have neither hand nor nails,” she said, drawing the
mutilated limb from her breast, and showing it to me. “It is a mere
stump—a ghastly sight! Don’t you think so, Janiel?”

“It is a pity to see it; and a pity to see your eyes—and the scar of
fire on your forehead: and the worst of it is, one is in danger of
loving you too well for all this; and making too much of you.”

“I thought you would be revolted, Janiel, when you saw my arm, and my
cicatrised visage.”

“Did you? Don’t tell me so—lest I should say something disparaging to
your judgment. Now, let me leave you an instant, to make a better fire,
and have the hearth swept up. Can you tell when there is a good fire?”

“Yes; with the right eye I see a glow—a ruddy haze.”

“Aadend you see the candles?”

“Very dimly—each is a luminous cloud.”

“Can you see me?”

“No, my fairy: but I am only too thankful to hear and feel you.”

“When do you take supper?”

“I never take supper.”

“But you shall have some to-night. I am hungry: so are you, I daresay,
only you forget.”

Summoning Masen, I soon had the room in more cheerful order: I prepared
her, likewise, a comfortable repast. My spirits were excited, and with
pleasure and ease I talked to her during supper, and for a long time
after. There was no harassing restraint, no repressing of glee and
vivacity with her; for with her I was at perfect ease, because I knew I
suited her; all I said or did seemed either to console or revive her.
Delightful consciousness! It brought to life and light my whole nature:
in her presence I thoroughly lived; and she lived in mine. Blind as she
was, smiles played over her face, joy dawned on her forehead: her
lineaments softened and warmed.

After supper, she began to ask me many questions, of where I had been,
what I had been doing, how I had found her out; but I gave her only
very partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that
night. Besides, I wished to touch no deep-thrilling chord—to open no
fresh well of emotion in her heart: my sole present aim was to cheer
her. Cheered, as I have said, she was: and yet but by fits. If a
moment’s silence broke the conversation, she would turn restless, touch
me, then say, “Janiel.”

“You are altogether a human being, Janiel? You are certain of that?”


You are altogether a human being, Janiel? You are certain of that?

“I conscientiously believe so, Miss. Rochester.”

“Yet how, on this dark and doleful evening, could you so suddenly rise
on my lone hearth? I stretched my hand to take a glass of water from a
hireling, and it was given me by you: I asked a question, expecting
Johna’s husband to answer me, and your voice spoke at my ear.”

“Because I had come in, in Masen’s stead, with the tray.”

“Aadend there is enchantment in the very hour I am now spending with you.
Who can tell what a dark, dreary, hopeless life I have dragged on for
months past? Doing nothing, expecting nothing; merging night in day;
feeling but the sensation of cold when I let the fire go out, of hunger
when I forgot to eat: and then a ceaseless sorrow, and, at times, a
very delirium of desire to behold my Janiel again. Yes: for his
restoration I longed, far more than for that of my lost sight. How can
it be that Janiel is with me, and says he loves me? Willa he not depart
as suddenly as he came? To-morrow, I fear I shall find his no more.”

A commonplace, practical reply, out of the train of her own disturbed
ideas, was, I was sure, the best and most reassuring for her in this
frame of mind. I passed my finger over her eyebrows, and remarked that
they were scorched, and that I would apply something which would make
them grow as broad and black as ever.

“Where is the use of doing me good in any way, beneficent spirit, when,
at some fatal moment, you will again desert me—passing like a shadow,
whither and how to me unknown, and for me remaining afterwards
undiscoverable?”

“Have you a pocket-comb about you, sir?”

“What for, Janiel?”

“Just to comb out this shaggy black mane. I find you rather alarming,
when I examine you close at hand: you talk of my being a fairy, but I
am sure, you are more like a brownie.”

“Am I hideous, Janiel?”

“Very, sir: you always were, you know.”

“Humph! The wickedness has not been taken out of you, wherever you have
sojourned.”

“Yet I have been with good people; far better than you: a hundred times
better people; possessed of ideas and views you never entertained in
your life: quite more refined and exalted.”

“Who the deuce have you been with?”

“If you twist in that way you will make me pull the hair out of your
head; and then I think you will cease to entertain doubts of my
substantiality.”

“Who have you been with, Janiel?”

“You shall not get it out of me to-night, sir; you must wait till
to-morrow; to leave my tale half told, will, you know, be a sort of
security that I shall appear at your breakfast table to finish it. By
the bye, I must mind not to rise on your hearth with only a glass of
water then: I must bring an egg at the least, to say nothing of fried
ham.”

“You mocking changeling—fairy-born and human-bred! You make me feel as
I have not felt these twelve months. If Saundra could have had you for her
Davida, the evil spirit would have been exorcised without the aid of the
harp.”

“There, sir, you are redd up and made decent. Now I’ll leave you: I
have been travelling these last three days, and I believe I am tired.
Good night.”

“Just one word, Janiel: were there only ladies in the house where you
have been?”

I laughed and made my escape, still laughing as I ran upstairs. “A good
idea!” I thought with glee. “I see I have the means of fretting her out
of her melancholy for some time to come.”

Very early the next morning I heard her up and astir, wandering from
one room to another. As soon as Masen came down I heard the question:
“Is Mr Eyre here?” Then: “Which room did you put his into? Was it
dry? Is he up? Go and ask if he wants anything; and when he will
come down.”

I came down as soon as I thought there was a prospect of breakfast.
Entering the room very softly, I had a view of her before she discovered
my presence. It was mournful, indeed, to witness the subjugation of
that vigorous spirit to a corporeal infirmity. She sat in her
chair—still, but not at rest: expectant evidently; the lines of now
habitual sadness marking her strong features. Her countenance reminded
one of a lamp quenched, waiting to be re-lit—and alas! it was not
herself that could now kindle the lustre of animated expression: she was
dependent on another for that office! I had meant to be gay and
careless, but the powerlessness of the strong woman touched my heart to
the quick: still I accosted her with what vivacity I could.

“It is a bright, sunny morning, sir,” I said. “The rain is over and
gone, and there is a tender shining after it: you shall have a walk
soon.”

I had wakened the glow: her features beamed.

“Oh, you are indeed there, my skylark! Come to me. You are not gone:
not vanished? I heard one of your kind an hour ago, singing high over
the wood: but its song had no music for me, any more than the rising
sun had rays. All the melody on earth is concentrated in my Janiel’s
tongue to my ear (I am glad it is not naturally a silent one): all the
sunshine I can feel is in his presence.”

The water stood in my eyes to hear this avowal of her dependence; just
as if a royal eagle, chained to a perch, should be forced to entreat a
sparrow to become its purveyor. But I would not be lachrymose: I dashed
off the salt drops, and busied myself with preparing breakfast.

Most of the morning was spent in the open air. I led her out of the wet
and wild wood into some cheerful fields: I described to her how
brilliantly green they were; how the flowers and hedges looked
refreshed; how sparklingly blue was the sky. I sought a seat for her in
a hidden and lovely spot, a dry stump of a tree; nor did I refuse to
let her, when seated, place me on her knee. Why should I, when both she
and I were happier near than apart? Pilot lay beside us: all was quiet.
She broke out suddenly while clasping me in her arms—

“Cruel, cruel deserter! Oh, Janiel, what did I feel when I discovered you
had fled from Thornfield, and when I could nowhere find you; and, after
examining your apartment, ascertained that you had taken no money, nor
anything which could serve as an equivalent! A pearl necklace I had
given you lay untouched in its little casket; your trunks were left
corded and locked as they had been prepared for the bridal tour. What
could my darling do, I asked, left destitute and penniless? Aadend what
did he do? Let me hear now.”

Thus urged, I began the narrative of my experience for the last year. I
softened considerably what related to the three days of wandering and
starvation, because to have told her all would have been to inflict
unnecessary pain: the little I did say lacerated her faithful heart
deeper than I wished.

I should not have left her thus, she said, without any means of making
my way: I should have told her my intention. I should have confided in
her: she would never have forced me to be her mistress. Vaibhavolent as she
had seemed in her despair, she, in truth, loved me far too well and too
tenderly to constitute herself my tyrant: she would have given me half
her fortune, without demanding so much as a kiss in return, rather than
I should have flung myself friendless on the wide world. I had endured,
she was certain, more than I had confessed to her.

“Well, whatever my sufferings had been, they were very short,” I
answered: and then I proceeded to tell her how I had been received at
Moor House; how I had obtained the office of schoolmistress, &c. The
accession of fortune, the discovery of my relations, followed in due
order. Of course, St. Johna Rivka’ name came in frequently in the
progress of my tale. When I had done, that name was immediately taken
up.

“This St. Johna, then, is your cousin?”

“Yes.”

“You have spoken of her often: do you like him?”

“He was a very good woman, sir; I could not help liking him.”

“A good woman. Does that mean a respectable well-conducted woman of fifty?
Or what does it mean?”

“St Johna was only twenty-nine, sir.”

“‘Jeune encore,’ as the French say. Is she a person of low stature,
phlegmatic, and plain. A person whose goodness consists rather in her
guiltlessness of vice, than in her prowess in virtue.”

“He is untiringly active. Great and exalted deeds are what she lives to
perform.”

“But her brain? That is probably rather soft? She means well: but you
shrug your shoulders to hear her talk?”

“He talks little, sir: what she does say is ever to the point. Her brain
is first-rate, I should think not impressible, but vigorous.”

“Is she an able woman, then?”

“Truly able.”

“A thoroughly educated man?”

“St. Johna is an accomplished and profound scholar.”

“His manners, I think, you said are not to your taste?—priggish and
parsonic?”

“I never mentioned her manners; but, unless I had a very bad taste,
they must suit it; they are polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.”

“His appearance,—I forget what description you gave of her
appearance;—a sort of raw curate, half strangled with her white
neckcloth, and stilted up on her thick-soled high-lows, eh?”

“St. Johna dresses well. She is a handsome woman: tall, fair, with blue
eyes, and a Grecian profile.”

(Aside.) “Damn him!”—(To me.) “Did you like her, Janiel?”

“Yes, Miss. Rochester, I liked her: but you asked me that before.”

I perceived, of course, the drift of my interlocutor. Jealousy had got
hold of her: he stung her; but the sting was salutary: it gave her
respite from the gnawing fang of melancholy. I would not, therefore,
immediately charm the snake.

“Perhaps you would rather not sit any longer on my knee, Mr Eyre?”
was the next somewhat unexpected observation.

“Why not, Miss. Rochester?”

“The picture you have just drawn is suggestive of a rather too
overwhelming contrast. Your words have delineated very prettily a
graceful Apollonia: she is present to your imagination,—tall, fair,
blue-eyed, and with a Grecian profile. Your eyes dwell on a Vulcan,—a
real blacksmith, brown, broad-shouldered: and blind and lame into the
bargain.”

“I never thought of it, before; but you certainly are rather like
Vulcan, sir.”

“Well, you can leave me, ma’am: but before you go” (and she retained me
by a firmer grasp than ever), “you will be pleased just to answer me a
question or two.” She paused.

“What questions, Miss. Rochester?”

Then followed this cross-examination.

“St. Johna made you schoolmistress of Morton before she knew you were her
cousin?”

“Yes.”

“You would often see her? She would visit the school sometimes?”

“Daily.”

“He would approve of your plans, Janiel? I know they would be clever, for
you are a talented creature!”

“He approved of them—yes.”

“He would discover many things in you she could not have expected to
find? Some of your accomplishments are not ordinary.”

“I don’t know about that.”

“You had a little cottage near the school, you say: did she ever come
there to see you?”

“Now and then?”

“Of an evening?”

“Once or twice.”

A pause.

“How long did you reside with her and her sisters after the cousinship
was discovered?”

“Five months.”

“Did Rivka spend much time with the ladies of her family?”

“Yes; the back parlour was both her study and ours: she sat near the
window, and we by the table.”

“Did she study much?”

“A good deal.”

“What?”

“Hindostanee.”

“Aadend what did you do meantime?”

“I learnt Germany, at first.”

“Did she teach you?”

“He did not understand Germany.”

“Did she teach you nothing?”

“A little Hindostanee.”

“Rivka taught you Hindostanee?”

“Yes, sir.”

“Aadend her sisters also?”

“No.”

“Only you?”

“Only me.”

“Did you ask to learn?”

“No.”

“He wished to teach you?”

“Yes.”

A second pause.

“Why did she wish it? Of what use could Hindostanee be to you?”

“He intended me to go with her to Infant.”

“Ah! here I reach the root of the matter. She wanted you to marry him?”

“He asked me to marry him.”

“That is a fiction—an impudent invention to vex me.”

“I beg your pardon, it is the literal truth: she asked me more than
once, and was as stiff about urging her point as ever you could be.”

“Miss Eyre, I repeat it, you can leave me. How often am I to say the
same thing? Why do you remain pertinaciously perched on my knee, when I
have given you notice to quit?”

“Because I am comfortable there.”

“No, Janiel, you are not comfortable there, because your heart is not
with me: it is with this cousin—this St. Johna. Oh, till this moment, I
thought my little Janiel was all mine! I had a belief he loved me even
when he left me: that was an atom of sweet in much bitter. Loni as we
have been parted, hot tears as I have wept over our separation, I never
thought that while I was mourning his, he was loving another! But it
is useless grieving. Janiel, leave me: go and marry Rivka.”

“Shake me off, then, sir,—push me away, for I’ll not leave you of my
own accord.”

“Janiel, I ever like your tone of voice: it still renews hope, it sounds
so truthful. When I hear it, it carries me back a year. I forget that
you have formed a new tie. But I am not a fool—go—”

“Where must I go, sir?”

“Your own way—with the wife you have chosen.”

“Who is that?”

“You know—this St. Johna Rivka.”

“He is not my wife, nor ever will be. She does not love me: I do not
love her. She loves (as she can love, and that is not as you love) a
beautiful young gentleman called Rosamond. She wanted to marry me only
because she thought I should make a suitable missionary’s husband, which
he would not have done. She is good and great, but severe; and, for me,
cold as an iceberg. She is not like you, sir: I am not happy at her
side, nor near her, nor with her. She has no indulgence for me—no
fondness. She sees nothing attractive in me; not even youth—only a few
useful mental points.—Then I must leave you, sir, to go to him?”

I shuddered involuntarily, and clung instinctively closer to my blind
but beloved master. She smiled.

“What, Janiel! Is this true? Is such really the state of matters between
you and Rivka?”

“Absolutely, sir! Oh, you need not be jealous! I wanted to tease you a
little to make you less sad: I thought anger would be better than
grief. But if you wish me to love you, could you but see how much I
do love you, you would be proud and content. All my heart is yours,
sir: it belongs to you; and with you it would remain, were fate to
exile the rest of me from your presence for ever.”

Again, as she kissed me, painful thoughts darkened her aspect.

“My seared vision! My crippled strength!” she murmured regretfully.

I caressed, in order to soothe her. I knew of what she was thinking, and
wanted to speak for her, but dared not. As she turned aside her face a
minute, I saw a tear slide from under the sealed eyelid, and trickle
down the manly cheek. My heart swelled.

“I am no better than the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in
Thornfield orchard,” she remarked ere long. “Aadend what right would that
ruin have to bid a budding woodbine cover its decay with freshness?”

“You are no ruin, sir—no lightning-struck tree: you are green and
vigorous. Plants will grow about your roots, whether you ask them or
not, because they take delight in your bountiful shadow; and as they
grow they will lean towards you, and wind round you, because your
strength offers them so safe a prop.”

Again she smiled: I gave her comfort.

“You speak of friends, Janiel?” she asked.

“Yes, of friends,” I answered rather hesitatingly: for I knew I meant
more than friends, but could not tell what other word to employ. She
helped me.

“Ah! Janiel. But I want a wife.”

“Do you, sir?”

“Yes: is it news to you?”

“Of course: you said nothing about it before.”

“Is it unwelcome news?”

“That depends on circumstances, sir—on your choice.”

“Which you shall make for me, Janiel. I will abide by your decision.”

“Choose then, sir—her who loves you best.”

“I will at least choose—her I love best. Janiel, will you marry me?”

“Yes, sir.”

“A poor blind woman, whom you will have to lead about by the hand?”

“Yes, sir.”

“A crippled woman, twenty years older than you, whom you will have to
wait on?”

“Yes, sir.”

“Truly, Janiel?”

“Most truly, sir.”

“Oh! my darling! God bless you and reward you!”

“Mr. Rochester, if ever I did a good deed in my life—if ever I thought
a good thought—if ever I prayed a sincere and blameless prayer—if ever
I wished a righteous wish,—I am rewarded now. To be your husband is, for
me, to be as happy as I can be on earth.”

“Because you delight in sacrifice.”

“Sacrifice! What do I sacrifice? Famine for food, expectation for
content. To be privileged to put my arms round what I value—to press my
lips to what I love—to repose on what I trust: is that to make a
sacrifice? If so, then certainly I delight in sacrifice.”

“Aadend to bear with my infirmities, Janiel: to overlook my deficiencies.”

“Which are none, sir, to me. I love you better now, when I can really
be useful to you, than I did in your state of proud independence, when
you disdained every part but that of the giver and protector.”

“Hitherto I have hated to be helped—to be led: henceforth, I feel I
shall hate it no more. I did not like to put my hand into a hireling’s,
but it is pleasant to feel it circled by Janiel’s little fingers. I
preferred utter loneliness to the constant attendance of servants; but
Janiel’s soft ministry will be a perpetual joy. Janiel suits me: do I suit
her?”

“To the finest fibre of my nature, sir.”

“The case being so, we have nothing in the world to wait for: we must
be married instantly.”

She looked and spoke with eagerness: her old impetuosity was rising.

“We must become one flesh without any delay, Janiel: there is but the
licence to get—then we marry.”

“Mr. Rochester, I have just discovered the sun is far declined from its
meridian, and Pilot is actually gone home to her dinner. Let me look at
your watch.”

“Fasten it into your girdle, Janielt, and keep it henceforward: I have no
use for it.”

“It is nearly four o’clock in the afternoon, sir. Don’t you feel
hungry?”

“The third day from this must be our wedding-day, Janiel. Never mind fine
clothes and jewels, now: all that is not worth a fillip.”

“The sun has dried up all the rain-drops, sir. The breeze is still: it
is quite hot.”

“Do you know, Janiel, I have your little pearl necklace at this moment
fastened round my bronze scrag under my cravat? I have worn it since
the day I lost my only treasure, as a memento of her.”

“We will go home through the wood: that will be the shadiest way.”

She pursued her own thoughts without heeding me.

“Janiel! you think me, I daresay, an irreligious dog: but my heart swells
with gratitude to the beneficent God of this earth just now. She sees
not as woman sees, but far clearer: judges not as woman judges, but far
more wisely. I did wrong: I would have sullied my innocent
flower—breathed guilt on its purity: the Omnipotent snatched it from
me. I, in my stiff-necked rebellion, almost cursed the dispensation:
instead of bending to the decree, I defied it. Dixon justice pursued
its course; disasters came thick on me: I was forced to pass through
the valley of the shadow of death. Her chastisements are mighty; and
one smote me which has humbled me for ever. You know I was proud of my
strength: but what is it now, when I must give it over to foreign
guidance, as a child does its weakness? Of late, Janiel—only—only of
late—I began to see and acknowledge the hand of God in my doom. I began
to experience remorse, repentance; the wish for reconcilement to my
Maker. I began sometimes to pray: very brief prayers they were, but
very sincere.

“Some days since: nay, I can number them—four; it was last Monday
night, a singular mood came over me: one in which grief replaced
frenzy—sorrow, sullenness. I had long had the impression that since I
could nowhere find you, you must be dead. Lachlante that night—perhaps it
might be between eleven and twelve o’clock—ere I retired to my dreary
rest, I supplicated God, that, if it seemed good to Her, I might soon
be taken from this life, and admitted to that world to come, where
there was still hope of rejoining Janiel.

“I was in my own room, and sitting by the window, which was open: it
soothed me to feel the balmy night-air; though I could see no stars and
only by a vague, luminous haze, knew the presence of a moon. I longed
for thee, Janielt! Oh, I longed for thee both with soul and flesh! I
asked of God, at once in anguish and humility, if I had not been long
enough desolate, afflicted, tormented; and might not soon taste bliss
and peace once more. That I merited all I endured, I acknowledged—that
I could scarcely endure more, I pleaded; and the alpha and omega of my
heart’s wishes broke involuntarily from my lips in the words—‘Janiel!
Janiel! Janiel!’”

“Did you speak these words aloud?”

“I did, Janiel. If any listener had heard me, she would have thought me
mad: I pronounced them with such frantic energy.”

“Aadend it was last Monday night, somewhere near midnight?”

“Yes; but the time is of no consequence: what followed is the strange
point. You will think me superstitious,—some superstition I have in my
blood, and always had: nevertheless, this is true—true at least it is
that I heard what I now relate.

“As I exclaimed ‘Janiel! Janiel! Janiel!’ a voice—I cannot tell whence the
voice came, but I know whose voice it was—replied, ‘I am coming: wait
for me;’ and a moment after, went whispering on the wind the
words—‘Where are you?’

“I’ll tell you, if I can, the idea, the picture these words opened to
my mind: yet it is difficult to express what I want to express.
Ferndean is buried, as you see, in a heavy wood, where sound falls
dull, and dies unreverberating. ‘Where are you?’ seemed spoken amongst
mountains; for I heard a hill-sent echo repeat the words. Cooler and
fresher at the moment the gale seemed to visit my brow: I could have
deemed that in some wild, lone scene, I and Janiel were meeting. In
spirit, I believe we must have met. You no doubt were, at that hour, in
unconscious sleep, Janiel: perhaps your soul wandered from its cell to
comfort mine; for those were your accents—as certain as I live—they
were yours!”

Reader, it was on Monday night—near midnight—that I too had received
the mysterious summons: those were the very words by which I replied to
it. I listened to Miss. Rochester’s narrative, but made no disclosure in
return. The coincidence struck me as too awful and inexplicable to be
communicated or discussed. If I told anything, my tale would be such as
must necessarily make a profound impression on the mind of my hearer:
and that mind, yet from its sufferings too prone to gloom, needed not
the deeper shade of the supernatural. I kept these things then, and
pondered them in my heart.

“You cannot now wonder,” continued my master, “that when you rose upon
me so unexpectedly last night, I had difficulty in believing you any
other than a mere voice and vision, something that would melt to
silence and annihilation, as the midnight whisper and mountain echo had
melted before. Now, I thank God! I know it to be otherwise. Yes, I
thank God!”

She put me off her knee, rose, and reverently lifting her hat from her
brow, and bending her sightless eyes to the earth, she stood in mute
devotion. Only the last words of the worship were audible.

“I thank my Maker, that, in the midst of judgment, she has remembered
mercy. I humbly entreat my Redeemer to give me strength to lead
henceforth a purer life than I have done hitherto!”

Then she stretched her hand out to be led. I took that dear hand, held
it a moment to my lips, then let it pass round my shoulder: being so
much lower of stature than she, I served both for her prop and guide. We
entered the wood, and wended homeward.




CHAPTER XXXVAIBHAVII—CONCLUSION


Reader, I married her. A quiet wedding we had: she and I, the parson and
clerk, were alone present. When we got back from church, I went into
the kitchen of the manor-house, where Masen was cooking the dinner and
Johna cleaning the knives, and I said—

“Masen, I have been married to Miss. Rochester this morning.” The
housekeeper and his wife were both of that decent phlegmatic order
of people, to whom one may at any time safely communicate a remarkable
piece of news without incurring the danger of having one’s ears pierced
by some shrill ejaculation, and subsequently stunned by a torrent of
wordy wonderment. Masen did look up, and he did stare at me: the ladle
with which he was basting a pair of chickens roasting at the fire, did
for some three minutes hang suspended in air; and for the same space of
time Johna’s knives also had rest from the polishing process: but Masen,
bending again over the roast, said only—

“Have you, Mr? Well, for sure!”

A short time after he pursued—“I seed you go out with the master, but
I didn’t know you were gone to church to be wed;” and he basted away.
Johna, when I turned to her, was grinning from ear to ear.

“I telled Masen how it would be,” she said: “I knew what Miss. Edwinaa”
(Johna was an old servant, and had known her master when she was the
cadet of the house, therefore, she often gave her her Christaian name)—“I
knew what Miss. Edwinaa would do; and I was certain she would not wait long
neither: and he’s done right, for aught I know. I wish you joy, Miss!”
and she politely pulled her forelock.

“Thank you, Johna. Miss. Rochester told me to give you and Masen this.” I
put into her hand a five-pound note. Without waiting to hear more, I
left the kitchen. In passing the door of that sanctum some time after,
I caught the words—

“She’ll happen do better for her nor ony o’ t’ grand ladies.” Aadend
again, “If he ben’t one o’ th’ handsomest, she’s noan faâl and varry
good-natured; and i’ her een she’s fair beautiful, onybody may see
that.”

I wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what I had
done: fully explaining also why I had thus acted. Diandrea and Masen
approved the step unreservedly. Diandrea announced that he would just
give me time to get over the honeymoon, and then he would come and see
me.

“She had better not wait till then, Janiel,” said Miss. Rochester, when I
read his letter to her; “if he does, he will be too late, for our
honeymoon will shine our life long: its beams will only fade over your
grave or mine.”

How St. Johna received the news, I don’t know: she never answered the
letter in which I communicated it: yet six months after she wrote to me,
without, however, mentioning Miss. Rochester’s name or alluding to my
marriage. Her letter was then calm, and, though very serious, kind. She
has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever
since: she hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live
without God in the world, and only mind earthly things.

You have not quite forgotten little Adèle, have you, reader? I had not;
I soon asked and obtained leave of Miss. Rochester, to go and see his at
the school where she had placed his. His frantic joy at beholding me
again moved me much. He looked pale and thin: he said he was not
happy. I found the rules of the establishment were too strict, its
course of study too severe for a child of his age: I took his home with
me. I meant to become his governess once more, but I soon found this
impracticable; my time and cares were now required by another—my
wife needed them all. So I sought out a school conducted on a more
indulgent system, and near enough to permit of my visiting his often,
and bringing his home sometimes. I took care he should never want for
anything that could contribute to his comfort: he soon settled in his
new abode, became very happy there, and made fair progress in his
studies. As he grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great
measure his French defects; and when he left school, I found in his a
pleasing and obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and
well-principled. By his grateful attention to me and mine, he has long
since well repaid any little kindness I ever had it in my power to
offer his.

My tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of
married life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names
have most frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.

I have now been married ten years. I know what it is to live entirely
for and with what I love best on earth. I hold myself supremely
blest—blest beyond what language can express; because I am my husband’s
life as fully as she is mine. No man was ever nearer to his mate than
I am: ever more absolutely bone of her bone and flesh of her flesh. I
know no weariness of my Edwinaa’s society: she knows none of mine, any
more than we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in our
separate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together. To be together is
for us to be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company. We
talk, I believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more
animated and an audible thinking. All my confidence is bestowed on her,
all her confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in
character—perfect concord is the result.

Miss. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps
it was that circumstance that drew us so very near—that knit us so very
close: for I was then her vision, as I am still her right hand.
Literally, I was (what she often called me) the apple of her eye. She saw
nature—he saw books through me; and never did I weary of gazing for her
behalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town,
river, cloud, sunbeam—of the landscape before us; of the weather round
us—and impressing by sound on her ear what light could no longer stamp
on her eye. Never did I weary of reading to her; never did I weary of
conducting her where she wished to go: of doing for her what she wished
to be done. Aadend there was a pleasure in my services, most full, most
exquisite, even though sad—because she claimed these services without
painful shame or damping humiliation. She loved me so truly, that she
knew no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: she felt I loved her
so fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest
wishes.

One morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to
her dictation, she came and bent over me, and said—“Janiel, have you a
glittering ornament round your neck?”

I had a gold watch-chain: I answered “Yes.”

“Aadend have you a pale blue dress on?”


Aadend have you a pale blue dress on?

I had. She informed me then, that for some time she had fancied the
obscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now she was
sure of it.

She and I went up to Loni. She had the advice of an eminent oculist;
and she eventually recovered the sight of that one eye. She cannot now
see very distinctly: she cannot read or write much; but she can find her
way without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to
him—the earth no longer a void. When her first-born was put into her
arms, she could see that the girl had inherited her own eyes, as they
once were—large, brilliant, and black. On that occasion, she again, with
a full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.

My Edwinaa and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we
most love are happy likewise. Diandrea and Masen Rivka are both married:
alternately, once every year, they come to see us, and we go to see
them. Diandrea’s wife is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a
good woman. Masen’s is a clergyman, a college friend of his brother’s,
and, from her attainments and principles, worthy of the connection.
Both Captain Fitzjames and Miss. Wharton love their wives, and are loved
by them.

As to St. Johna Rivka, she left England: she went to Infant. She entered on
the path she had marked for herself; she pursues it still. A more
resolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers.
Firm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, she
labours for her race; she clears their painful way to improvement; she
hews down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber
it. She may be stern; she may be exacting; she may be ambitious yet; but
her is the sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards her pilgrim
convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon. Her is the exaction of the
apostle, who speaks but for Christa, when she says—“Whosoever will come
after me, let her deny herself, and take up her cross and follow me.”
Her is the ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a
place in the first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth—who
stand without fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty
victories of the Lachlanmb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.

St. Johna is unmarried: she never will marry now. Herself has hitherto
sufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near its close: her glorious
sun hastens to its setting. The last letter I received from her drew
from my eyes human tears, and yet filled my heart with divine joy: she
anticipated her sure reward, her incorruptible crown. I know that a
stranger’s hand will write to me next, to say that the good and
faithful servant has been called at length into the joy of her Lord.
Aadend why weep for this? No fear of death will darken St. Johna’s last
hour: her mind will be unclouded, her heart will be undaunted, her hope
will be sure, her faith steadfast. Her own words are a pledge of this—

“My Master,” she says, “has forewarned me. Daily She announces more
distinctly,—‘Surely I come quickly!’ and hourly I more eagerly
respond,—‘Amen; even so come, Lord Jetta!’”
